course_title: Critical Perspectives on Citizenship in a Globalized World
Critical Social Policy for Transformative Development
lecturers: ['CG Guharay Gomez', 'dr. A Chhachhi', 'dr. KA Siegmann', 'dr. RBC Huijsmans']

text:
Inhoud
This course introduces students to critical theory and aims to equip students with the conceptual tools forged by some of the major scholars working in the critical tradition such as Horkheimer, Adorno and Marcuse (The Frankfurt School), Althusser, Foucault, Deleuze & Guattari (The Paris School) and Williams, Hall and Gilroy (The Birmingham School). Students learn to apply critical theory as a “martial art”: a means of self-defence against discursive and non-discursive structures of violence without having the right for unfair attacks (i.e., submission to the rules of responsible speech). The course provides students with the necessary historical and theoretical background needed to understand later developments in the fields of critical theory and cultural analysis (as offered by the various majors in the Humanities) and the skills to become “Critical World Citizens” in the present.
Leerdoelen
After completing this course, you will:
  • have basic knowledge of the foundational schools and thinkers of critical theory;
  • have a basic understanding of the main concepts and theories used in critical theory;
  • have a basic understanding of the historical context of the main thinkers and theories used in critical theory;
  • have a basic understanding of the various intersections of class, race, gender and nature that undergird the critical theories studied in this course. 
  • be able to apply critical theory to domains as varied as science, education, culture, media, and sports.

course_title: Critique: The Impact of Philosophy on Social Sciences and Humanities
lecturers: ['CR Koekoek, MSC MA', 'J van der Klaauw, MA', 'L Baan Hofman, MA', 'prof.dr. M Huijer']
text:
Inhoud

Lectures will be recorded.

Tutorials are not obligatory.

What is critical thinking? What is its function in an era of ‘alternative facts’? This module explores some of the most important post-war continental social-philosophical theories and their consequences for disciplinary thinking in the humanities and social sciences. Guiding notion is that of critique, as developed by the Frankfurt School. We investigate the relation between society and the knowledge produced and methods used by social sciences and humanities (but also by medical and environmental sciences). We focus on critical theory (Habermas, Frankfurt School), poststructuralism (Foucault), feminist critique, postcolonial critique, tentacular thinking (Haraway) and critical realism (Latour).

Leerdoelen
  • being able to reflect critically on the various roles that scientific knowledge plays in society
  • being able to analyse and evaluate the different kinds of critique, both historically and systematically   
  • understanding the methodology of philosophical critique with regard to social sciences and humanities, and assessing its relevance for society

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Course description

Cross-cultural competence is about professional ability to make sense of actions and complexities, which require comparison of values, norms and actions (verbal, material, symbolic, etcetera). Future managers must be able to perform a multidimensional analysis of an emergent mix of interactive, communicative and organizing processes – in order to make sense of them, in order to help others understand them, in order to perform efficiently and effectively. 

Cross-cultural competence allows us to understand what individuals mean by words and acts. Dialogical turn in hyper-connected societies of mobile individuals requires a more coaching and servant leadership based type of managers. Students will exercise their methodological skills in deconstructing and changing complex adaptive systems by rhetoric, design, and contextual shifts. Students have to learn how to perform a quick cultural scan of organisations and compare the results across national, organisational, and professional fault lines. We shall also ask students to hone their skills in cross-cultural analysis by submitting a comprehensive team assignment, which will include an analysis of a country of one of their teammembers and a country of Latin-America. In a team the students will analyse these countries on the historical, cultural and economic background, 

The course focuses specifically on the Latin-American cultures. These countries know a turbulent, often violent history, with democratic yet unstable governments and a developing economy. In many cases, the Latin-American countries are still unfolding their own identity. In order to understand these cultures, we cannot judge them by applying cultural models, which are developed based on our western standards. Instead, we should do so by watching their movies, reading their books, seeing their art and, most importantly, by engaging in conversation. 
Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives

At the end of this course, you should be able to:
-    Judging cultural models and evaluate them in different contexts and to reflect on the impact of these models.
-    Performing cross-cultural diagnosis in a real-life practice, thus by comparing different countries developing cross-cultural competence.
-    Investigating a countries' culture by analysing its history and art.
-    Distinguishing own perceptions by experimenting with observations and to reflect on one’s own behaviour and attitude.                
-    Understanding the differences in country cultures and what it is you need to know as a global manager.                            
-    Diagnosing and analyse cross-cultural processes for individual and collective sense making in organizations.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Contents, course description

Many practitioners and academics alike argue that complex societal challenges, including sustainable development, require collaborative processes between different sectors of society (state, market, and civil society). Cross-sector partnerships are therefore also an important part of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) agenda and even have their own goal: the 17th SDG is to ‘strengthen the means of implementation and revitalize the global partnership for sustainable development’. Despite all the positive rhetoric on cross-sector partnerships, critical voices point to their limited success in addressing the systemic causes underlying the severe sustainability challenges of our times. In this course, participants are therefore encouraged to critically analyze the concept of cross-sector partnerships, their role in sustainable development and their possible impact and frailties. As such, the course builds specifically on the core courses Sustainability Grand Challenges and Global Business Strategies, where collaboration for sustainability is introduced. This course, however, focuses on cross-sector partnerships not necessarily from a business perspective, but rather form a multi-actor perspective.
 
In the course, participants are stimulated to critically look at the drivers of cross-sector partnerships, explore different types of cross-sector partnerships and the process of navigating these, carefully assess the interlinkages between partnerships and sustainable development, and view partnerships as new forms of governance and explore issues of legitimacy and democracy. An important element of this course is the link between theoretical concepts and their practical relevance and case studies therefore play an important role. This course is developed and taught by staff of the Partnerships Resource Centre (PrC), a specialist research centre at Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University. The PrC connects scientifically sound research and practitioner experience of cross-sector partnerships to aid sustainable and inclusive development.
Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
After completing this course, participants will be able to:
  • Explain the concept of cross-sector partnerships for sustainable development;
  • Classify the different drivers and challenges of cross-sector partnerships;
  • Distinguish between different types of cross-sector partnerships;
  • Apply theoretical knowledge about partnerships for sustainable development to real-world situations;
  • Explain the interlinkages between partnerships and sustainable development;
  • Analyze cross-sector partnerships from different theoretical perspectives;
  • Critically reflect on the idea of partnerships for sustainable development.

course_title: Crosscultural Psychology - Fundamentals and Ethnic Differences
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud

With increasing globalization, we get in touch with different cultures more and more. In a city such as Rotterdam, where people from over 100 countries live and work, knowledge and skills in cross-cultural contacts have become essential. This minor deals with various important themes across psychological subdisciplines, including emotions and psychopathology in different cultures, cultural differences in education and in attachment, working in intercultural teams, well-being of expatriates and immigrants, and problems in conducting cross-cultural research and assessment.
 
This minor is intended for all students who are interested in intercultural issues and in psychology. The minor aims to increase students’ awareness of cultural differences and contributes to the development of a broader academic attitude. Working during the course with students from diverse cultural backgrounds will deepen students’ knowledge through experiencing different cultural backgrounds and viewpoints themselves.
 
The minor will be open for international students. For this reason, all the material and activities will be in English. The language used in all tutorial groups will in principle be English. It will be possible to answer open ended questions on the exam in Dutch.
 
Students from all educational backgrounds are admissible for this minor. Students who do not have a background in psychology need to be aware they may need to put in extra effort in order to master the material and understand the underlying psychological principles. Students who do not have a background in problem-based learning (PBL) will need to know the didactical model of PBL will be used in this course. Before the course, a short digital introduction will be provided on PBL for these students, which they will need to have completed.

Overview minor modules:

1. Fundamentals in Cross-Cultural Psychology
2. Ethnic Differences

Module 1: Fundamentals in Cross-Cultural Psychology

In this module we will study the main themes within cross-cultural psychology. Classic concepts in this domain will be discussed, as well as the factors that need to be considered when performing and interpreting cross-cultural research. Themes that are subsequently treated are: cultural differences and similarities in cognitions, emotions and autobiographical memory, how normal and abnormal behavior is perceived in different cultures, and cross-cultural issues related to society and work. Examples belonging to this last theme are experiences of expatriates, and preferred leadership styles across cultures.
Teaching method(s): Problem Based learning: Tutorial groups, self-study and lectures.
Teaching materials: Recent journal articles and book chapters, provided on the internet.
Contact hours: 8 hours per week

Module 2: Ethnic Differences

In Module 2, students learn about psychological aspects related to living in a multicultural society. This module deals with more fundamental issues, such as stereotyping and prejudice, acculturation strategies and multicultural identity development. In addition, this module addresses issues that professionals may encounter when dealing with people from different cultural backgrounds in practice. Here one can think of topics such as: the role of ethnicity in diagnostics and treatment of psychopathology, immigrants’ study success, the influence of migration on mental health, discrimination at work and team performance.
Teaching method(s): Problem Based learning: Tutorial groups, self-study and lectures.
Teaching materials:  Recent journal articles and book chapters, provided on the internet.
Contact hours: 8 hours per week

Modules 1 and 2 will be closed with a separate exam each. The exam consists of 50 statements (true/false) and 16 short-answer open-end questions. In addition, during Modules 1 and 2 you will work in couples to prepare a presentation. During the last tutorial meeting of module 2, you will give this presentation to the students in your tutorial group.

The final grade will be a weighted average of both Exam Part 1 and Exam Part 2, plus the grade for the presentation (weights 2 + 2 + 1).
In order to pass the course, the minimum weighted average of both Exam Part 1, Exam Part 2 must be a 5.5. Each exam separately (Part 1 and Part 2), needs to be graded with a 5.0 at minimum. That means students can to some extent compensate an insufficient grade for one part of the minor. In addition, the assessment of the final presentation needs to be a 5.5 or higher.

Students will be offered the possibility to review their answers for each part of the exam shortly after the grades have been announced.

Leerdoelen
Concrete learning objectives:
  • Students gain insight into the following overarching themes: cross-cultural differences in child development, cognitions, emotions, personality, intelligence, psychopathology and the meaning of working.
  • Students gain insight into methodological issues that play a role when conducting cross-cultural research.
  • Students gain insight into ethnic differences and similarities in the domains of (mental) health care, education and the labour market.
  • Students gain insight into the processes playing a role in stereotyping and discrimination.
  • Students gain insight into effective behaviour in intercultural situations.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud This course will survey academic research in the emerging area of FinTech, an interdisciplinary field which studies the application of Information Technology to the Finance area. The FinTech movement began a decade ago with the publication of Nakamoto’s (2008) proposal for the first successful cryptocurrency, Bitcoin. However, it is now recognized that FinTech builds upon important antecedents such as Haber and Stornetta’s (1991) introduction of blockchains and distributed ledgers and Szabo’s (1997) ideas for smart contracts. We will survey the foundational literature of cryptocurrency, blockchains, smart contracts, consensus protocols, and related regulatory issues.  Applications of FinTech in areas such as corporate finance, central banking, investment management, real estate, supply chain management, and personal finance will be studied. We will also study crypto asset investment markets including recent developments in the derivative and NFT markets. We will draw upon the academic literature currently being featured in numerous research conferences and special issues of some of the leading peer reviewed journals.  We will conduct some hands-on data exercises using live FinTech data from public blockchains.
Please note that the Netherlands is a particularly active contributor to FinTech with important applications being introduced in locations such as the Port of Rotterdam: https://www.cryptocoinsnews.com/europes-largest-shipping-port-launches-blockchain-field-lab/

Prof. David Yermacsk (New York University Stern School of Business). Leerdoelen To acquaint students with the fundamentals of blockchains, digital currency, smart contracts, decentralized finance, and other important FinTech topics, while providing an overview of the new academic literature in this area.  The importance of ideas such as crowdfunding, decentralization, algorithmic governance, and financial disintermediation will receive special attention.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud

From art to advertising and from power to politics, cultural studies have inspired and influenced many contemporary debates in society. In this course, we will delve into this ever-expanding field of research. We will discuss classical concepts from culture and media studies like representation, gender, and race. Also, we will investigate the contemporary value of culture and media studies as a field of research and discover emerging concepts and ideas. In doing this, we will move across different visual media like art, film, photography, television, and online media. A part of the classes will be dedicated to critically analysing objects selected by students.

 

Leerdoelen

This course aims to familiarize students with the different theoretical traditions and perspectives in the broad field of culture and media studies. Students learn to critically examine theories and concepts deriving from culture and media studies, and are able to use them in the analysis of contemporary cultural objects. They will learn to present their analyses in a clear and convincing way, both orally and in writing.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud The seminars deals with the problems of doing empirical research: how scholars have tested theories, what methods and data sources have been used, how scholars overcame the problems encountered in empirical research, what are the main limitations of their empirical works, and so on. The seminar provides a forum for discussion of the week's topic and reading material. Students are expected to read and discuss the literature and to summarise it for discussion in class. A critical approach is encouraged. Students therefore learn to appreciate standards of research and how to conduct their own research later on.
 
Topics covered in the course, among others: cultural policies; cultural heritage; cultural demand; artists' labour markets; culture, economy and cities; (temporary) clusters and intermediaries. Leerdoelen The aim of the course is to offer advanced training in the application of cultural economics to specific areas of the cultural and creative industries. The seminar builds on the Cultural Economics: Theory course in Term 1. The aim is to enable students to select areas of special interest and to become familiar on how empirical research is done by scholars in the field of the cultural and creative industries and to learn to evaluate it.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud For better or for worse, economics is a most influential theory of human behavior and a popular tool for rationalizing decisions. Economic perspectives and arguments are important in debates on public policy of almost any kind. Decision-makers in businesses draw heavily on aspects of economic theory. Economic reasoning is also increasingly employed in the cultural sector. In this course, we discuss the theoretical underpinnings of cultural economics, to help students in harnessing economics for their own purposes.
We do so by discussing ‘classic’ theoretical issues and debates that illuminate the foundations of economics. We begin with two fundamental aspects of economics, price theory and welfare economics, as well as their limitations. We continue with four main themes in cultural economics: (1) public goods, (2) intrinsic motivation, (3) uncertainty and taste formation, as well as (4) superstars. We round off the course with a discussion of economic perspectives on entrepreneurship. Leerdoelen This course will help you to better understand the foundations of economics in general. You will develop an overview of the main themes in cultural economics. We encourage a critical, but constructive approach to the application of economics for decision-making in the cultural sector. Usually, the question is not whether economics is perfect but whether there is a superior alternative for a specific purpose, for instance to structure your thoughts, to interpret empirical evidence and to prepare your own empirical research or to convince others. All of this will serve you as a solid basis for subsequent courses, and help you define your specific areas of interest in further stages of the M.A. in Cultural Economics & Entrepreneurship.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud The seminar builds on the ‘Cultural Entrepreneurship: Theory’ course in Term 1. By means of weekly subjects and a number of assignments (including a mini-research in group), students will become familiar with and evaluate how cultural entrepreneurship scholars research the field. The sessions simultaneously deal with a number of prominent entrepreneurship themes and the various research methods that are being applied to address those research themes. Some examples can include case studies of entrepreneurship and place, policy for entrepreneurship, quantitative testing of entrepreneurial traits and successes, entrepreneurial networks, big data challenges in relation to entrepreneurship, ethnography in entrepreneurship, etc. Guest speakers working within the field are invited, and one of the last sessions entails a study trip (if the C19-situation allows us to do so) during which we apply our insights.

The seminar provides a forum for discussion of the weekly topic and reading materials. Students are expected to read and prepare for discussing the literature in class. A critical approach is encouraged. Students get acquainted with the standards of research in entrepreneurship and will be able to practice those standards within individual and group assignments.
  Leerdoelen The aim of the course is to get acquainted with empirical research in the setting of Cultural Entrepreneurship. The course can be considered to be an advanced training in the application of entrepreneurship theory to specific areas of the cultural and creative industries, and should allow students to independently and in group develop research on the subject.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud The notion of “entrepreneurship” is commonly associated with the discovery and pursuit of new business opportunities through the creation of firms. The ultimate aim of entrepreneurial activity is seldom profit or personal wealth-creation, but rather realizing new ideas and being free from restraints. Similarly, artistic and creative work is often about the introduction of novelty, and artists and creative professionals seek to create the conditions and to overcome the barriers to be able to develop works of art and creative goods or services.

Different approaches to and theories on entrepreneurship coincide, which we will explore during this course. The series of lectures in term 1 will introduce students to the diverse facets of the entrepreneurship literature, yet, not without making the necessary connections to the practice of entrepreneurship within the cultural and creative industries. We do so by specialist readings, exercises, group work and interventions by guests. The course introduces students to professional research in cultural entrepreneurship and teaches how to critically engage with this literature. Topics of the course include (but are not limited to):
  • Entrepreneurship: traits or skills?
  • Is cultural entrepreneurship different?
  • A context for entrepreneurship
  • Entrepreneurial strategy
  • Business planning, agile and lean entrepreneurship
Leerdoelen The aim of this course is to offer an advanced training in cultural entrepreneurship by surveying the field of (cultural) entrepreneurship. It provides students with a solid background in the subject as a basis for subsequent courses and it enables them to select areas of special interest to pursue during the MA.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud The scientific study of cultural heritage has developed significantly in recent decades. Not only has the interest in this subject grown explosively, also what is exactly meant by 'cultural heritage' has been changing rapidly.
 
Until recently, attention was focused mainly on forms of material culture of seemingly undisputed value, such as museum artifacts, monuments, and archaeological sites. However, the concept of cultural heritage has broadened considerably. It now also includes intangible forms of culture, such as rituals, customs, and traditions, which are usually associated with non-Western cultures and traditional folk culture. At the same time, within the heritage sector there is a noticeable growing interest in the role of (new) media in the creation and (re)presentation of a shared past. 
 
The course Cultural Heritage Studies offers students an introduction to the above developments. Students take note of recent publications in these fields, do their own research - both individually and in groups - and present their findings during class meetings. For students in Arts and Culture Studies, this course provides an introduction to the heritage branch in the program and elucidates the canonization of arts and culture. Students in History and Media & Communication Studies with an interest in the handling of the present with the past will find this course a welcome addition to their usual curriculum.

NB the maximum number of participants in this course is 25. The aim of this course is to gain knowledge and an understanding of cultural heritage, in particular relating to contemporary developments within the field of heritage studies. This insight is obtained by a) critically examining, summarizing and presenting current, scientific literature; b) applying this literature to concrete examples.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud

In recent years, mainly with the advent of digital technology, new media platforms and transnational media networks have become central in the study of cultural identity and acculturation processes. New media is redefining the meaning of cultural identity and shaping the integration experiences of different ethnic migrant groups in both Western and non-Western societies. The purpose of this course is to unravel the intricate relationships between new media, in, and cultural identity and acculturation through the process of definition, interpretation, and critical analysis. In this course, students will develop their own research project to examine the relationships between new technologies and cultural identity from the perspective of migration, focusing on community networks and practices to explain the new dynamics of connection and bond formation among migrants, and the development of transnational socializing in online environments. Building on qualitative interview and content analysis methodologies, students will investigate the various ways in which (ethnic) migrant groups and institutions are appropriating such new technologies and the implications of these practices for their adaptation experiences in their entirety.

Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • Key theoretical perspectives on the study of cultural identities.
  • The main theoretical approaches to the analysis of the role of digital media in cultural identity processes.
 
Students have the ability and/or propensity to:
  • Critically analyze new media as spaces for communication and network practices adopted by different migrant populations.
  • Analyze digital initiatives focusing on migrants’ experiences in relation to identity negotiations and media use.
  • Collect and analyze data based on interview research and qualitative content analysis.
  • Report and present research findings in a clear, organized style.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud We will study the impact of culture on communication processes in various domains such as time, space, verbal and non verbal communication. We will also analyze major research frameworks and methods as they are applied to the field of cultural differences in communication. Through discussion of intercultural issues and through analysis of numerous real-life cases with the help of visual materials (photographs, videos) and texts, we will improve our own cross-cultural understanding and our intercultural communication  skills.
 
Note: The maximum number of participants is 60
  Leerdoelen Students will acquire an understanding of:
  • The influence of culture on communication style and processes;
  • The main theoretical frameworks, research methodologies, perspectives and issues in the field of cultural aspects of communication;
After completing this course, participants will have improved their intercultural communication skills: they will have acquired conceptual tools which help them in avoiding interpretation errors when dealing with people from a culture different from their own. They will also develop an open attitude   to cultures that are, potentially, very different from their own.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud This research workshop focuses on the relation between theory and research in the domain of cultural participation taken in the broad sense. The questions to be addressed can be summarized as: who engages in which cultural activities and why? Students formulate questions about (specific forms or patterns of leisure or) cultural participation and its relation to people’s socioeconomic background characteristics and formulate hypotheses on the basis of the relevant literature.
Subsequently, they employ data made available by the lecturer to test their hypotheses on social differentiation in cultural participation (be it museum visits, concert or theatre attendance, TV watching, reading, going out, etc), Statistical techniques for causal analysis will be used in order to determine which characteristics of respondents are actually determining their cultural taste or behavior.
Students produce a research report (individually or in duos) that includes a concise literature review on the topic to be analyzed, and a presentation and discussion of the statistical analyses carried out.
 
It is recommended to take this course only after the Statistics course has been completed successfully.
In this course, students learn to answer questions about cultural participation by analyzing existing quantitative data. After this research workshop, they are able to translate substantial questions into adequate statistical analyses and produce a sound report of their work. They learn to critically reflect on the (im)possibilities of empirical research and to interpret their results in light of the original research questions.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud
<html>
<head>
<meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8" /><style type="text/css">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>This course will cover the main components of the arts and cultural management, including business planning, marketing, fundraising, production, governance and the bifurcated leadership structures (so often found in arts organisations). Properly researched case studies from international practice will be used to make the peculiarities of the management of arts and cultural organisations clear.</body>
</html>

Leerdoelen
<html>
<head>
<meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8" /><style type="text/css">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Arts and cultural organisations are in important respects different from other organisations. The goal of this course is to introduce the student to the principles of cultural  management. Here the particular and peculiar questions of management of arts and cultural organisations will be explored.</body>
</html>

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Organisations are of great importance in the production and realization of cultural value. The first half of this course will analyse the fundamental questions underlying the cultural organisations. We explore economic and alternative explanations for the existence of cultural organisations. We analyze the difference between formal and informal organisations in the cultural sector, and their relative importance. We explore the methodological side of studying organisations. How is this best done? How important are metaphors for the imagination of organization? And how important is the interpretive side of the analysis of organisations. Finally we explore how institutional logics within organisations are the most important source of conflict.

The second half of the course explores particular challenges that cultural organisations face, through the analysis by students of a cultural organisation of their choice. Why do creative firms choose to cluster, or integrate? How to motivate creative workers, and is this different from motivating workers in the commercial sector? What type of conflicts are likely to arise in cultural organisations? How do cultural organisations develop a mission? And how can we evaluate the cultural and social goals of cultural organisations?
  Leerdoelen At the end of this course:
  • You can explain the most common economic theories for the existence of firms.
  • You can explain the difference between formal organisations and informal organisations such as innovation commons.
  • You can explain some of the important advantages and disadvantages of different methodological approaches to the study of (cultural) organisations.
  • You can explain the importance of institutional logics in shaping cultural organisations, and how this is a potential source of intra-firm conflict.
  • You are able to explain how we can assess the non-economic goals of an organisation, and how we can evaluate these.
  • You are able to use the theoretical insights above to analyse particular organisations and industries within the cultural sector.
  • You are able to use this analysis to highlight potential danger and opportunities for a cultural organisation.
  • You are able to present your analysis in an academic manner, as well as in a format that would be useful in a cultural organisation.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud This course takes a global perspective in exploring the theoretical social context of cultural policy with examples from European cultural strategy, though policy in the United States and other parts of the world are also examined. Classes are grounded in sociological theory and knowledge will be extended and enhanced through empirical research.  Emphasis is on the various dilemmas facing those who create, study, and work with cultural policy. Topics covered include how culture is defined, what is considered legitimate and consequently worthy of state support; art’s growing position in the marketplace; how globalization may affect local and national culture; the organizational needs of managers versus the creative needs of artists; how consumption practices influence policy and policy’s effect on cultural participation and education. We end the course considering how cultural policy has shifted to match changing cultural and social values.
 
The course is for advanced students interested in academic or applied careers in arts, culture, and public policy. In exploring various forms of culture and cultural research, the course cuts across disciplines, including economics, humanities, and social-psychology, though is grounded primarily in sociological theory and methodology. This course is a seminar and, consequently, the class work is a combination of lecture, discussion, class exercises and student presentation. Students will contribute to the content of the course through discussion and presentation of case studies that serve as exemplars. In this way, the class is research intensive, relying on student interests to direct the exploration of the course's main themes. The class is conducted entirely in English and students are required to discuss and report in every class. Leerdoelen Students will learn to distinguish the main policy concerns debated by academics and those involved in cultural policy creation and research. Students will be able to address these concerns through a foundation of cultural and organizational sociological theory and empirical research. Finally, students will be able to link concepts considered in class to the broader social context and current courses of action.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud In recent decades, cultural sociology has been one of the fastest growing – yet fuzzily bounded – areas of sociological study. Some have even argued that contemporary sociology is witnessing a ‘cultural turn’ – making culture (‘meaning-making’ in a broad sense) a central aspect of sociological inquiry in many different areas, such as politics, economy, the state, etc. However, as ‘culture’ is difficult, if not impossible, to define, discussions often lack conceptual clarity, leading to truisms like ‘culture matters’.
This course addresses major theories and contemporary debates in cultural sociology. Besides discussing classical sociological traditions (Marx, Durkheim, Weber) and conceptions of culture, we will discern six ideal typical approaches in cultural sociology: (1) culture as an instrument of power (neo-Marxism and conflict sociology), (2) culture as (cognitive) structure (neo-Durkheimian sociology and structuralism), (3) culture as meaningful action (neo-Weberian sociology and rationalization), (4) culture as a product of social interaction (symbolic interactionism and ethnomethodology), (5) cultural as signification (semiotics) and (6) culture as embodied practice (practice and performance theory).
While most contemporary research usually draws on several of these approaches, we aim to provide a degree of intellectual clarity by disaggregating these traditions. Including both classical theories as well as related contemporary empirical studies, this course will stimulate systematic and critical sociological thinking, and provide a necessary compass to navigate current debates in cultural sociology.  Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of: ​
  • Current theoretical insights, academic debates and approaches in the sociological thinking about culture
Students have developed skills to:
  • Reproduce and contextualize contemporary theories, insights, and academic debates in cultural sociology
  • Apply relevant cultural sociological theories and concepts to empirical reality

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud
This course is founded in a cultural sociological approach to the phenomenon of tourism, focusing on key concepts and theories which are relevant in the study of tourism as embedded in wider socio-cultural context in which they occur and acquire significance. First, the course will address both seminal theories as well as cutting-edge research on the historical development of tourism, paying particular attention to the underlying interests, activities and concerns which are attached to this phenomenon in its respective context. Moving from tourism and travel in pre-modernity, via the massification of tourism during modernity towards the contemporary nichification of tourism in postmodernity, the course will illuminate central issues related to the practice of tourism in relation to the particular ‘Zeitgeist’ in which it occurs. Second, the course will dive into the practices, motivations and experiences of the tourists themselves, scrutinizing the meanings that they attribute to their travels to and interactions with foreign locations and localities. Third, the destinations of tourists and locals will be of focus, particularly related to transformations of place, host-tourist relationships and issues related to sustainability, both in terms of preserving local culture, economy and the environment. Fourth, rising middle-classes in rapidly developing countries are increasingly having an impact on global tourism flows, resulting in a huge influx of tourists from a plethora of socio-cultural backgrounds, bringing in new opportunities, challenges and considerations. Last, the ever-increasing ubiquity of popular and digital media are brought in dialogue with contemporary and future tourism practices.
Leerdoelen The main aim of this course is to teach students the basics and fundamental knowledge from the field of tourism from a cultural sociological perspective. Through working with a combination of seminal works in this field as well as more state of the art research, students learn to analyze tourism and related practices within the wider socio-cultural and political contexts in which they occur. In doing so, students will be able to reproduce and contextualize important insights, theories and concepts related to a cultural sociological of tourism. In addition, students will be able to critically and systematically analyse complex socio-cultural processes underlying the evolution of tourism in an age characterized by ongoing processes of globalization, mediation and digitization.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud The course is oriented towards developing the understanding of the production and consumption of culture in contemporary societies. It will look at practical aspects of the organization and financing of cultural industries and discuss how these affect the type of art that is created and the cultural products that reach the audiences. Students will be introduced to the key sociological and the cultural economics concepts and theories that help to understand the functioning of cultural and creative industries. In order to highlight the relevance of discussed theoretical perspectives, the lectures will bring in empirical examples from the range of cultural industries taking diverse positions in the arts economy and consider both commercial and non-profit organizations.
  Leerdoelen This course aims at providing students with the basic understanding of the functioning of cultural and creative industries. The lectures introduce the sociological and cultural economics perspectives on the functioning of “high arts” (e.g. contemporary visual art and theatre) and “popular” industries (e.g. film and television) and provide conceptual frameworks to better understand recent developments in cultural industries across sectors and cross-nationally. It deals with applying the theoretical knowledge to real empirical cases by discussing the recent issues and developments in specific cultural organizations or creative fields more generally. The knowledge on the functioning of creative industries offers a useful frame of reference for the remainder of the bachelor program.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud
There is little dispute that the rise of digital technologies – file-sharing software, Internet, smart phones, etc. – has radically transformed cultural markets in the past decades concerning consumers’ purchasing modes, companies’ business models, impact of experts, and overall power relations. What the precise consequences of these transformations are, and will be in the long run, is less evident.
This research workshop focuses on the material and symbolic production of culture in online contexts. We will pay compare traditional and new business models in cultural production; transformations in how audiences find and consume cultural products; and changes in symbolic production of culture associated with new media (including the role of user-generated content).
Students conduct a small research on one of these themes. They formulate a research question, seek appropriate literature, and collect and analyze data to answer their research question. All research questions need to have an explanatory and/or comparative element.
Students can choose to (a) use survey data on how consumers access music, books, or audiovisual materials in Europe (made available by the lecturer), (b) conduct a content analysis of reviews or social media posts, or (c) collect online data on ratings, downloads, or other indicators of popularity.
Leerdoelen
 
Students have  knowledge  and understanding of:
  • State-of the art theory on the topic of material and symbolic production of culture in online contexts;
  • Common research designs and methods to examine this topic.

Students have developed the skills to:
  • Design and execute a small-scale empirical study on the topic of culture online;
  • Report on their findings in oral and written form;
  • Critically reflect on the limitations and the possible societal implications of their research;
  • Constructively work as part of a team.

course_title: Culture, New Media and International Business
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud In international business, it is crucial that the use of various media for internal and external corporate communication is aligned to its own cultural context. This course will analyze the cultural dimensions of international business communication, for instance, how various mobile channels are adopted and perceived in distinct cultural contexts, or how social media could be used to create cohesive groups with their own values and culture. An in-depth understanding of the interplay between culture and media can lead to effective practices to achieve communicative goals in cross-cultural contexts, which is vital for the success of multinational companies. Through case studies, this course will discuss cultural issues in cross-cultural marketing, branding, public relations, and organizational communication. Theories and practical implications supported by empirical case studies will also be introduced to students to build their knowledge base that can inform practice. Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • Academic perspectives on the importance of culture in international business communication.
  • Research on the perception and uses of media in different cultural contexts.
  • The interplay between culture and media in an international business settings.
  • How new media may shape and change social networks and culture.
Students have developed skills to:
  • Effectively apply various media for international business with cultural sensitivity.
  • Strategically use social media to form groups, shape cultures, and maintain social networks that can promote international business.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud What can superhero movies like Black Panther teach us about today’s society? Or series like the Handmaid’s Tale or Black Mirror? What is the cultural value of memes? And who decides what content is (allowed to be) shared via popular platforms like Instagram or Facebook? As a form of entertainment for the masses, popular culture (movies, series, music, social media, games etc.) has always played a key role in society. In this course, we approach popular culture beyond its entertainment function by paying close attention to both its content and its followers, the fans.
 
Often popular culture illustrates, reflects on, and helps to better understand the world we live in through representing or questioning societal changes that take place. In this seminar, we explore the interplay between popular culture, media entertainment, and fandom. We do so by examining topics ranging from meme culture to race, and gender to transnational pop culture.
 
Discussing different theories and popular culture topics each week, we address core questions like: Why and what ways do people engage with popular culture? How has and will popular culture help us understand societal changes?

This course should not be taken if you have already followed CM2232. Leerdoelen

Students have knowledge and understanding of:

  • Key concepts and approaches in theory and research on current and past perspectives on popular culture and its role in society.
  • The relation between popular culture and societal changes.
 
Students have developed skills to:
  • ·Critically assess and compare existing theories on popular culture and societal changes.
  • ·Analyze and reflect upon popular cultural forms using concepts and theories covered in this course.
  • ·Coherently present the discussed themes verbally (and visually) as well as in written assignments.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. B Van den Bergh', 'dr. CJP Lembregts', 'dr. JMT Roos', 'dr. M Szymanowski', 'dr. X Chen', 'prof.dr. G Liberali', 'prof.dr. S Puntoni', 'prof.dr. STLR Sweldens', 'prof.dr. YM van Everdingen', 'prof.dr.ir. A Smidts']
text:
Inhoud

Topics that will be discussed are: 
Motivation in Consumer Behavior (van den Bergh);
Introduction to Marketing Science (Roos);
Consumer Neuroscience (Smidts);
Learning Brand Associations (Sweldens);
Consumer Processing of Numerical Information (Lembregts);
Primer on Experimental Consumer Research (Puntoni);
Machine Learning in Marketing (Liberali);
Social Networks in Marketing (Chen);
Adoption and Diffusion of Innovations (van Everdingen);
Structural Demand Models (Szymanowski)

Leerdoelen The main goal of the course is to familiarize students with key areas of marketing research as well as with different methodological approaches that are influential in marketing. As a result, the course will cover a wide variety of topics and perspectives, spanning consumer behavior, marketing strategy, and quantitative marketing topics. The broad set of topics and methods reflects the diversity of marketing research. You are not expected to pursue research in all of these areas in the future. Rather, we would like the course to help you understand the field and form a clearer idea of what area might be most suitable for you.
The course also serves two additional goals: introducing students to RSM marketing faculty and introducing faculty to students. Our hope is that this course will offer a useful platform on which students can build to develop a successful line of research during their time at ERIM, by exposing them early on to the research carried out at the RSM marketing department and by facilitating interactions between students and faculty and thereby increasing the likelihood of collaborations.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud

Hier staat een omschrijving van de inhoud van deze testcursus

Leerdoelen Dit is een testcursus t.b.v. inwerken Key User 77147

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Course description

The emergence of information and data technologies, together with the sophistication of tools in econometrics and machine learning, have led to a radical shift in the way marketing operations are run. The focus of companies has been shifted away from product-centric approaches and mass marketing campaigns to customer-centric campaigns tailored to the needs and wants of each individual customer. Such campaigns target a well-chosen subset of customers, at a well-chosen time, and with a well-chosen incentive. At their core, they require strong data analytics tools in order to be able to predict each customer’s behavior and derive optimal marketing interventions.

This elective will provide students with the necessary knowledge and skills to tackle these challenges. The course will focus as much on the managerial questions as well as on the use of methodologies to address these questions. The elective will be articulated around the core metric of Customer Lifetime Value (CLV). We will especially focus on customer-centric tactics firms can use to:

-    Enhance customer acquisition (e.g. customer referral programs, seeding strategies)
-    Boost customer spending (e.g. loyalty schemes, customer engagement)
-    Prevent customer churn (e.g. proactive retention programs).

To address these challenges, we will use state-of-the-art machine learning methods, including boosting, uplift models, decision trees, etc. Finally, we use rely heavily on the notion of A/B testing and randomized control trials in order to optimize personalized interventions of firms.

Leerdoelen Learning Objectives

-    Understand and explain the importance of customer analytics in today’s business world;
-    Possess a good expertise of companies’ best practices in the domain of customer analytics, and think critically about them;
-    Understand, explain and apply the latest research in the area of customer analytics;
-    Understand and explain key customer analytics tools companies have at their disposal to develop customer-centric strategies;
-    Manipulate and do data analyses using customer analytics tools using the R programming language (via tutorials);
-    Provide and justify concrete managerial recommendations to non-technical audiences through (online) presentations and written reports.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Course description

The emergence of information and data technologies have led to a radical shift in the way marketing operations are run. The focus of companies has been shifted away from product-centric approaches and mass marketing campaigns to customer-centric campaigns tailored to the needs and wants of each customer. Customer-centric marketing campaigns target a well-chosen subset of customers, at a well-chosen time, and with a well-chosen incentive. Moreover, they also require a good monitoring of their impacts on firms’ profits. In other words, a customer-centric campaign requires companies to answer four key questions:

(1)    Who to target?
(2)    What to offer?
(3)    When to target?
(4)    How to evaluate effectiveness?

Customer-centric marketing can be applied to any domain of marketing and, so, is an approach that can be broadly adopted by multinationals. In this course, we will focus on the three key marketing tasks, which relate to the stages of a customer lifecycle: customer acquisition, customer development and customer retention. 

The course will focus as much on the managerial questions and challenges, as well as on the use of methods to address these questions. This elective will be articulated around the customer lifecycle and rely on the core metric of Customer Lifetime Value (CLV). Leerdoelen Learning Objectives

-    Understand and explain the importance and meaning of customer-centric marketing for today’s businesses;
-    Possess a good expertise and think critically about companies’ practices in the domain of customer centricity;
-    Understand and explain the latest research in the area of customer centricity;
-    Understand and explain the general intuition behind the methods companies have at their disposal to develop a customer-centric marketing strategy;
-    Provide and justify concrete managerial recommendations to non-technical audiences through (online) presentation and (digital) reporting.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Contents, course description
How can companies gain and sustain competitive advantage in an increasingly competitive environment? In recent years, companies have realized that a crucial source of competitive advantage lies in the provision of a compelling customer experience. Customer experience is comprised of all cognitive, emotional, physical, sensorial, and social elements that mark the customer’s interactions with companies or other market actors (De Keyser et al. 2015). Due to the rapid rise of digital and mobile devices, customers are increasingly valuing seamless experiences. In response, leading companies have decided to hire so-called “customer experience managers” to improve their customer experiences. This course discusses the general determinants of great customer experiences across all touch points (prior, during and after purchase) and introduces methods to improve customer experiences.

  Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
At the end of this course students will be able to:
  • Understand and explain the importance of customer experience management for business.
  • Recognize, understand and explain the determinants of great customer experiences.
  • Analyse companies’ customer experiences and identify strengths and weaknesses.  
  • Understand and apply methods and techniques to improve customer experiences.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
​
Consumers are becoming more and more knowledgeable and demanding and contact firms in many different situations. These consumers require the formation of tailored value creation systems to better match their needs. As a result, business and marketing strategies have shifted from the traditional product-centric to a more customer-centric approach. The emerging challenge for firms is how to best support and activate consumers and also learn about their product needs. Increasingly firms and consumers work closely together in the value creation process across all stages of the value chain. In the information search stage, firms attempt to maximize the accuracy of their recommendations by also incorporating consumer insights. Firms allow their customers to customize products to their own taste, rely on customers to generate ideas for new products, use customers’ spare resources (e.g. cars, money, products) in order to create a community of sellers and buyers, or entirely depend on consumer input to create value for other consumers. To be successful, these new business models often use non-conventional business models and digital commerce strategies to interact with consumers.

The sessions of the course cover the following topics: Online Personalization, Recommendation Systems, Crowdsourcing, Mass-Customization, Crowdfunding, Consumer-driven Pricing, Product Reviews, User Generated Content, Online Communities, Sharing Economy.
  Leerdoelen Learning Objectives

The first goal of the course is to provide students with a better understanding of how firms and consumers interact to create greater consumer value and how this process can best be organized. Different stages in the value creation process in which consumer-firm interactions take place are defined and analyzed (i.e. customer journey). Emerging channels and IT-enabled systems that can be used for these different interactions receive special attention. The second goal of the course is for students to learn how to analyze consumer channel usage decisions in each of the interaction stages. The course focuses on consumers’ information search, purchase decisions, product use, and post-consumption behavior. Two key questions guide these analyses: (a) How can individual consumers best be supported in the stages of the value chain? (b) How can consumers be activated so that they themselves become value co-creators?

At the end of this course students will be able to:
•    Understand and explain the importance of customer-firm interactions for business success.
•    Recognize, understand and explain consumer decisions throughout the stages of value creation process.
•    Analyze customer-centric business models (and their sustainability) and identify strengths and weaknesses.  
•    Understand and apply this knowledge in real-life business cases.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['C Wan, MA', 'dr. A Priante', 'prof.dr. DGJ Bongaerts']
text:
Inhoud

Contents, course description

Data is a key business resource. Web stores such as Amazon or Coolblue use customer data to dispatch purchased products and to make recommendations of new products; banking service providers such as ING or HSBC use data for processing cash and ATM transactions and for assessing a client’s credit worthiness; manufacturers such as BMW and Tesla use data to design and produce cars and to propel self-driving cars. Often, this data is spread within the organization through multiple information systems. In order for organizations to operate successfully, they need to be able to share data. Data management is the field dedicated to enabling the sharing of data such that it is available at the right time, place, user and quality. This course introduces data management topics such as database design, data preparation, manipulation, modeling, alongside with discussions on ethical frameworks that should guide the management of data and data privacy issues. 
In addition, the course provides an introduction to blockchain, which is a new and atypical way of organizing data. This type of data solution arose in the wake of the global financial crisis of 2007-2009 with the introduction of Bitcoin, the first cryptocurrency. Ever since, there has been an enormous growth in different types of blockchain based business solutions, some of them meaningful, some of them not. We discuss the basic design, logic and economic incentives underlying the blockchain technology, and discuss real-life applications, hypes and scandals.

Leerdoelen Learning Objectives

•    Understand, describe and discuss data management topics, such as database design, and data preparation, quality, manipulation, modeling and analysis
•    Learn and apply SQL methods for managing and analyzing data
•    Develop a critical understanding and ability to use data management plan frameworks
•    Understand, describe and discuss the technical design, economic incentives, and potential applications of blockchain
•    Understand, discuss and critically analyze ethical and privacy issues related to data management

Inhoud The course starts by introducing the basic types of data, data quality, preprocessing techniques, and measures of similarity and dissimilarity. Then it describes data classification techniques and classification evaluation measures. After that data clustering techniques and clustering evaluation measures are explained.
 
In order to better assimilate the topics covered during lectures, the students will work in teams on several assignments on the discussed topics. The students will also write a report describing the proposed solutions. Leerdoelen Knowledge and understanding of: data characteristics, classification techniques, classification evaluation measures, clustering techniques, and clustering evaluation measures.
​Be able to apply data mining techniques.

course_title: Data Processing and Analyses in R
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud

This course is an introduction in basic data science skills for psychologists. Students will learn to develop data analysis scripts in the programming language R. This course is also the basis for later courses using R for inferential statistics.

R is a free software environment for statistical computing and data visualization that has become in the last couple of years the de-facto-standard tool for advanced statistics and reproducible research in psychology and social sciences.

Leerdoelen At the end of the course the student will be able to develop scripts in the programming language R. The acquired data science skills comprise
  • reading data files in different formats
  • pre-processing data such as data wrangling, transformation, aggregation and filtering
  • data visualization
  • descriptive statistics

lecturers: ['dr. R van den Akker', 'S Koevoets', 'SM Wieman, MSc']
text:
Inhoud

In this course students discover why data visualisation is becoming increasingly important – both in the field of journalism and in the field of science. There are nowadays more and more unseen data that can or should be disclosed. Visualisation is the apparent answers to open up this vast amount of ‘big data’. Data visualisation is also needed to communicate effectively with an audience that is overloaded with information. Researchers who want to successfully disseminate their work should also think about how to construct compelling and effective visualisations. Basic knowledge of data visualisation principles will also help us to understand and apply data visualisation tools and techniques that have become freely available on the Internet, and to interact with data visualisation libraries and online communities. Data visualisation also enables us to incorporate the vast amount of open data, in particular since national governments and international organisations have opened their databases and made them accessible through interactive data visualisation tools.

Leerdoelen The learning objectives of this course are twofold. On the one hand, we will teach you the basics of creating effective, creative and beautiful visualisations. On the other hand, we will teach you how to better understand the world of data and data visualisations and how to develop a critical attitude towards the politics of design and data visualisation.
 
At the end of this course students should be able to:
  • Understand, apply and reflect on the basic principles of good visuals (‘remove to improve’)
  • Communicate a story with data visuals
  • Find and apply (open-source) data visualisation tools
  • Explore and visualise data from (open-access) databases
  • Understand the politics of design and reflect critically on data visualisation in art, journalism and science

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['E. Buitenhuis - Linssen', 'L.M.R. Nijs - de Langen', 'P. Bremen']

course_title: Data-Driven Dreams: The potential and challenges of data-driven technologies in healthcare
college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
text:
Inhoud
The allure of a ‘data-driven’ future healthcare system continues to seduce many. Driven by technological developments and increasing opportunities for algorithmic analysis of large and varied datasets, the latest years have seen a continuous stream of hypes and ‘buzzwords’ about the potential of data-driven healthcare technologies. These range from notions like ‘Big Data’, predictive medicine and data science to more recent expressions of hope and potential related to Artificial Intelligence and subfields like machine learning. The underlying promise is remarkably similar: healthcare is expected to improve significantly because more data is collected from varied sources and better analytical techniques are available to meaningfully process these data. Consequently, healthcare delivery is argued to become better, in terms of ‘prevention’ (e.g. early detection of disease markers) or ‘personalization’ (care tailored to individual needs).

Not everybody shares these high hopes regarding new data-driven technologies in healthcare. Many scholars in the field of Critical Data Studies have emphasized the dangers of the perceived “radical shift” that these data-driven healthcare technologies bring. Expressed fears in the scientific and media debates take all sorts of shapes. Publications describe how data analytics will reinforce discrimination and enlarge social inequality, how painful and wrong conclusions are drawn from limited healthcare data and how the use of data analytics could challenge the authority of medical professionals and promote defensive decision-making which might harm patients. Simultaneously, the media often fuels these fears by repetitions of all sorts of modern myths and references to stories in which technologies are misused and out-of-control leading to a variety of harmful effects. Stories about how a large supermarket chain knew that a teen girl was pregnant before her father did are frequently repeated and references to dystopian stories are often made (think about the books Brave New World, 1984, movies such as Minority Report and series such as Black Mirror).

From a medical perspective, several scholars versed in Evidence-Based Medicine take issue with radical claims that data-driven technologies promise to sideline many of the established scientific methodologies, while many of the methodological issues are still relevant with big data analyses. The fear is that based on innovative data analytics, we start to see patterns in data where none exist and that limitations and biases in data will be amplified, leading to incomplete or misguided decision-making by medical professionals and healthcare policymakers with possible detrimental consequences.

This course provides students with insights into the potential and the challenges that come with the set of data-driven technologies in healthcare. Students will gain a better understanding of both the practical aspects of these technologies (i.e. a basic understanding of the logic behind data science and machine learning), but also the relevant political and managerial discussions about how to embed such technologies in healthcare contexts. This course therefore builds on a multidisciplinary, socio-technical perspective on data-driven technologies that also takes into consideration their social, legal, and ethical aspects. This broader, multidisciplinary perspective is not only relevant for better understanding the promises and limits of data-driven healthcare technologies, but also brings students as future healthcare managers in a better position to make balanced decisions about what such technologies can and cannot do.

Language: Lectures are in English

course_title: Data-Driven Dreams: The potential and challenges of data-driven technologies in healthcare
college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['dr. JWM Weggelaar - Jansen', 'dr. RLE Wehrens', 'J Kostenzer', 'MJ Stevens, MSc', 'RE Michels']
