Eetstoornissen zijn de afgelopen decennia steeds meer voor het voetlicht gekomen. Zowel in de wetenschap als in de media wordt er relatief veel aandacht aan besteed. Maar wat is er nu eigenlijk precies over bekend?
Seksuele stoornissen zijn veelal een taboe voor de cliënt, maar zijn vaak ook voor de psycholoog niet het makkelijkste onderwerp om over te beginnen. Des te belangrijker dus om er in de opleiding aandacht aan te besteden. Welke seksuele disfuncties kunnen we tegenkomen bij mannen en vrouwen, wat is er bekend over de achterliggende mechanismen, en hoe kunnen deze stoornissen het best behandeld worden?
Aan slaapstoornissen wordt in het psychologisch wetenschappelijk onderzoek nog relatief weinig aandacht besteed. In de praktijk is het echter één van de meest voorkomende stoornissen, die ook vaak als comorbide stoornis optreedt, en nadelige consequenties heeft voor ons psychisch- en sociaal functioneren. Voor een klinisch psycholoog daarom van belang om hier kennis over te hebben.
 
In dit blok komen van alle hierboven genoemde stoornissen de verschijningsvormen en theoretische verklaringsmodellen aan bod. Tevens wordt er aandacht besteed aan de verschillende behandelingsmethoden en de effectiviteit hiervan. Hoewel het zwaartepunt ligt bij dergelijke psychopathologie in volwassenen, wordt deze problematiek in kinderen en adolescenten ook behandeld in dit blok.
 
Blokopdracht dynamische diagnostiek
In het blok zal ook aandacht besteed worden aan psychodynamische psychodiagnostiek. In dit blok staan enkele projectieve tests centraal, namelijk de Defense Style Questionnaire, de Rorschachtest en de Thematische Apperceptie test. Er wordt niet alleen uitgebreid ingegaan op de inhoud van deze tests, maar ook op de betrouwbaarheid, validiteit, scoring en klinische relevantie van deze tests.

De diagnostiekopdracht is een onderdeel van de eisen voor het behalen van de Basisaantekening Psychodiagnostiek van het Nederlands Instituut van Psychologen (NIP).
 
Leerdoelen Doel van dit blok is kennis verwerven over recente wetenschappelijke inzichten met betrekking tot de verschijningsvormen, theoretische verklaringsmodellen en behandelmethoden van eetstoornissen, seksuele stoornissen en slaapstoornissen bij zowel volwassenen als kinderen en adolescenten.

Aan het eind van dit blok, heb je substantiële kennis van …
  • de prevalentie, etiologie en (evidence-based) behandeling van anorexia nervosa;
  • de prevalentie, etiologie en (evidence-based) behandeling van bulimia nervosa;
  • de prevalentie, etiologie en (evidence-based) behandeling van de eetbuistoornis;
  • eetproblematiek bij kinderen;
  • psychologische factoren die een rol spelen bij obesitas;
  • de rol die lichaamsbeeld en zelfwaardering spelen bij eetstoornissen;
  • de belangrijkste (neuro)biologische principes van seksualiteit; 
  • de seksuele responscyclus;
  • de (informatie ver)werking van het seksuele systeem;
  • de prevalentie, etiologie en behandeling van seksuele stoornissen bij de man;
  • de prevalentie, etiologie en behandeling van seksuele stoornissen bij de vrouw;
  • de effecten van (farmacotherapie bij) psychiatrische stoornissen op seksualiteit;
Tevens heb je aan het eind van dit blok basale kennis van …
  1. de prevalentie, etiologie en psychologische behandeling van slaapstoornissen;
  2. de meetpretentie, validiteit en scoring van de Defense Style Questionnaire;
  3. de meetpretentie, betrouwbaarheid, validiteit, testafname en scoring van de Rorschach-test;
  4. de meetpretentie, betrouwbaarheid, validiteit, testafname en scoring van de Thematische Apperceptie Test (TAT).
Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

Inhoud Econometrics is characterized by the combination of economic research questions, use of empirical data, application of statistical and mathematical methods, and the use of software to estimate and evaluate models. All these topics are extensively discussed in the lectures and practised in the tutorials.
  • Lectures and exercise lectures: Introduction to econometrics, research questions, methods. The linear regression model (simple and multiple), method of least squares, testing. Non-linear models, maximum likelihood, some asymptotic theory of estimation and testing. The models and methods are motivated by economic applications and applied in practical examples. The required econometric methods make intensive use of earlier courses in the programme, in particular statistics, matrix algebra and analysis.
  • Tutorials: Exercises on theory and applications. Further, some tutorials consist of computer sessions to apply econometric techniques by means of the software package EViews.
Leerdoelen
  • Learn the mathematical structure and statistical properties of linear and non-linear regression models by means of matrix methods and statistical analysis.
  • Understand the process of econometric modelling as an interplay of economic insights, data properties, and statistical model assumptions.
  • Get experienced in the mathematical analysis and statistical evaluation of econometric models.
  • Get experienced in the practical interpretation of outcomes of econometric analysis and in choosing between alternative models and methods.
  • Get practical experience in analysing economic data by means of econometric software on the PC.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The lectures have been transformed into videos that will be discussed in online zoom sessions. The tutorials and exercise lectures are also all done online. Extra Bij het (her)tentamen mag alleen gebruik worden gemaakt van een eenvoudige rekenmachine, niet van een grafische of programmeerbare.

Inhoud The lectures are a follow-up on the lectures in Econometrics 1. The following topics will be discussed:
  • Models with heteroskedasticity and/or serial correlation
  • Models with endogenous regressors
  • Models for limited dependent variables (logit, probit, multinomial)
After this course the student will have practical and theoretical knowledge of various extensions of the linear model (among which: heteroskedasticity, serial correlation, endogeneity). The student will also have knowledge of models for limited dependent variables (logit model, probit model, multinomial).

The student will be able to apply the theory in practice, and will also gain experience in the analysis of economic data using Eviews. Leerdoelen
  • After this course the student will have practical and theoretical knowledge of various extensions of the linear model (among which: heteroskedasticity, serial correlation, endogeneity).
  • The student will also have knowledge of models for binary and multinomial dependent variables (logit and probit models).
  • The student will be able to apply the theory in practice, and will also gain experience in the analysis of economic data using Eviews.
Extra The written examination grade must at least be 4.5 in order to have the assignment grades count for your full grade.

Inhoud
Instructor: Dr A. Schnucker (EUR)
 
Short subject description:
This course provides knowledge on the quantitative analysis of economic data.
 
Course contents:
In this course we provide an understanding of basic econometric methods. Knowledge of these methods allows one to understand modern empirical economic literature and to perform one's own analysis of economic and business data. The technique of regression is discussed, as well as various extensions that are needed in concrete applications to deal with, for example, heteroskedasticity, autocorrelation, endogeneity, and non-linearities. Furthermore an introduction to discrete choice modeling is given. The main emphasis of the course is on the interpretation of models and outcomes of estimation and testing procedures. The students practice this themselves by analyzing economic and business data by means of the software R and by deriving and interpreting formulas for basic models and concepts.
Leerdoelen After this course students will be able to apply econometric techniques to answer empirical questions and will be able to critically evaluate econometric models.

Inhoud
Instructor: Prof. B. van der Klaauw (VU) and Dr H.G. Bloemen (VU)
 
Short subject description:
This course focuses on drawing inference from cross-sectional and panel data using techniques that are frequently used in applied econometric research.
 
Course contents:
Many empirical questions in economics require estimating causal parameters. Regression models provide correlations which only have a causal interpretation if the zero conditional mean assumption holds. This assumption is often violated, for example when there are omitted variables, non-random sampling, reversed causality or measurement errors in regressors. In this course we discuss methods dealing with these confounding factors. In particular, we consider limited dependent variable models, instrumental variables estimation, panel data models and sample weighting. In this course, we introduce the potential outcomes model, which is the most general model for defining treatment effects such as average treatment effect, average treatment effect on the treated, quantile treatment effects and local average treatment effects. The emphasis of the course is on identification, estimation and interpretation rather than a thorough treatment of the asymptotic properties of the estimators. During the course applications of the different methods are discussed, mainly in the fields of labor economics, health economics, and the economics of education.
Leerdoelen The key objective of the course is applying microeconometric techniques rather than deriving econometric and statistical properties of estimators. After the course student should be able to decide about the appropriate model, apply the estimation method correctly, and they should be able to interpret the estimation results.

Inhoud
Instructor: Prof. S.J. Koopman (VU)
 
Short subject description:
This course provides knowledge on the quantitative analysis of economic time series.
 
Course contents:
In this course we provide an understanding of basic econometric methods for the analysis of time series.  Knowledge of these methods allows one to understand modern empirical economic literature and to perform one's own analysis of economic and business time series data. Autoregressive Moving-Average (ARMA) models are considered for stationary time series. Generalized Autoregressive Conditional Heteroskedasticity (GARCH) models are discussed for describing the time-varying volatility of time series. Models (and tests) for deterministic and stochastic trends are addressed. It is discussed how forecasts are computed and assessed. Further, multivariate time series models are considered: the Vector Autoregression (VAR) and cointegration. The main emphasis of the course is on the interpretation of models and outcomes of estimation and testing procedures. The students practice this themselves by analyzing economic and business time series by means of the econometric software package EViews and by interpreting and extending formulae for basic models and concepts.
Leerdoelen After this course students will be able to apply time series models to answer empirical questions and will be able to critically evaluate such models.

Inhoud Het vakgebied econometrie wordt gekenmerkt door een combinatie van economische vraagstellingen, gebruik van empirische gegevens, toepassing van statistische en wiskundige methoden, en gebruik van software om modellen te schatten en te evalueren. Al deze onderwerpen komen uitgebreid aan de orde in de hoorcolleges en worden geoefend bij de sommencolleges en in de practica.
  • Hoorcollege en sommencollege: Inleiding econometrie, vraagstellingen, modellen, methoden. Het lineaire regressiemodel (enkelvoudig en meervoudig), methode van kleinste kwadraten, toetsen. Niet-lineaire modellen, maximale aannemelijkheid, enige asymptotische theorie van schatten en toetsen. De modellen en methoden worden gemotiveerd vanuit economische toepassingen en toegepast in praktische voorbeelden. De benodigde econometrische methoden maken intensief gebruik van eerdere vakken uit het programma, met name statistiek, lineaire algebra en analyse.
  • Practicum: Opgaven over theorie en toepassingen. Voorts wordt enige malen een computer-practicum gehouden, waar econometrische technieken worden toegepast met het pakket EViews.
Leerdoelen
  • Leren van de wiskundige structuur en de statistische eigenschappen van lineaire en niet-lineaire regressiemodellen, door middel van matrixmethoden en statistische analyse.
  • De processen van het econometrische modelleren als snijvlak van economische inzichten, data eigenschappen en statistische modelaannames begrijpen.
  • Vertrouwd raken met het analyseren van de wiskundige en statistische structuur van econometrische modellen.
  • Vertrouwd raken met de praktische interpretatie van de uitkomsten van econometrische analyse en het kiezen tussen alternatieve modellen en methoden.
  • Opdoen van praktische ervaring met het analyseren van economische data met behulp van econometrische software op een PC.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar De hoorcolleges zijn verwerkt in videos die besproken worden in online zoom sessies. De practica en sommencolleges worden ook allemaal online uitgevoerd. Extra Bij het (her)tentamen mag alleen gebruik worden gemaakt van een eenvoudige rekenmachine, niet van een grafische of programmeerbare.

Inhoud
Het college is een vervolg op het college Econometrie 1 en bestaat uit de volgende onderwerpen:
  • Modellen met heteroskedasticiteit en seriecorrelatie
  • Modellen met endogene regressoren
  • Modellen voor kwalitatieve data (logit, probit, multinomiaal)

Na dit college heeft de student kennis van de theorie over diverse uitbreidingen van het lineaire model (waaronder: heteroskedasticiteit, seriecorrelatie, endogeniteit). Daarnaast heeft de student kennis van modellen voor keuzegedrag (logit, probit, multinomiale variabelen).

De student kan de theorie ook daadwerkelijk toepassen in de praktijk, en heeft ook ervaring met het zelf analyseren van economische data met behulp van Eviews.
Leerdoelen
  • Na afloop van het vak heeft de student praktische en theoretische kennis van verschillende existensies van het lineaire model (onder andere: heteroskedasticiteit, serie-correlatie, endogeniteit).
  • Studenten hebben ook kennis van modellen voor binaire en multinomiale afhankelijke variabelen (logit en probit modellen).
  • Studenten zijn in staat theorie in de praktijk toe te passen, en zullen ervaring opdoen in het analyseren van economische data met gebruik van Eviews.
Extra Het cijfer voor het schriftelijk tentamen moet minstens 4.5 zijn om de opdrachtcijfers te laten tellen.

lecturers: ['dr. A Quintavalla', 'drs. EC Smit - Bennemeer', 'prof.dr. K Heine', 'prof.mr.dr. F Weber']
text:
Inhoud
This course is designed for students who are interested in an analytical understanding of European integration that goes beyond ‘black letter law’, reflecting the growing need of more interdisciplinary studies of European integration. Students will learn to use the economics tool box in order to comprehend and to evaluate law and policy proposals towards more (or less) European integration.
 
The teaching content consists of two parts. The first part of the lecture is dedicated to the theoretical understanding of economic integration, including a basic understanding of international trade theory. Topics are: theorem of comparative advantages, free trade, protection, tariffs, stages of integration and federalism theory. Emphasis is placed on a qualitative understanding of these topics. The second part of the lecture applies the gained theoretical insights to topical problems of European integration. Topics are, for example: the concept of regulatory competition, which will be linked to the famous ECJ decisions ‘Cassis de Dijon’ and ‘Centros’, European state aid control, Digital Governance and Common Agricultural Policy.
 
Leerdoelen After having completed this course successfully, a student will be able to:
  1. Describe and analyze the historical and institutional framework of European integration as well as the economic theories dealing with integration issues.
  2. Analyze and assess the interrelation between the political process and European economic integration.
  3. Develop and conduct independently academic research by using economic theories and legal analysis.

Inhoud
<html>
<head>
	<title></title>
	<style type="text/css">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
	</style>
</head>
<body>This 8-ECTS course aims at giving students an overview of the most important insights from the economic analysis of private law. It combines economic analysis of property law, tort law, and contract law. As far as property law is concerned, the course integrates the legal and the economic approach to ownership and illustrates costs and benefits of different ways to protect entitlements. As far as tort law is concerned, the course offers a comparative analysis of the legal principles from an economic perspective, particularly regarding the structure of liability, the damage compensation, and the insurance. As far as contract law is concerned, the course illustrates its goals and functions from an economic perspective. Moreover, it aims to provide a functional understanding of the spectrum of feasible contracts and of their use in legal practice.</body>
</html>

Inhoud This course offers an introduction to the economic analysis of regulation, which is broadly interpreted as government intervention in market processes. The course illustrates the purposes of regulatory intervention from a welfare economics perspective, and it discusses the tension between public and private interest in regulatory choices. A special focus of this course is on issues of European regulation and on cost-benefit analysis.

course_title: Economic Geography of Creativity and Urban Development
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud During the past decade, the concept of creative economy along with that of creative industries have experienced an intensifying academic research and policy attention. The course critically investigates theories and issues linked to culture, creativity, economy and cities. It will provide students with a contrasting set of views on the role of cultural and creative industries in cities through the use of theories, case studies and fieldtrips. Topics discussed include: the role of culture and creativity in   cities across centuries, the emergence of a creative city (e.g. a fashion capital), the economic geography of cultural production, cultural-led urban (re)generation, gentrification, circular economy, cultural intermediaries, (temporary) clusters, the black box of urban growth. We emphasize an analytical approach in understanding the dynamic development of cultural and creative industries and place, and the issues that arise from them.
 
 
Note
  • The maximum number of participants is 30.
  • This course is only open to Pre-Master students in Cultural Economics and Entrepreneurship, BA students in International Bachelor Arts and Culture Studies (IBACS) and BA Algemene Cultuurwetenschappen
Leerdoelen In this seminar students will acquire knowledge and understanding of the spatial dimension and characteristics of creativity as well as the connections between the development of cultural and creative industries and the growth of cities and regions. Special attention is dedicated the role cultural and creative industries play in supporting the transition to the circular economy.
At the end of the course students should be able:
  • To develop knowledge and understanding of theories applied to the spatial dimensions of creativity;
  • To apply concepts and theories to specific case studies in group presentations, discussions and written assignments;
  • To explain main issues and limitations of theories; critically assess the value and relevance of models, concepts and theories.

Inhoud

Why are some countries rich, and some poor? When, how, and why have widespread differences in the wealth of nations emerged? Economic history addresses these (and other) questions. This course starts by looking into the Great Divergence – the process whereby Western Europe started industrialising and growing at sustained growth rates, and thus diverge from the rest of the world. Why did the Industrial Revolution take place in England and not elsewhere in the world? Why could other Western countries easily catch up with England, while large parts of other world regions remained underdeveloped? Historical developments can teach us what is important for successful economic development and catching-up. As a central task, the course will therefore develop the “standard model” of industrialisation and development, and evaluate the role played for development by institutions and technological progress.

lecturers: ['dr. AP Markiewicz', 'dr. D Sisak', 'prof.dr. OH Swank', 'prof.dr. OR Marie']
text:
Inhoud The minor aims to broaden as well as deepen the knowledge and understanding of economics for individuals trained in econometrics on several dimensions.

Module 1 : "Theoretical Microeconomics"
This module begins with an introduction to/refresher of game theory to lay the methodological foundations. In the rest of the course we consider classical strategic problems of individual interaction such as 
 
  • problems of coordination
  • communication and information exchange
  • contests & tournaments
  • bargaining
After a general analysis of these strategic situations, we apply the framework to questions of economic relevance.


Module 2 (Dr Agnieszka Markiewicz):  "Macroeconomics: Theory and Practice"
In this module we will study the long run behaviour of economy and its short-run fluctuations. 
In the first part (long-run), we will cover economic growth and unemployment. 
In the second part (short-run), the focus will be on the consumption, investment and asset prices’ determination.
The models presented in this course are an introduction to modern macroeconomics and build on the 1st year macroeconomics course. We will study the applications of the models using academic papers.

Module 3 (Prof Olivier Marie): "Applied Micro-Econometrics Methods"
The module is about micro-econometric empirical strategies used to estimate causal relationships that are of interest to economists. These include:
  • Lab & field experiments
  • Randomized control trials
  • Difference-in-differences
  • Propensity score matching
  • Instrumental variables
  • Regression discontinuity
 
The module will describe the advantages (and disadvantages) of these different empirical strategies to identify the causal effect of a treatment. Students will learn what kind of identifying assumptions different empirical strategies are based on. We will also appraise which data requirements have to be met for the successful application of a particular strategy.
 
This will be done, for each method in turn, by:
  1. reviewing the econometric theory behind the various methods
  2. go through empirical papers which have successfully applied these methods
Leerdoelen The goal of this minor is to introduce students to important macroeconomic and microeconomic problems and theories that modern economic research focuses on. A further key objective is to teach students how they can use empirical methods to systematically think about the relationships between microeconomic and aggregate variables. Extra Interim test results cannot be taken to resit and thus max grade is out of 80% if only taking resit.

Module 1; (Dr Dana Sisak): "Theoretical Microeconomics" 
  • 20% Assignment (Homework) + 80% Essay
  • Resit: 80% Essay with assignment grade taken forward for remaining 20% (and is compulsory)
Module 2; (Dr Agnieszka Markiewicz):  "Macroeconomics: Theory and Practice"
  • 20% Assignment (Homework) + 80% Written Exam (Open Questions + MCQs)
  • Resit: 80% Written Exam with assignment grade taken forward for remaining 20%
Module 3; (Prof Olivier Marie): "Applied Micro-Econometrics Methods"
  • 20% Assignment (Homework) + 80% Essay 
  • Resit: 80% Essay with assignment grade taken forward for remaining 20% (and is compulsory)

course_title: Economic and Monetary Union and the European System of Financial Supervision
lecturers: ['dr. M Markakis, MJur DPhil (Ox)', 'prof.dr. F Amtenbrink']
text:
Inhoud The global financial and economic crisis and the subsequent European sovereign debt and financial crisis have broad the importance of the regulation of economic and monetary integration, as well as the supervision of financial markets in the European internal market to the forefront. The complexity of institutional and substantive rules governing these areas of European Union law, as well as the (political) economic arguments that often dominate the legal (policy) debate may explain why in the past these areas of law have received considerably less attention from lawyers and in law school curricular than other areas of European Union law. However, due to the proliferation of rules in recent years and the likelihood of further regulation, there is a growing demand for specialized knowledge among national, European and international (government) organizations, multinational law firms and consultancy firms.

The course first of all addresses the principles and rules governing the European economic and monetary union (EMU). Here the focus comes to rest on the general characteristics of EMU and its shortcomings (namely asymmetric integration), the economic and legal objectives and principles underlying economic policy coordination, the different Union and extra-Union instruments that define the preventive and corrective arms of the Stability and Growth Pact and the macroeconomic imbalances procedure (namely Six Pack, Two Pack, Fiscal Compact), the conditions for granting financial assistance to Member States (namely Articles 122(1), 125 TFEU & ESM Treaty), as well as the institutional position and tasks of the European System of Central Banks and the European Central Bank.     

The course moreover concentrates on the principles and rules governing the European System of Financial Supervision and the so-called European Banking Union. Here the focus lies on the overall supervisory architecture (namely the role of the three European supervisory authorities & the ECB’s Supervisory Board), an overview of the main features of the Single Supervisory Mechanism (namely based on Regulations (EU) No 1024/2013 and No 1022/2013), as well as the main features of the Single Resolution Mechanism (Regulation (EU) No 806/2014) and of the Single Resolution Fund.    

Throughout the course particular attention will be paid to (1) explaining the (political) economic rationale for institutional arrangements and (2) highlighting the close link between economic and monetary integration, but also between EMU and the regulation and supervision of financial markets in the EU that stress the need for an integrated approach to the study of these fields of law. With regard to (1) the course builds on the knowledge acquired namely in block 1 (Research & Writing Skills) and block 3 (Foundations of European Economic Integration) of the master.
  Leerdoelen As a result of this course, a student should be able to independently:
  • describe, analyse and assess the legal framework relevant to EMU and European System of Financial Supervision, and its systemic and the methodological factors thereof (learning objective 1, 4, 8)
  • independently analyse and assess the economic and political economy rationale underlying the legal framework relevant to EMU and European System of Financial Supervision (learning objective 3, 5, 8)
  • independently develop, conduct and account for academic research, and, based on this, provide a well-reasoned opinion of his/her own, as well as communicate, in writing as well as orally, scientifically justified research and legal advice, to legal specialists and to non-legal specialist audiences (learning objective 9, 11)

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. AM Nadolska-den Ouden', 'dr. L Rosendahl Huber', 'F Madertoner, MA', 'M Lissenberg - van der Pennen', 'prof.dr. PGJ Roosenboom', 'prof.dr. WB Wagner']
text:
Inhoud This course focuses on two separate, yet related aspects of the economy by introducing both the micro- as well as the macro-economic viewpoint.
 
The Micro-economics part of the course examines three interrelated questions:
  1. how individuals and firms make choices,
  2. in what way these choices interact in different markets and
  3. how businesses and managers adjust their decision making process to the various characteristics of the markets in which they are active.
This first part of the course focuses on developing a sound understanding of the basic principles of consumer choice and the efficient use of inputs by firms. We then bring consumers and firms to the market place. Here we study how different market structures (perfect competition, monopoly, oligopoly, monopolistic competition) affect pricing and the allocation of resources. A strong emphasis is placed on the applicability of theories, principles and concepts to actual situations and concrete management problem. The skills developed during the course enable the students to (1) understand concrete situations and (2) to have an impact on these situations.
 
The second part of the course is about macro-economics, or the general environment in which firms are active. In macroeconomics the focus is on nations. Together these nations form the global economy. This introductory course aims to familiarize students with the most important concepts and models from (international) macroeconomics. Important macroeconomic topics will be discussed such as macroeconomic policies, key macroeconomic variables and their interrelationships, globalization, and regional integration agreements. We will also relate to relevant topics in today’s business climate. For example, topics include changing demands due to European integration, rise of emerging markets, the recent financial crisis, and climate change. It also can be beneficial as you write your Strategic Business Plan as it allows you to consider the broader environment in which firms formulate and implement their strategies.
 
Leerdoelen
  • To understand consumer and producer behavior and its impact on markets;
  • To grasp basic economic theories and principles and their impact on business strategies and government policies;
  • To develop an understanding of the basic market structures and what they imply for a strategy of a company;
  • To apply the tools of microeconomics to solve business as well some economic problems;
  • To name important macroeconomic variables and explain their interrelations;
  • To explain how governments and central banks can influence the economy;
  • To interpret important international developments and develop a critical stance towards the current macroeconomic environment we live in;
  • To describe how the macroeconomic context of firms are characterized and explain how (international) firms affect each other.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. L Rosendahl Huber', 'F Madertoner, MA', 'F Mazzola, MSc', 'prof.dr. WB Wagner']
text:
Inhoud The course examines three interrelated questions:

1) How do firms (and individuals) make optimal choices?
2) In what way do these choices interact through markets?
3) How do businesses and managers adjust their decision making process to the characteristics of the markets in which they operate?

The first part of the course focuses on developing a sound understanding of the basic principles of consumer choice and the efficient use of inputs by firms. The second part of the course brings consumers and firms to the market place. Here we study how different market structures (perfect competition, monopoly, oligopoly, monopolistic competition) affect pricing and the allocation of resources. The final part of the course studies how various imperfections (such as asymmetric information and/or non-cooperative behaviour) affect outcomes.

A strong emphasis is placed on the applicability of theories, principles and concepts to actual situations
and concrete management problems. The skills developed during the course enable the students to (1) understand concrete situations and (2) to have an impact on these situations.
 
Leerdoelen
Learning goals

- To understand producer (and consumer) behavior and its impact on markets
- To grasp basic economic theories and principles and their impact on business strategies
- To develop an understanding of the basic market structures and what they imply for a company’s strategic behaviour
- To apply the tools of economics to solve business as well some economic problems

Inhoud Almost all socio-economic characteristics (e.g., educational attainment, occupation, and income) have been shown to be moderately heritable. This makes it possible to identify specific genes that are related to socio-economic differences among individuals and to investigate how these genes interact with environmental factors. For example, which genetic factors contribute to educational attainment and do specific family environments moderate the genetic susceptibility to perform well in school? In this course, students are introduced to key concepts and state-of-the-art computer tools in genetics. The goal of this course is to make students familiar with the consequences for economics developments in genetics may have, and to reflect on the ethical aspects of these consequences. This course covers topics such as the nature vs. nurture debate, estimation and interpretation of heritability, gene discovery, and genetic prediction. Moreover, the students become familiar with big data analysis by performing basic genetic analyses using specialized statistical software. Leerdoelen In this course, students are introduced to key concepts and state-of-the-art computer tools in genetics. The goal of this course is to make students familiar with the consequences for economics developments in genetics may have, and to reflect on the ethical aspects of these consequences.

  Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar - Fully online course.
- Stronger integration (video) lectures, tutorials and assignments. Extra Background knowledge about genetics is not needed to follow this course, but basic knowledge about statistics (e.g., regression analysis) will be assumed.

course_title: Economics and Financing of Health Care Systems
college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['D Cattel', 'dr. F Eijkenaar', 'dr. RC van Kleef', 'prof.dr. FT Schut', 'prof.dr. M Varkevisser', 'prof.dr. WPMM van de Ven']
text:
Inhoud Historical developments, political choices, and societal structures strongly influence the organization of health care systems across countries. The main purpose of this course is to provide an introduction to various conceptual frameworks that help you to understand and use economic principles applied to health care systems. The course will deal with theory of supply and demand in health care, the crucial role of (asymmetry in) information, provider payment incentives, private and social health insurance, theory and practice of managed compe­tition, organization and financing of long-term care, and the public/private mix in the financing and provision of care. The course looks at how health care systems, in the Netherlands as well as in other developed countries, deal with important policy issues like competition and regulation, solidarity, and the role of voluntary supplementary health insurance.

The course consists of:
  • 15 video lectures with formative assignments
  • Live Q&A-meetings corresponding to video lectures
  • 2 peer-reviewed group assignments

 
  Leerdoelen By the end of this course students are able to:
  • explain and analyze the economic complexities of health care (systems) that are relevant for health policy;
  • classify different types of healthcare systems, describe and analyze how these systems function in terms of the organization and financing of health care, and infer the implications thereof for efficiency and equity in health care;
  • assess the comparative performance of health care systems and to use such an analysis to infer implications for health policy.

course_title: Economics and Management of Network Businesses and Marketing
text:
Inhoud
Instructors: 
prof. dr. E.T. Verhoef, dr. A.J.H. Pels, dr. T. de Graaff, dr. M.D. König (VU)
 
Short subject description:
This course addresses the analysis and management of network businesses and markets from the perspective of firms and society.
 
Course content:
The course centers around the theme of networks in business and economics. We will discuss physical networks, such as those in transport, and non-physical networks, including internet-based platforms. We will address, from the business perspective as well as the societal viewpoint, phenomena such as network design, market power, congestion, economies of density, market failure, alliances, spill-overs, equilibrium versus optimum, dynamics, nodes, gravity and agglomeration. We will discuss theory and empirics, presenting methodologies to study and analyze network (behavior) from both perspectives.
Leerdoelen After the course students are able to apply state-of-the-art methods from business and economic sciences to analyze network businesses and marketsfrom the theoretical and empirical perspective. This includes having acquired fundamental insights into how the specific phenomena that characterize networks, and that differentiate these from non-network businesses and markets, affect the desirability of outcomes from the private and public perspective; which policies and strategies may be employed to optimize outcomes; and which theoretical and empirical techniques to use to answer these questions.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud The course illustrates the contribution of cultural economics to the analysis of cultural heritage to guarantee it a sustainable future. Students will learn the main topics characterizing the cultural-economic perspective on cultural heritage. The analysis will consider the issues related to cultural heritage conservation and enhancement emphasizing the role it can have for a sustainable economic, cultural and social development. The course will refer to the main documents issued by UNESCO and the EU related to the role of cultural heritage for society and will use the cultural economic concepts to reflect on the issues at stakes, the values involved and possible interventions to guarantee a sustainable conservation and enhancement of cultural heritage. The main issues considered are:
  • The evolution of the concept of cultural heritage: tangible, intangible.
  • Economic concepts applied to cultural heritage.
  • The values of cultural heritage, evaluation methods and their limits.
  • Cultural heritage policies: actors and tools.
  • Conventions and other protection instruments.
  • The World Heritage List.
  • Cultural heritage and tourism.
  • Conservation and adaptive re-use of cultural heritage.
  • Cultural heritage and sustainability.
  • Cultural heritage and development.
 
Note:  The maximum number of participants is 30. Leerdoelen After completing the course, students should have a wide-ranging knowledge and critical understanding of the cultural economic perspective on cultural heritage. They will be aware of the relevance of economic concepts and management issues related to cultural heritage and sites as well as of the main policy dilemmas arising in this field. The course gives specific attention to the connection between theory and practice referring to several case studies.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud The course will introduce the main concepts related to tourism in general: its development, its economic impact, the main definitions and concepts (tourist, visitor, excursionist, carrying capacity of a destination), and the trends characterizing the sector and modifying it. The course will then focus on cultural tourism: a specific branch of tourism that is expanding though it is still difficult to identify and define. The economic approach will highlight the characteristics of the sector, its potential for the economic development of regions but also the risks it can entail (for example in terms of congestion and wear and tear of heritage sites). The course will provide a critical review of the virtuous-vicious relationship between tourism and culture and will focus on the possible strategies that can be applied to avoid or, at least, reduce the risks in order to attain sustainable cultural tourism development.
Every week the lecturer will introduce a theme illustrating the main theoretical notions and some examples. The week after a group of students will lead the class making a presentation that provides a thorough analysis of the same topic using a case study. Leerdoelen The aim of this course is to teach students the main concepts from the economics of tourism, considering the evolution and development of the sector through time, focusing in particularly on the niche of cultural tourism. Based on a critical engagement with the fundamental theories and empirical literature, students are challenged to identify and comment the effects, opportunities and challenges related to cultural tourism. Students will improve their presentation and writing skills by doing presentations in class and writing a final essay.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. O Slivko', 'EJ Haag, MSc', 'prof.dr. RA Zuidwijk']
text:
Inhoud

Contents, course description

Over the last decades, information systems, digital communication technologies and businesses structured as online platforms have rapidly emerged, fundamentally changing the relations among economic actors, e.g., businesses, customers and governments. The aim of this course is to introduce essential concepts from the digital economy literature (e.g., network effects, switching costs, platforms, pricing, online auctions) and supply chain literature (e.g., lead times, inventories, operations planning, omnichannel) and examine which economic forces govern digital businesses and what distinguishes it from the traditional business relations and operations. For example, digital technologies have led to a rapid decline in the cost of storage, computation and transmission of data, which has impacted the way how products are produced, how they travel through supply networks to their intended consumers and how they are consumed. 

Questions that will be addressed in this course include: What characterizes the production of digital goods and what impact does this have on how digital goods are sold on markets? Why are many digital markets dominated by powerful platforms, such as Google and Facebook, and what makes these platform companies different from traditional companies? What are important strategies for digital platforms to compete in markets and how should platforms be regulated by public policymakers? How non-platform companies can adapt to the markets where platforms play a significant role? How have digital technologies impacted the relations within supply chains, and the economic productivity and growth at the macro-economic level? What is the likely future impact of new digital technologies such as artificial intelligence on the future economy and on individuals?

We will particularly address how digitization disrupted supply chains management in organizations in this course. The new operating model for purchasing and supply management, known as Procurement 4.0 will be thoroughly addressed as well as the new role of purchaser in the organization. Finally, we will take a closer look at the digital platforms in port logistics.

Leerdoelen Learning Objectives

In this course, students will learn the main concepts from digital economy, information systems and supply chain literature and how to apply them for the analysis of firms’ digital strategies. In particular, students will:

•    Understand the role of digital transformation in shaping performance of firms and industries
•    Understand the main principles behind the platform economy (e.g. multi-sided platform pricing, competitive strategies, challenges, governance)
•    Use the main concepts from digital economy (network effects, switching costs, bundling) to rigorously study the impact of digital transformation on businesses
•    Learn how digitization transforms supply chains management in organizations, and how the role of purchaser evolves (Procurement 4.0)

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud The seminar looks at the fashion industry as one of the creative industries. It aims to facilitate students’ knowledge and understanding of how the industry works. The seminar will confront students with the most recent theories linked to the characteristics, the demand, the supply and intermediaries for fashion products as well the sustainability issues in the fashion industry. We emphasize an analytical approach in understanding the dynamic development of the fashion industry. In doing so, we will discuss relevant literature and specific cases through student presentations, class discussion and field trips. Students will focus on one fashion product/firm/market and carry out research based on scholarly literature, resulting in an individual essay and in a group poster presentation.
 
Note:
 
The maximum number of students is 30.
  • Priority is given to bachelor students from Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication (7 students from BA Geschiedenis or IBHistory, 7 students from BA ACW or IBACS, 7 students from IBCoM, 3 exchange students, 9 students from other faculties or universities).
  • It is not allowed to take this course as an individual course; students are required to take the entire Minor Fashion Industry of 15 ECTs. Minor students should obtain a pass mark for each of the three course; it is not possible to compensate for a score below the pass mark.
  • Admission requirements: Proficiency in spoken and written English is essential [VWO-final examination grade: 7 or higher / TOEFL-test: minimum score 580 (paper-based), 237 (computer- based) or 92 (internet-based) / IELTS-test: minimum of 7(overall band)]
Leerdoelen The seminar aims to facilitate students’ knowledge and understanding of how the fashion industry works. The main objective is to gain insight into the cultural economic dimensions of the fashion industry. We emphasize an analytical approach in understanding the dynamic development of the fashion industry. In doing so, we will discuss relevant literature and specific cases through student presentation, class discussion and field trips.

course_title: Economics of Fashion, Design and Architecture
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud In academia, business environment and policy-making circles the past decade has given rise to a growing acknowledgment of the design industries as paradigmatic sectors of post-industrial economies, “cognitive-cultural” capitalism, or even better “neo-industrial” economies, in which production increasingly relies on symbolic and aesthetic considerations as well as on local specificities. The seminar provides a forum for discussion of the week's topic, reading material, case studies and fieldtrips. Students are expected to read and discuss the literature, summarize it for discussion in class and apply it to specific cases. A critical approach is encouraged. Topics covered in the course, among others: characteristics of design products; demand for design products; economic and spatial organization of design industries; labour market for designers; intermediaries, temporary clusters and global pipelines; sustainability, circular economy and design industries. Students will focus on design, fashion or architecture industries and carry out research based on scholarly literature, resulting in an individual essay and in a group poster presentation. This course builds further upon the courses in Term 1 and 2, and it is connected to topics that students will encounter in their master thesis.
 
Note
  • The maximum number of participants is 25.
  • It is not allowed to follow the seminar “Economics of Fashion, Design and Architecture” together with the seminar “Heritage and Fashion”
Leerdoelen The seminar wishes to facilitate students’ knowledge and understanding of the economic and spatial characteristics of the design industries - in particular fashion, design and architecture. We emphasize an analytical approach in understanding the dynamic development of the design industries. Special attention is dedicated the role design industries play in supporting the transition to the circular economy. In doing so, we will discuss relevant literature and specific cases through student presentation, class discussion and field trips.

Inhoud This course provides essential insights for anyone interested in the organization of firm production which becomes increasingly complex in a globalizing world. The course first looks at several theories to explain how firms govern production. In particular, it analyses how moral hazard in production, transaction cost economics and hold-up problems affect the decision of firms to vertically integrate along the production chain. In the last part of the course the relevance and effects of the broader institutional environment (rule of law, corruption, etc.) on the economic performance is discussed. Throughout the course the theoretical insights are supported by empirical applications. Note that a basic knowledge of mathematics (e.g. derivatives, optimization) and econometrics is needed to succeed in this course.
  Leerdoelen
  • Describe the importance of moral hazard, transaction costs, hold-up problems and knowledge dissipation for the governance of production chains, building on theoretical arguments and empirical evidence.
  • Clarify competition policy issues related to vertical integration and long term contracts using insights from the literature on the governance of production chains.
  • Critically analyse a firm’s governance strategy based on data collection and sound theoretical arguments.
  • Interpret empirical evidence in the academic literature on firm governance and vertical integration.
  • Solve economic models analysing firm governance issues and vertical integration.

course_title: Economics of Health and Health Care
college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['dr. M Tenand', 'dr. PLH Bakx', 'J Stöckel, MSc', 'JAM Bom', 'M Bar', 'MS Perry-Duxbury, MSc', 'prof.dr. EKA Van Doorslaer']
text:
Inhoud This course builds on Economics and Financing of Health Care, in which the principles of health economics and health care financing are explained. This course uses the tools and concepts discussed in that course to analyse and compare health and health care at the macro or system level. The performance of health care systems may be evaluated by analysing whether the outcomes are efficient and equitable. Therefore, this course consists of three parts.

The first part is about the relationships between health, health care and income. Understanding these relationships is an important goal in its own right, but also provides some of the building blocks that are necessary for the definition and measurement of equity (part 2) and efficiency (part 3). In each of the three parts, the main focus is on applying the analytical framework – and evaluating how other researchers’ applied it – to compare the performance of developed and less developed countries and discuss the aspects of health care systems and their performance in a structured manner. Leerdoelen After taking this course, students are able to:
  • Explain why equity and efficiency are important health system performance indicators
  • Apply the tools that are used to measure equity and efficiency of health systems
  • Judge whether the measures of equity and efficiency are used in a valid and meaningful way in international comparative analyses of health care system functioning
  • Comment on scientific articles on health system performance from top journals in the field of health economics

Inhoud Today both developed and developing countries are searching for ways to foster economic growth. Innovation is considered to be a major force for economic growth. The objective of this course is to provide students with a comprehensive and advanced understanding of what innovation is, how innovation is organised and diffused, how internal and external (industry) factors impact on innovation, and what the role is of different actors involved in innovation such as different types of firms (start-ups, small firms and large firms) banks and venture capitalists. Leerdoelen
  • Students are able to reproduce and interpret main concepts and characteristics of innovation; economic incentives for innovation; the organization and diffusion of innovation; the economic consequences of innovation; and the economic rationale of public policies for fostering innovation.
  • Students apply concepts, theories and paradigms of innovation to analyze complex and current issues of a (business) economics nature such as industry developments and differences, the role of entrepreneurs in fostering innovation and standards races.
  • Students analyze developments related to innovation (such as the emergence of industrial clusters and the increased globalization of specialized production) from several perspectives and then explain these developments based on the tension between those different perspectives.
  • Students present the results of an industry or company analysis.

Inhoud Game theory is the study of strategic interaction. It is a structured approach to analysing situations in which there is room for cooperation and conflict. Such situations are abundant in markets, organisations, and beyond. This course provides an introduction to the use of game theory in a variety of contexts, in particular, bargaining and negotiation, contracting, and auctions. The emphasis of the course is on developing skills to approach problems in a structured and systematic manner. The course aims to promote a careful approach to strategic situations, without undue emphasis on technicalities. The reading material assigned for this course is illustrative of the sort of game-theoretic reasoning this course seeks to promote. Leerdoelen
  • To understand the basic tools of game theory
  • To develop skills for systematic, game theoretic, reasoning in decision making
  • To apply game theoretic reasoning to bargaining and negotiation
  • To understand how the design of contracts affects incentives
  • To understand the mechanics of various types of auctions

Inhoud This course analyzes markets and organizations by studying seminal and contemporary papers in theory and empirics in this field. The course analyzes papers on the following topics in detail:

1. Markets of Goods and Services 2. Labor Markets
3. Financial Markets
4. Incentives in Organizations
5. Decision Making in Organizations
6. Leadership in Organisations

Imperfect markets and asymmetric information play a key role in the research field of markets and organizations. During this course we analyze and discuss why firms set different prices for the same goods during sales. Who monitors a CEO and does it have any effect? Why are some decisions in firms delegated and others not? How do organizations incentivize employees when effort is unobservable? How do banks ensure loans are paid back by organizations? How do consumers choose between different products?

This course deepens some of the topics from previous micro economics and organizational courses from the Bachelor and gives a preview of the topics discussed in the Economics of Markets and Organizations Master.

  Leerdoelen The goal of the course is to gain knowledge on the application of game theory models within a market and organization context and link this knowledge to empirical papers on the same topic.

Learning goals

* Student is able to understand theory and empirical papers on the discussed topics
* Student is able to analyze models on the discussed topics using game theory
* Student is able to argument the advantages and disadvantages of the assumptions and results in the discussed papers
* Student is able to explain and discuss the empirical strategy used in the discussed papers to analyze a research question
* Student is able to identify and explain which possible sources of endogeneity might hamper causality on the discussed topics Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The goal of the course is to gain knowledge on the application of game theory models within the fields of industrial organization and organizational economics and link this knowledge to empirical papers on the same topic.
In contrast to previous year, the emphasis is not on contract theory or full-fledged game theoretic knowledge.
The course has a clear applied view on the theory, shows the many interesting topics in these fields, and links the theoretical knowledge to empirical papers.

Inhoud Traditionally, the firm is treated as a structure where inputs are transformed into output. Yet, 'the firm' is not a decision-making unit. Rather, production is shaped by the decisions of people within the organisation. People involved in an organisation (or, more generally, in any transaction) will have different objectives, which may hamper cooperation.
The issues we will discuss include the effects and limitations of various instruments that may improve efficiency, such as property rights, contracts, financial and non-financial incentives, and organisational structure. Throughout, we take a microeconomic perspective.

  Leerdoelen
  • Understand and apply important concepts, tools, and theories regarding the behaviour of people in organisations.
  • Recognise situations where there may be conflicts of interest between people, analyse the effects of the conflict of interest, and assess how interests could be (better) aligned.
  • Independently recognise how institutional and organisational features have developed to cope with conflicting interests between people.
  • Critically assess scientific literature in the field of Organisational Economics.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The first assignment is shortened, to allow for more time to settle in Rotterdam. Extra In the re-examination,  the original grades for the assignments will count. It is not possible to redo the assignments.

Inhoud The course integrates insights from industrial organisation and strategy research while building upon a strong theoretical and empirical foundation.

1. First, the course discusses the concept of real options as a tool to make investment decisions under uncertainty.
2. The second part examines investments in research and development and advertising.
3. The last part analyzes strategies for particular types of goods and industries.

The topics are of interest to anyone with both a theoretical and a professional interest in strategic decision making at the firm level. As the course will use basic micro-theory, some knowledge in this field (monopoly, oligopoly, Stackelberg, perfect competition) and the associated mathematics (e.g., basic rules of differentiation such as the product rule and the chain rule) and statistics (probability theory) is required. Leerdoelen
  • Students will understand under which circumstances real options theory helps to make better managerial decisions.
  • Students will understand how strategic decision variables of firms interact.
  • Students will understand how and when irreversible investments in research and development and advertising lead to a sustainable competitive advantage.
  • Students will understand how sector and product characteristics have an impact on managerial decision making.
Extra Not recommended for students of the Master in Financial Economics.

Inhoud

The dramatic changes of the last century on the global scale in social, technological and environmental spheres put sustainability at the top of the international political agenda. The objective of this course is to provide students with an introduction to various approaches to the intersection of economics and sustainability. They will be motivated to think theoretically and practically on how to redesign current economic structures focusing on production, distribution and consumption to create a more sustainable world in the 21st century. The theoretical conceptualization and operationalization of sustainability in Economics is a necessity to understand current changes in the global scale. The linear economic structures which resource waste and pollution. Institutions, policies and regulations, and continuous technological innovations play a vital role in realizing these new economic models. Green energy systems, which are introduced as a remedy for the problems of climate change, exemplify such technological innovations. Demographic dynamics is another dimension next to ecological concerns that should be addressed by coordinated actions at the international level for a sustainable future.

Inhoud This course provides a thorough understanding of a number of key topics within the economics of taxation. The course is largely positive in its scope but also provides a few normative (i.e., prescriptive) insights. 
 
The course addresses the following questions and more: Under which conditions is the laissez-faire market equilibrium efficient? How does taxation interfere with efficiency? Who carries the burden of taxation? How does this depend on individual rationality assumptions? How may income taxes help improve the distribution of resources? How does the optimal income tax differ from the one chosen by democratically elected officials? How might taxation help improve efficiency when dealing with externalities? What about internalities? What determines individuals’ decisions to evade taxes? And to what extent do governments compete for internationally mobile tax bases? 
 
The goal is to understand both the traditional theory on each topic, as well as the state-of-the-art insights generated by current academic research. As such, the required literature for many of the topics consists of recent scholarly papers as well as textbook chapters.
Leerdoelen
  • To gain knowledge on the principles of public finance.
  • To understand how changes in taxes affect decisions to work, consume, and engage in tax evasion.
  • To understand how taxes affect market outcomes, efficiency, and the distribution of resources.
  • To understand which policies are best suited to tackle problems generated by externalities, internalities, and tax evasion.
  • To understand how relaxing rationality assumptions affect the conventional wisdom on the economics of taxation.
  • To link insights from public finance to actual policy debates.
  • To critically read and understand academic journal articles at the scientific frontier of the economics of taxation.
  • To apply basic concepts from microeconomics and mathematics to the study of public economics.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar One additional Lecture is added on the optimal linear income tax in the presence of income inequality, as well as on voting over a linear income tax.
The part on fiscal federalism is dropped and replaced by a part on tax havens and corporate tax avoidance.

lecturers: ['dr. M Hendriks', 'E Pleeging, MA', 'I Wijngaards, MSc', 'prof.dr. MJ Burger', 'prof.dr. NJA van Exel']
text:
Inhoud This interdisciplinary course connects economics and other social sciences with its ultimate purpose: understanding and increasing people’s well-being. The central question in this minor is how to improve people’s well-being in various contexts (in personal life, at work, at the macro level). This course provides future economists, policy-makers, business leaders, human resources specialists, psychologists, and related professions with fundamental expertise in a world where human well-being is increasingly relevant in organizational and public policies.

A good quality of life is not only a fundamental goal of people, happy and healthy individuals are proven pivotal for building successful organizations and societies. 
In this course, we explore how economic behavior and phenomena relate to well-being at both the individual level (e.g. labor market choices, consumption behavior), the organizational level (e.g. well-being at work), and the macro-level (e.g. economic prosperity and the health care system). 
Core questions that will be covered in this minor include: What makes whom happy? Do people make optimal choices to achieve their well-being goals? If not, how can people be supported in optimizing their well-being? How to create thriving organizations and societies with flourishing employees and citizens? And, do happier and healthier citizens and employees stimulate better societal outcomes and company profits? 
To answer these and other questions, the course material features contemporary scientific insights (academic articles and videos) from various disciplines, including applied economics (happiness economics, health economics, and behavioral economics), business economics, psychology (positive and organizational psychology), and sociology. You will also conduct empirical analyses to explore the topic of well-being. Both objective and subjective measures of well-being will be discussed, with a focus on subjective well-being (happiness) and health.
The graded assessments are mostly individual assignments that focus on developing ideas and interventions on (how to improve) well-being and critically reflecting on existing ideas about well-being. This minor helps you to develop some core skills, including the ability to work with and critically reflect on scientific literature, conduct data analysis, and develop interventions. The course material is also relevant on a personal level, as personal well-being is important in its own right and instrumental in reaching other goals in life such as a successful career.
The course material is tailored to a broad audience and we encourage both students with an economic and non-economic background to participate in this minor.

  Leerdoelen After completing this course, the student will be able to …
1. evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of various conceptualizations and measures of well-being using appropriate arguments.
2. illustrate how people’s well-being influences their behaviour and achievements by applying appropriate empirical evidence and theories.
3. critically reflect on lay beliefs, contemporary theories, and empirical analyses on well-being using appropriate arguments. 
4. develop strategies and policies that improve well-being by applying appropriate empirical evidence and theories.
5. conduct an empirical study on people’s well-being using basic statistical techniques in Stata. 

  Extra Method of examination:

Module 1 “Well-being: An introduction”
 Take-Home Exam (four open questions) 
 
Module 2 “Empirical analyses of Well-being”
 Individual assignment. In this assignment, students conduct empirical analyses on well-being related research questions and describe their findings in a research report. Students can select their topic of interest from a list of three topics. 

Module 3 “Work and Well-being”
 Pitch (oral presentation). In this assignment, students work on a business case in which they address a real-world issue faced by a company related to employee well-being. Students present an intervention and propose a method to test the effectiveness of the intervention.

Module 4 “Health and Well-being”
 Written Exam (multiple choice and open questions)

Module 5 “Society and Well-being”
 Individual Assignment (students write an essay about a well-being related societal issues).

The final grade of the minor is the weighted average of the four or five modules. An average grade of 5.5 is sufficient to pass the minor. 100% of the course grade is based on individual assessments.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud
<html>
<head>
	<title></title>
	<style type="text/css">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
	</style>
</head>
<body>Analyses of the production, distribution, presentation and consumption of performing arts in different countries and in different economic and social systems are discussed. Attention will be paid to functions of the performing arts, programming, audience development, public and private financing, pricing theory, economic geography, marketing concepts, collaboration and economics and innovation in the popular music industry. Students will be trained in analyzing the establishment of cultural institutions in the performing arts. They will be encouraged to analyze and compare the economic aspects of performing arts in different countries. During the course two performing arts organizations will be visited. During guest lectures, students will get first hand experiences from specialists in the sector.</body>
</html>

Leerdoelen
<html>
<head>
<meta http-equiv="content-type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8" /><style type="text/css">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>The aim of the seminar is to acquire comprehension of specific objectives of the performing arts from an economic and a cultural point of view. Students learn to understand the different ways of organizing, financing and developing the production and presentation of the performing arts such as popular music, drama, classical music and so on in different countries.</body>
</html>

Inhoud European countries are noted for the extent of their welfare systems. Education and health care are predominantly publicly funded. Unemployment and disability insurance, as well as income support for the poor, tend to be more generous than on other continents. States are deeply involved in the regulation and financing of pensions. The continued viability of the European social model is hotly debated across the continent. Some question the consistency of generous welfare provisions with maintaining competitiveness in increasingly globalized markets. Others retort that insurance eases transitions through the business cycle and good quality public education raises productivity. Ageing populations strain public pension and health care systems but public financing may help constrain rising health care costs. The contribution of welfare provisions to immigration into and within Europe is highly contested. This course uses economics to cast light on these issues. It separates equity from efficiency goals and analyses the extent to which state involvement in the finance and provision of pensions, insurance, health care and education is justified with respect to economic efficiency. Moving beyond the broad issue of whether the state should be involved in these sectors, the course considers how social policies should be designed to best achieve specific equity and efficiency objectives. After this course you will be:
i) more critical of debates about welfare policies in Europe;
ii) able to distinguish equity from efficiency motivations for social policies;
iii) able analyse the design of welfare policies;
iv) able to assess the validity of empirical analyses of welfare issues;
v) practised in developing a logical, coherent argument. Leerdoelen
  • Students are able to distinguish equity from efficiency motivations for social policies.
  • Students are able to analyse the design of welfare policies.
  • Students are able to assess the validity of empirical analyses of welfare issues.
  • Students become more critical of debates about welfare policies in Europe
  • Students are practiced in developing a logical, coherent argument.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The course has been redesigned following the re-structuring of the bachelor program. Changes take into account that students have followed Applied Microeconomics and the set of skills learned throughout the program. 
In particular, students are now expected to write a policy report in groups, and the course is structure around several individual and group assignments designed to guide the students to achieve this goal. 
Students can also choose among two different broad topics, which contributes to the plans for additional differentiation within courses.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud In deze module wordt ervan uitgegaan dat bestuurskunde- en sociologiestudenten een brede economische basis moeten krijgen omdat ze op verschillende wijze in aanraking kunnen komen met het vakgebied. Bestuurskundigen en sociologen krijgen voortdurend op verschillende plekken, bij departementen, gemeenten en organisaties, te maken met ontwikkelingen, projecten dan wel beleid, waarbij economische principes en instrumentarium toegepast worden om maatschappelijke processen te beïnvloeden. Daarbij komen vier aspecten aan bod:
  1. Micro-economisch gedachtengoed: consumentengedrag, producentengedrag, markt(werking), vraagsturing, collectieve goederen (plus externe effecten) en welvaartsverdelingsvraagstukken.
  2. Macro-economisch gedachtengoed: Uitgaande van vraag- dan wel aanbodgericht beleid, gericht op allocatie, stabilisatie en verdeling, aandacht voor vormgeving en doeltreffendheid van economische politiek, monetair beleid, sociale zekerheid, verdelingsvraagstukken en internationale economische betrekkingen.
  3. Begroting: Inkomsten en uitgaven, normen, besluitvormingsprocessen.
  4. De betekenis van instituties, hun bijdrage aan economische ontwikkeling en economische politiek, en de samenhang tussen hun vormgeving en de effectiviteit van beleid.
 Leerdoelen De module 'Economie: productie, verdeling, en de rol van de overhead' heeft tot doel studenten vertrouwd te maken met het economisch begrippenapparaat en deze kunnen toepassen op actuele maatschappelijke en beleidsmatige vraagstukken Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. AM Nadolska-den Ouden', 'dr. L Rosendahl Huber', 'F Madertoner, MA', 'M Lissenberg - van der Pennen', 'prof.dr. PGJ Roosenboom', 'prof.dr. WB Wagner']

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. CT Witte', 'dr. L Rosendahl Huber', 'F Madertoner, MA']
text:
Inhoud Het vak Economie richt zich met name op micro economische aspecten.
 
In het vak gaan we nader in op drie samenhangende vraagstukken:
  1. Hoe individuen en bedrijven keuzes maken,
  2. Op welke wijze deze keuzes verschillende markten beïnvloeden
  3. Hoe bedrijven en managers hun besluitvorming aanpassen aan de verschillende kenmerken van de markten waarbinnen zij actief zijn.
Het vak richt zich op het goed begrijpen van de basisprincipes van consumentenkeuzes en het efficiënt gebruik van input door bedrijven. We brengen daarna consumenten en bedrijven bijeen op de markt, waarbij we nader bekijken hoe de verschillende marktstructuren (perfecte concurrentie, monopolie, oligopolie, monopolistische concurrentie) effect hebben op prijsstelling en de verdeling van resources. De nadruk ligt daarbij op de toepasbaarheid van theorieën, principes en concepten rond reële situaties en concrete maatschappelijke problemen. De vaardigheden die gedurende het vak ontwikkeld worden stellen de student in staat om: (1) concrete situaties te begrijpen (2) deze concrete situaties te kunnen beïnvloeden.
  Leerdoelen Leerdoelen
Na afloop van deze cursus is de student in staat om:
  • De invloed van consumenten en producenten gedrag op de markt te herkennen
  • De verschillende economische basistheorieën en principes en hun invloed op bedrijfsstrategieën te benoemen
  • Basis marktstructuren met elkaar te vergelijken en uit te leggen wat die betekenen voor de strategie van een bedrijf
  • Economische kennis toe te passen bij het oplossen van bedrijfseconomische problemen.

lecturers: ['C van der Kooi', 'dr. JW Hengstmengel', 'prof.dr. PJJ van Geest']

text:
Inhoud In this course, we analyse the transition from a linear, oppositional, externalising, identity based discourse on ecology to a circular, inclusive discourse that is based on an ecophilosophical perspective that focuses on differences and relations. Connecting the domains of art, science and politics to philosophy, a threefold ecology (ECO3) is explored and fed back into the current debates on ecology. The broad perspective is the proposition that after the modern enlightenment of the mind 21st century schizoid man is up to a new, medial enlightenment that acknowledges the productive role of technology for the constitution of our self-consciousness. Leerdoelen The seminars are not obligatory.

​Lectures will be recorded.

Acquiring a limited but relevant overview on current philosophical debates on sustainability and ecology and being able to analyze and debate specific ecophilosophical problems concerning the relation between economy, ethics, politics and ecology. To learn to carefully read, understand and critically reflect on selected texts of a diversity of authors that problematize conventional concepts, disclosing new perspectives on ecological issues focused on the transition of philosophy to ecosophy, and being able to transpose these acquired insights to one’s own field of expertise.

Inhoud De Educatieve minor biedt je de mogelijkheid om kennis te maken met het leraarschap. De Educatieve minor bestaat uit een samenhangend pakket van 30 ECTS, bestaande uit 13 ECTS aan vakken en 17 ECTS praktijkstage op een middelbare school (voortgezet onderwijs) inclusief supervisie. De vakken zijn erop gericht om jou optimaal voor te bereiden op je stage, waarin jij voor de klas staat. Deze minor bevat dus een afgewogen combinatie van theoretische kennis en praktische vaardigheden en leert je bovendien de attitude die passend is voor het leraarschap. In combinatie met het bachelordiploma van je vakstudie levert de succesvolle afronding van de Educatieve minor een beperkte tweedegraads onderwijsbevoegdheid op (hiermee kun je jouw vak geven in de onderbouw van havo en vwo en het vmbo-t).

Aantal contacturen

De colleges voor deze minor voor bachelor studenten Economie en Bedrijfskunde vinden plaats in Rotterdam op vrijdag. Bij minder dan 10 deelnemers vindt het onderwijs voor alle vakken echter plaats in Leiden op maandag. Houd er rekening mee dat je deze hele collegedag (9.00-17.00 uur) beschikbaar bent voor onderwijsactiviteiten. De andere 4 dagen kan je besteden aan het praktijkdeel van de opleiding. Studenten zijn gemiddeld 3 dagen per week op hun stageschool.
 
De minor is 30 ECTS, wat zich vertaalt naar een studiebelasting van 840 uur.
