Inclusief Startweek (24 uur), hoor- en werkcolleges (82 uur) en stage (minimaal 120 klascontacturen, daarnaast evalueer je je lessen met je begeleider, neem je deel aan schoolactiviteiten en volg je activiteiten in het kader je van ontwikkeldoelen Praktijk) komt het aantal contacturen neer op 226 uur. De overige uren besteed je aan zelfstudie, opdrachten voor de opleiding, het voorbereiden van lessen, aanwezigheid bij schoolse activiteiten zoals een vergadering of ouderavond, et cetera. De ervaring leert dat je deze uren hard nodig hebt.

Module:
  • Leren en Instructie (3 ECTS)
  • Pedagogiek (5 ECTS)
  • Vakdidactiek (5 ECTS)
  • Praktijk (17 ECTS)
 
  Leerdoelen Na afronding van de educatieve minor kun jij:
  • Een goede samenwerking met en tussen leerlingen tot stand brengen.
  • Voor groepen leerlingen en individuen een veilige leeromgeving creëren.
  • Een krachtige leeromgeving inrichten waarin leerlingen zich op een goede manier leerinhouden van het vakgebied Economie eigen maken.
  • In groepen leerlingen en in andere contacten met leerlingen een overzichtelijk, ordelijk en taakgericht leef- en werkklimaat tot stand brengen.
  • Relevante informatie uitwisselen met collega’s in de school en uitkomsten daarvan benutten.
  • Eigen opvattingen over het leraarschap en de eigen bekwaamheden als leraar te expliciteren, kritisch te onderzoeken en verder te ontwikkelen op basis van theoretische inzichten en empirische gegevens.
  • Vakdidactisch ingrijpen in de leerstof met als doel de verlening van betekenis aan economische begrippen te vergroten.
Extra
  • Start 26 augustus 2020
  • Voor de beoordeling wordt bij elk studieonderdeel (uitgezonderd Leren en Instructie) gebruik gemaakt van rubrics. De rubrics zijn gebaseerd op de eindtermen van de minor. Voor elk van de vijf beroepsrollen (professional, regisseur, vakdidacticus, pedagoog en lid van de schoolorganisatie) waarvoor wordt opgeleid, is een rubric beschikbaar.  Het studieonderdeel Leren en Instructie wordt afgesloten met een tentamen.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud
Vanaf het moment dat we geboren zijn tot aan het eind van ons leven, blijft de mens nieuwe dingen leren. Soms maken we ons dingen vrijwel automatisch eigen en soms eist het een extreme inspanning. Veel van dit leren gebeurt in een onderwijssetting, die speciaal ingericht is om bepaalde kennis en vaardigheden bij te brengen. Maar hoe gaat dat leren nu precies in zijn werk? Zijn er verschillende vormen van leren en welke vorm is dan de beste? En hoe kun je in je onderwijs het leren stimuleren? Wanneer gaat dit leren fout? Welke leerproblemen kom je tegen? Waarom kunnen we soms dingen die we geleerd hebben in de ene context wel goed toepassen en in een andere context niet? Deze en nog andere vragen over leren staan centraal in dit blok. Studenten denken na over deze vragen aan de hand van problemen uit de praktijk van onderwijs en onderzoek.
 
Leerdoelen Op basis van theorieën over leren en ontwikkeling verwerven studenten inzicht in wat er gebeurt en verandert wanneer mensen leren. Studenten zullen vertrouwd raken met thema's zoals leren lezen, misconcepties, transfer, expertise, leermotivatie, leren met multimedia, toetsing en de achtergronden bij het probleemgestuurd onderwijs. Er wordt bij elk van de thema's ook aandacht besteed aan implicaties voor de inrichting van onderwijs. Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

course_title: Effectieve bestanddelen van psychologische behandelingen in het ziekenhuis
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud In de onderwijsgroepen wordt gewerkt met verschillende vignetten van somatische zieke patiënten (met of zonder psychische problemen). De hoorcolleges bieden elke week verbreding van het betreffende onderwerp. In de eerste week wordt aandacht besteed aan diagnostiek van psychische problemen bij somatisch zieke patiënten. Psychische problematiek kan het gevolg zijn van ziekte of het ziek zijn en het kan een complicerende factor zijn bij een somatische ziekte. Verder komt het verschil tussen stepped-care en matched-care aan bod. De voorwaarden voor beide worden besproken evenals de voor- en nadelen van deze twee methodieken.
De tweede week gaat over laagdrempelige en kortdurende behandelingen, zoals zelfhulp en e-mental health. Er zijn vele vormen van zelfhulp, zoals zelfhulpgroepen, zelfmanagementprogramma’s en bibliotherapie. Maar kan een behandeling zonder therapeut wel werken? De opkomst van nieuwe media biedt nieuwe mogelijkheden voor de hulpverlening. Zo wordt steeds vaker gebruikgemaakt van internet, e-mail, sms, chat en games in de psychologische hulpverlening. Hoe gaat dat?
In week drie komt een aantal vormen van psychologische behandeling bij somatische patiënten aan bod. Het doel is klachtvermindering en het verbeteren van de eigen gezondheid en kwaliteit van leven. We gaan in op cognitieve therapie, en daarbinnen specifiek op het gevolgenmodel. Op welke theorieën zijn deze behandelingen gebaseerd? Wat zijn de basisprincipes? Hoe werken deze therapieën? Wanneer kunnen ze worden ingezet?
Het beheersbaar houden van de kosten in de zorg staat hoog op de agenda van de overheid en de zorgverzekeraars. Dat betekent dat er wordt gekeken naar de verhouding tussen de effecten en de kosten van een behandeling. In week vier gaat het daarom over kosteneffectiviteit. Een ander onderwerp in deze week is de rol van non-specifieke factoren (zoals de duur van de therapie en de therapeutische relatie) bij psychologische behandelingen. Wat zijn deze factoren en hoe kan je ze beïnvloeden zodat een behandeling zo effectief mogelijk is?
In de vijfde week zijn we aanbeland bij meer intensievere behandelingen, zoals psychofarmacologie. Psychologen schrijven zelf geen pillen voor, maar het is belangrijk dat zij op de hoogte zijn van medische behandelmogelijkheden, hoe deze werken en wat de voor- en nadelen zijn.

Het practicum bestaat uit vier sessies, waarin je met je groep een (simulatie)patiënt met reuma en somberheidsklachten begeleidt. Je oefent o.a. het voeren van een intakegesprek en verschillende psychologische interventietechnieken. Op die manier doe je zoveel mogelijk ervaring op met technieken die je als therapeut kunt gebruiken. Ook heb je na afloop een overzicht van de verschillende fasen van het therapieproces (intake, behandelingsfase en afronding) en de specifieke eisen die elke fase stelt aan de therapeut.
 
Vanwege beperkte capaciteit kunnen maximaal 50 studenten deelnemen aan dit blok. Leerdoelen Dit keuzevak is bedoeld voor studenten psychologie die willen weten hoe psychologische behandelingen werken bij patiënten met lichamelijke klachten. Het is een introductie op behandelingen die door medisch psychologen kunnen worden ingezet. De medisch psycholoog werkt vanuit de visie dat somatische, psychologische en sociale aspecten bij elke aandoening een rol spelen. Vragen die o.a. aan bod komen zijn: Waarom zouden somatische patiënten eigenlijk gebaat kunnen zijn bij een psychologische behandeling? Voor welke patiënten is een psychologische behandeling geschikt (of noodzakelijk)? Welke vorm van psychologische behandeling biedt je een patiënt aan? Hoe motiveer je patiënten voor psychologische begeleiding? Wanneer kies je voor een psychologische behandeling en wanneer voor medicamenteuze therapie? Begin je standaard bij elke patiënt aan een eerstelijns psychologische behandeling, of kies je op basis van de kenmerken van de patiënt gelijk voor een tweede- of derdelijns zorgaanbod? Kan je nieuwe media en psychologische zorg combineren? Zo ja, hoe doe je dat? Werkt een psychologische behandeling eigenlijk wel? Zo ja, hoe werkt dat dan? Is het de theorie die ten grondslag ligt aan de therapie of is het de aandacht die je als cliënt krijgt van de therapeut? Hoe bepaal je of je behandeling heeft gewerkt? Na afloop van het blok heeft de student kennis opgedaan over indicatiecriteria voor verschillende psychologische behandelingen (voornamelijk psychologische interventies) die door medisch psychologen worden ingezet, de kenmerken en werkwijze van verschillende psychologische behandelingen en de effectieve bestanddelen ervan. Studenten kennen het principe van stepped-care en kunnen de voor- en nadelen daarvan uitleggen. Studenten zijn in staat om deze kennis toe te passen op praktische casuïstiek van patiënten met sterk uiteenlopende lichamelijke problemen die tijdens de onderwijsgroepen en practica aan bod komt.
 
Dit keuzevak is zowel interessant en geschikt voor studenten die de minor Medische Psychologie hebben gevolgd als voor studenten die (nog) weinig kennis hebben van het vakgebied van de medische psychologie.
 
 Leerdoelen:
  • De student kan uitleggen wat de invloed van somatische aandoeningen kan zijn op het psychisch functioneren (en vice versa).
  • De student kan de stepped-care methodiek met de matched-care methodiek vergelijken.
  • De student kan aangeven welke verschillende behandelingen medisch psychologen kunnen gebruiken bij somatisch zieke patiënten met psychische problemen, zoals (online) zelfhulp, cognitieve gedragstherapie en psychofarmacologie.
  • De student kan aangeven wat de mogelijkheden en onmogelijkheden zijn van verschillende behandelingen die medisch psychologen kunnen inzetten bij somatisch zieke patiënten met psychische problemen
  • De student kan onderbouwen voor welke psychologische behandeling het beste gekozen kan worden bij een gefingeerde casus over een somatisch zieke patiënt met psychische problemen.
  • De student kan de basistechnieken van de cognitieve gedragstherapie benoemen en zelf toepassen bij een simulatiepatiënt.
  • De student kan benoemen en toelichten welke factoren bij psychologische behandelingen werkzaam zijn.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud Psychophysiology assumes that cognitive, emotional, social and behavioral processes are mirrored in physiological processes in the human body. Electrophysiology focusses on electrophysiological processes, like activity in the brain, the heartbeat and muscle activity. It can be used to study all kind of mental events, like emotions and thoughts. With electroencephalography (EEG), we can visualize the activity in the brain, electrocardiography (ECG) investigates activity of the heart and electromyography (EMG) records activity of the muscles. In this practical training all three techniques will be covered. There will be lectures in which the theoretical background will be explained and there will be hands-on training sessions.
  Leerdoelen At the end of this course,
  • you know how to measure EEG/ERP, ECG, and EMG, and you can explain the procedure;
  • you know how to analyze EEG/ERP-data, and you can explain the procedure;
  • you can write a report on a scientific electrophysiological experiment, according to a scientific format.
Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

Inhoud This course will provide a global outline of how the human body develops from a fertilised egg. From an embryological perspective, human prenatal development can be grossly divided into three periods, i.e. the early pre-embryonic period covering the first two weeks, the embryonic period from 2 to 8 weeks after conception, and the foetal period that extends from the 9th week to birth (usually at 38 weeks after conception). The early period is characterised by cell multiplication, implantation in the uterine wall, and the development of extra-embryonic tissues, such as the placenta and the amniotic membrane, which also arise from the fertilised egg. During this period, the cells that will give rise to the embryo remain undifferentiated. After two weeks of development, these undifferentiated cells are arranged in a disk-like structure. During the embryonic period this disk will transform into a small human body (~4 cm in length) with almost all organs and body parts present in a recognizable form. The foetal period is characterised by growth of the body and maturation of the organs. An important topic of this course will be the transformations during the 3rd and 4th week of development, when the early embryo transforms from a disk-like structure into a cylindrical embryo, in which most body parts and organs are formed in rudimentary form. Leerdoelen After completing this course you will have basic knowledge of:
  • Development of primordial germ cells, genital tract development and sexual differentiation
  • Early pre-implantation development
  • Sizes and gross appearance of the developing human body throughout pregnancy.
  • Development of the basic body plan, including the development of the major germinal layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm), the development of the body axes (cranio-caudal, left-right, dorso-ventral), the role of key embryonic events, i.e. gastrulation, neurulation and embryonic folding, and the role of temporary embryonic structures such as the primitive streak, the notochord, neural crest, pharyngeal arches, somites, and lateral plate mesoderm
  • The role of signalling molecules, such as Sonic hedgehog, BMPs and Wnts, and transcription regulators such as the Hox family of proteins in the regulation of developmental processes such as the development of limbs and the vertebral column.
  • How abnormalities in embryonic signalling cascades may result in congenital malformations

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. HJP Delea', 'MDP Jimenez Galindo, MA', 'prof.dr. HAM Klemann']
text:
Inhoud
In this course we study emerging economies. This has become a popular theory since the end of the Cold War in the late 1980s. What exactly do we mean by emerging economies? Why and how do they develop? What are the effects of emerging economies on the global division of labour? This course takes a historical approach because the concept of emerging economies. Throughout world history we can discern the rise and decline of markets and economies. Before c. 1800 the economic centre of the world was firmly in Eastern Asia, but shifted to Western Europe and North America during the Industrial Revolution. We are now perhaps witnessing a new shift with the rise of the BRIC-countries: Brazil, Russia, India and China. These important economic processes also change the balance of economic and military power in the world and thus the system of international relations.
Leerdoelen
  • Students will be able to assess the concept of emerging economies.
  • Students will be able to compare various cases of economic 'emergence' since ca. 1800 and in different world regions.
  • Students will be able to write a speech, prepare a political programme, conduct a formal debate and compose an opinionated essay on economic development.

lecturers: ['dr. JW Hiah', 'dr.mr. WJ Kortleven', 'mr. CV Dunk', 'mr.dr. HTM Kloosterhuis', 'mr.dr. NL Holvast', 'prof.dr. P Mascini']
text:
Inhoud
Dit vak biedt een inleiding in de rechtssociologie, waarin de wereld van het recht centraal staat. Die wereld gaan we mede aan de hand van de actualiteit verkennen op empirische wijze. Daarbij laten we zien welke sociale (f)actoren het recht beïnvloeden en –omgekeerd– welke rol het recht in de samenleving speelt. Aandacht wordt besteed aan wetgevingspraktijken en zo wordt inzicht gegeven in de feitelijke processen die schuilgaan achter de teksten die in het Staatsblad verschijnen. Tevens worden inkijkjes geboden in de wereld van de advocatuur en die van de rechterlijke macht. Daarbij laten we zien hoe die werelden veranderen in relatie tot de algemene veranderingen die in de samenleving als geheel aanwijsbaar zijn. Een belangrijk aandachtspunt is ook het thema handhaving, waarbij wordt ingegaan op vraagstukken rond effectiviteit van wetgeving en regelnaleving.
Leerdoelen ​Het doel van rechtssociologie is:
 
  • inzicht geven in de wisselwerking van recht en samenleving
  • inzicht geven in de positie en de rol van de pijlers van de rechtsstaat, te weten wetgeving, advocatuur, rechterlijke macht en handhavingsorganisaties in de moderne samenleving
  • inzicht geven in theoretische en empirische bevindingen van de rechtssociologie
  • inzicht geven in de mogelijkheden en beperkingen om met behulp van juridische interventies maatschappelijke problemen op te lossen
  • het leren schrijven van een werkstuk waarin een kritische reactie gegeven wordt op een maatschappelijk en juridisch actueel thema

Inhoud Modern law and economics is unthinkable without empirical tests. This course makes students familiar with the most important aspects of such tests from the design stage, to the collection of data to the actual estimate of simple econometric models. It is a "hands on" course including many practical exercises. Students of this course will learn to: 
1. Think creatively about research design;
2. Describe the data;
3. Understand OLS regressions;
4. Understand empirical work as it relates to causality.
 
This course is open for EMLE students only.

lecturers: ['dr. JW Hiah', 'dr.mr. WJ Kortleven', 'mr. CV Dunk', 'mr.dr. HTM Kloosterhuis', 'mr.dr. NL Holvast', 'prof.dr. P Mascini', 'prof.dr. PTM Desmet']
text:
Inhoud
Dit vak biedt een inleiding in de rechtssociologie, waarin de wereld van het recht centraal staat. Die wereld gaan we mede aan de hand van de actualiteit verkennen op empirische wijze. Daarbij laten we zien welke sociale (f)actoren het recht beïnvloeden en –omgekeerd– welke rol het recht in de samenleving speelt. Aandacht wordt besteed aan wetgevingspraktijken en zo wordt inzicht gegeven in de feitelijke processen die schuilgaan achter de teksten die in het Staatsblad verschijnen. Tevens worden inkijkjes geboden in de wereld van de advocatuur en die van de rechterlijke macht. Daarbij laten we zien hoe die werelden veranderen in relatie tot de algemene veranderingen die in de samenleving als geheel aanwijsbaar zijn. Een belangrijk aandachtspunt is ook het thema handhaving, waarbij wordt ingegaan op vraagstukken rond effectiviteit van wetgeving en regelnaleving.
Leerdoelen ​Het doel van rechtssociologie is:
 
  • inzicht geven in de wisselwerking van recht en samenleving
  • inzicht geven in de positie en de rol van de pijlers van de rechtsstaat, te weten wetgeving, advocatuur, rechterlijke macht en handhavingsorganisaties in de moderne samenleving
  • inzicht geven in theoretische en empirische bevindingen van de rechtssociologie
  • inzicht geven in de mogelijkheden en beperkingen om met behulp van juridische interventies maatschappelijke problemen op te lossen
  • het leren schrijven van een werkstuk waarin een kritische reactie gegeven wordt op een maatschappelijk en juridisch actueel thema

Inhoud In this course, we will discuss how economists apply the scientific method and use various empirical techniques to answer research questions in Personnel Economics. We will use research papers from the Personnel Economics literature to build your knowledge and develop your skills. This course further combines the theoretical insights and econometric skills you obtained in block 1. 

The course topics include:
  • Employee movement in and out of firm: screening, hiring, retention, quits
  • Monetary and non-monetary incentives
  • Supervision and monitoring
  • Teams and workforce diversity
  • Peer pressure and fairness.
Leerdoelen At the end of this course you should be able to:
  •    interpret empirical findings in personnel economics research papers, in light of both theory and empirical methods used,
  •    assess the validity of different empirical methods researchers used to answer research questions,
  •    perform an empirical analysis on a given question, and to interpret and expose the findings correctly and clearly,
  •    design an experimental setting to test causality in topics related to personnel  economics,
  •    evaluate the main advantages and drawbacks of different types of experimental strategies that can be used to test hypotheses related to personnel economics theories,
  •    collaborate with other students to formulate and answer research questions. 
    Extra In the re-examination, the original grades for the assignments will count. It is not possible to redo the assignments.

Final grade:
  • Two assignments (40%)
  • Written (re-)examination with essay questions and possibly multiple choice questions (60%)

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud The course is structured around current and emerging themes and debates in the methodological literature. Current research routines and their alternatives will be discussed and critically assessed using literature in which competing approaches are presented and justified or criticized.
In this course you will
(a) Read literature on methodological debates and discuss its contents in class.
(b) Practice your understanding of this literature by means of assignments.
For each of the ten plenary sessions, there will be readings and an assignment. You will receive feedback on each assignment. Submission of assignments (before the stated deadline) and attendance at the sessions are mandatory.
  Leerdoelen The goal of this course is to strengthen and deepen the understanding of the core methodological issues and choices in empirical research. The contents of this course comprise all phases of an empirical study, from the specification of its aim against the background of an evaluation of previous research, through case selection and measurement decisions, to the production of the study’s results, their interpretation and their reporting.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University

lecturers: ['dr. RBC Huijsmans', 'prof.dr. M Arsel', 'prof.dr. W Harcourt']

course_title: Endoscopie: klinisch redeneren en vitale functies

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Increasingly strong calls for “relevant” research emanate from society at large, research financiers, and the scholarly community. One example is the Responsible Research in Business and Management platform, which held its first Summit in Rotterdam to achieve this goal. While academic researchers must remain “rigorous” in their endeavours, they are expected to engage ever more with complex societal problems, such as the contribution of business to mitigating climate change and reducing social disparities such as gender discrimination and high income inequality. So far, management scholars have trailed in disseminating their insights outside academic circles, as is usual in many natural sciences. Many businesses, governments, and civil organizations are more than eager to acquire the knowledge and skills to better align their own actions with societal needs. 
Engaged research aims to bridge the wide gap between management scholars and practitioners. While maintaining high research quality standards, it seeks to produce knowledge to address societal challenges. Engaged research is a participative form of inquiry, whereby scholars interact with practitioners during the identification of research questions, the collection of data, the interpretation of outcomes, and/or the translation of academic insights into managerial implications. 
During the course, you will discover the opportunities and challenges of engaged research. You will peruse different perspectives on engaged research, written by both proponents and skeptics. You will analyze and discuss the strengths and limitations of the different viewpoints with fellow students, so as to tease whether, when, and how engaged research will be valuable to management research, in particular, to your academic career. Finally, you will develop a research proposal in which you apply engaged research principles to a concrete research problem of your choice.

Leerdoelen The course has three major aims. First, realizing the opportunities for academic researchers to perform “engaged research,” that is, applying academic insights to address real-world societal challenges. Second, understanding the epistemological specificities of performing engaged research. Third, developing the mindset and skills to embark on engaged research.

Inhoud

Deze cursus voor academische doeleinden omvat alle belangrijke vaardigheden en taalaspecten die nodig zijn voor het verbeteren van de Engels taalvaardigheid in zowel academische als alledaagse situaties. De volgende onderwerpen komen aan bod:

  • luisteren;
  • spreken- discussiëren, debatteren en presentaties;
  • begrijpend lezen;
  • schrijven- essays, beschrijven van grafieken, e-mails etc.;
  • kritisch denken;
  • grammatica;
  • vocabulaire.
Leerdoelen Tijdens de cursus ligt de focus mede op het gebruik en verbeteren van grammaticale structuren, zodat je in diverse situaties kunt communiceren. Bovendien heeft deze cursus een interactief karakter. Het eindniveau van de cursus is B2.1 volgens het Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR). Belangrijk om te weten

  • Het cursusmateriaal is bij de cursusprijs inbegrepen. In de bevestigingsbrief die je ontvangt als de cursus doorgaat, informeren we je over de details.

  • De groepen zijn klein: minimaal 12 en maximaal 14 deelnemers. Let op! Bij minder dan 12 inschrijvingen behoudt het LTC het recht om de cursus te annuleren.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud This course deals with factors that influence learning, such as characteristics of the learner, characteristics of the learner's environment, and the learning process. Topics that we will focus on include individuals’ intellectual capacities and how intelligence contributes to learning, the influence of the family and the importance of upbringing in relation to learning, teachers’ role in the learning process and what he/she can do to motivate students. Moreover, we will learn how learners can influence their learning outcomes. For this, we will look at self-directed learning, which is an important learning skill, and physical movement and exercise as a means to support learning.
  Leerdoelen After this course, the student should be able to:
-Stress the importance of the engines for learning discussed in this course using theories and
empirical evidence from educational psychology, cognitive psychology, and developmental
psychology.
-Critically evaluate these engines for learning by discussing under which conditions each engine
can influence learning and how.
-Write and present a project plan from the perspective of an educational psychologist for an
organisation that seeks consultancy.
  Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

Inhoud

Inhoud Today, many Dutch law firms and companies expect their legal staff not only to be fluent in ordinary English, but familiar with legal English. Furthermore, the new Dutch court specializing in international commercial transactions, the ‘Netherlands Commercial Court’, conducts all its procedures and hearings in English.
The aim of this course is to familiarize students with the legal concepts behind English legal terminology. This will not only provide students with a better understanding of English legal texts, but will also give students the tools they need to be able to translate concepts from the Dutch legal system into English. With its emphasis on oral practice, the course will also help students to prepare for conducting legal discussions in English in their professional lives.
  Leerdoelen This course is intended for students who have studied law in a language other than English. The aim of this course is to familiarize students with the legal concepts behind English legal terminology. This will not only provide students with a better understanding of English legal texts, but will also give students the tools they need to be able to translate concepts from the Dutch legal systems into English. By also focusing on speaking about legal issues in English, it will help students to prepare for conducting legal discussions and negotiations in English in their professional lives.

Inhoud The terminology is explained by placing it within the context of a brief overview of a range of legal domains: legal system, tort, contract, company and criminal law. Familiarity with English legal terminology will not only provide students with a better understanding of English legal texts, but will also give students the tools they need to be able to translate concepts from their own legal systems into English.
  Leerdoelen This course is intended for students who have studied law in a language other than English. It is open to both Dutch and international students. This course will familiarize students with English legal terminology.
 
The aim of this English legal terminology course is two-fold: to help law students in their academic studies and to prepare them for professional life. However, it is not an ‘English for lawyers’ course. It is not a course dealing with English grammar. The focus of the course is on the legal concepts behind English legal terminology.

course_title: English business speaking and writing skills
college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University

text:
Inhoud
This course aims to improve the practical skills such as reading, writing and listening. Fluency practice and public administration terminology are also important elements in this course. 
Leerdoelen
By the end of the course, students should be able to:
* express themselves in grammatically correct English, both orally and in writing.
* comprehend a text on public administration; analyze and interpret this text; summarize
this text.
* write a short policy paper on a specific subject; write an essay on a specific public
administration issue.
* write lecture notes on web lecture.
* define and explain public administration concepts; express their ideas or opinions on
certain subjects; provide arguments for their opinion.
* understand and use typically public administration terminology.

Inhoud Why do students need to understand the context of Information Systems within enterprises?
  • Information Systems (IS) have enormous strategic value so when they are not working even for a short time, an organization cannot function;
  • The Life Cycle Costs (acquisition, operation, security, and maintenance) of enterprise systems is considerable;
  • It is therefore essential to manage information systems properly. The planning, organizing, implementing, operating, and controlling of the infrastructures and the organization's portfolio of applications must be done with great skill;
  • To obtain awareness of different types of Information Systems and different roles that different systems play in organizations;
  • To gain awareness and knowledge of ERP, CRM, SCM and E-Commerce;
  • To be able to recognize opportunities that are enabled by information technology and to be able to decide to what extent information technology is needed within an organization.
  • To understand critical issues in Information Systems, such as security, project risks and outsourcing of Information Systems. Be able to identify these issues and deal with them.
  • The course also helps students digest why most ERP systems do not live up to its acronym of planning resources for the enterprise. Students should be able to critically evaluate the following questions:
  • What is ERP? What is EIS? How do People and Process come into Technology?
  • What are the similarities and differences between ERP and EIS?
  • How do Enterprise Systems affect Accountants and Economists?
  • How can economic theory help explain the effects of information technology on organizations and value chains?
  • What benefits have been realized by certain companies by implementing Information Technology?
  • How can information technology be an enabler but also be an inhibitor for realizing an organization its strategy?
  • What are advantages and disadvantages from new technologies as Big Data and Blockchain
Leerdoelen
  • Students have knowledge of the use of Enterprise information systems within organisations.
  • Students have knowledge of different applications of Enterprise information systems in organisations.
  • Students have knowledge of different economic theories that enable them to explain and understand the effects of the use of information systems within organisations.
  • Students have knowledge of how research is performed with regard to information systems.
  • Students are able to analyse and identify different situations in which technology is able to help an organization succeed in its goals.
  • Students are able to use different theories to explain how the use of technology may affect organisations.
  • Students are able to critically analyse and report on research findings from a project they perform in a logical and consistent way.
  • Students are able to present their research essay as well as answer critical questions about this essay in a convincing manner.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Added several additional new cases for learning in practice.
  Extra
  • Presentation 5%, Essay 25%.
  • The exam consists of two parts, a multiple choice (MC) part and an open question part. The MC part of the exam needs to be passed with a score of at least 5.5 in order for the essay to be included in the final result for the course.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Telling entertaining stories to educate people is as old as mankind. Think of court jesters, fairytales, puppet shows: all examples of entertainment with an added value. Nowadays you find it in all modern media: drama and soap series on television, blogs on the internet, „webisodes‟ on your mobile phone. The difference with the old age is that because of the application of modern technology, the potential impact of an Entertainment-Education intervention is much bigger.
The Entertainment-Education strategy is a communication strategy that has received a lot of scientific attention (both nationally and internationally), and is being put into practice more and more often. To effectively apply this strategy, it is important to gain knowledge and skills both in academic and applied settings and beyond. In this course we discuss and show examples of EE programs, theories for social change, media practice, different EE collaborations, formative and summative research and ethics.  During the course you gain knowledge and experience via (guest) lectures, analyzing video and film fragments, and working in small groups on designing an Entertainment Education media program.

Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 25. IBCoM students take priority over other students. Leerdoelen This course gives you an in-depth understanding of the Entertainment-Education (EE) strategy and how it works in theory and practice. Entertainment-Education is a scientific communication strategy that systematically interweaves prosocial issues into an entertainment storytelling format in order to create a favorable climate for prosocial change. We will apply participatory working methods to actively engage you on your Entertainment-Education journey and to show how you can use your learning experience in your future professional life.
 
You have gained knowledge and understanding of:
  • The main theoretical approaches and perspectives on the Entertainment-Education for Social Change communication strategy.
  • Examples of how various Entertainment-Education media formats are designed and implemented worldwide (e.g. in soap- and drama series, webisodes, serious games, music, theater cross media and transmedia platforms).
  • How prosocial organizations, communication experts, entertainment media makers and other stakeholders collaborate during the design and implementation of an entertainment education program e.g. in the field of health, sustainability and social tolerance.
  • Different forms of Entertainment-Education research that come into play during the development and implementation of an EE media format.
  • Potential ethical dilemmas and unintended effects that might be faced.
 
You have developed skills to:
  • Analyze the applications of Entertainment-Education (EE) strategies worldwide and EE-formats in different media.
  • Apply theoretical notions of the EE strategy (e.g. social learning theory, elaboration likelihood model, para-social interaction, positive deviance strategy).
  • Identify and understand different roles of various stakeholders in the design and implementation of an Entertainment-Education media format.
  • Apply different forms of EE research.
  • Examine and (pro-actively) reflect on potential ethical dilemmas and unintended effects in Entertainment-Education programs.
  • Design and pitch an Entertainment-Education media intervention plan.

Inhoud This course aims at providing students with an overview of opportunities and challenges faced by entrepreneurs in young, high-growth ventures.
The course is divided into three parts.
In the first part, the course explores valuation methods for entrepreneurial ventures (e.g. DCF analysis and multiples) and how to assess their growth potential.
The second part of the course focuses on obtaining external funding:  it studies the advantages and disadvantages of different funding players (e.g. angel financing, Venture Capital, crowdsourcing), furthermore it explores the design of financing instruments (e.g. staging, convertible instruments).
Lastly, the third part of the course describes and investigates exit strategies and their related costs and benefits (e.g. acquisitions, IPOs).

  Leerdoelen Understanding the main challenges faced by entrepreneurs in the early stages of their ventures, especially in uncertain and innovative streams of business.
Understanding the factors considered by investors when selecting which entrepreneurial project to fund.
Analyzing the benefits and costs associated with different sources of funding, both for the entrepreneurs and financiers.
Understanding the various ways investors and entrepreneurs can exit from their ventures and monetize their investments.
By the end of the course, students will gain an overview of the process of starting, funding, growing and exiting an entrepreneurial project. The course will have them equipped with the tools to better understand the financing of innovation and the venture capital industry.

  Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The course is new and it was not offered in previous years. The course took over a previous course code, but the two do not share any similarity, nor in terms of contents nor approach.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Content
 
Running a start-up requires operating under high uncertainty and navigating well through often chaotic, confusing information and experiences. In this course, we will focus on the customer development process, after an opportunity has been identified, and address a set of skills that can help early-stage entrepreneurs to manage their ventures more effectively. In particular, we will discuss different leadership styles and decision making approaches and explore how these can affect the performance, motivation and culture of the members of a new venture. We will further focus on strategies for making good decisions and discuss ways to avoid common mistakes and biases throughout the customer development journey. Being an effective entrepreneur and leader will also require learning how to develop empathy and to engage effectively with your customer, by acquiring strong interviewing techniques. As an entrepreneur, you would also often need to handle difficult conversations and we will further identify a set of techniques for effective conflict resolution, as well as a range of influence tactics and mechanisms that can be applied in your start-up and work relationships. In addition, we will discuss different negotiation styles and learn how best to align individuals’ goals, interests and values with those of the organization. The overall aim of the course is to provide practical knowledge and skills that future entrepreneurs can apply when developing, testing and validating their hypotheses about a business opportunity.
Leerdoelen
Learning Goals

At the end of this course, students will be able to:
• Understand the dynamics of the entrepreneurial process and learn best practices for customer development.
• Learn and apply a set of interviewing best practices for customer discovery
• Learn the characteristics of effective team formation and recognize your own team profile, identifying core strengths and areas for improvement.
• Engage with a set of negotiation techniques and influence tactics and learn how to apply them in order to improve your start-up’s outcomes.
• Understand the set of entrepreneurial skills, necessary at different stages of the idea validation process
• Develop self-awareness as to your own entrepreneurial skillset and its strengths and areas for improvement, based on reflection and action learning tools

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud The course Entrepreneurial Challenge is an intensive module. You will explore and experience what it entails to start a new and ambitious company. You will come to understand that not only existing businesses, but also new businesses require management. As you are enrolled in the Master in Management program, it is important to understand that without businesses there is nothing to manage, and without entrepreneurs there would be (and will be) no businesses. Furthermore, many RSM graduates will – at some stage in their career – consider entrepreneurship as a serious career opportunity. 
In line with RSM’s mission statement we will focus on social entrepreneurship, supporting one of the SDG’s which will be introduced elaborately. The course contains a concise introduction to the domain of social entrepreneurship theory and research. To apply the key concepts and tools in a real-life setting, teams will develop and revise their own start-up opportunities and explore viable business models in the field of social entrepreneurship. Entrepreneurship is about turning unmet needs and unsolved problems into viable economic activity. The essence of entrepreneurship has been described as ‘the pursuit of opportunity without regard to the resources currently controlled.’ Entrepreneurship starts with the discovery of promising opportunities. Understanding the origins of such opportunities is key for start-up entrepreneurs and existing companies alike to develop business models that will effectively create and capture value from the identified opportunities. Entrepreneurship is not just a process, but also a mindset. In this module you develop that mindset by exploring the first stages of the process: the identification and evaluation of opportunities and the search for viable business models.
The course requires that all students actively participate in the classes. In addition, we expect the students to spend additional time per day on class preparation by reading the literature and doing project work. This course is a crash course into the (theoretical) foundations of entrepreneurship and a pressure cooker module for developing a business case and presenting it in front of a jury; both of them require your full dedication.

Sessions and attendance

The sessions in this module will differ in nature, ranging from student presentations, to workshops, to feedback sessions. During these meetings, a proactive and constructive atmosphere will be stimulated: a collaborative, open approach is needed to help each other and to learn from each other. The instructor in this course will serve primarily as a coach, rather than as a teacher. His main concern is to guide the group and the teams through the necessary thought and work processes.
Attendance of all university sessions is compulsory

This course is worth 2 EC. Leerdoelen Content-wise: During this course:
  • You will come to understand that new venture creation is a process to systematically turn business model assumptions into knowledge, and that this learning process typically involves business model change.
  • You will come to understand the complexity of the new venture creation process, i.e. you will be able to explain and illustrate that its key steps, activities and challenges are highly interrelated, interdisciplinary, unpredictable, heterogeneous, and iterative.
 
Analytical skills: During this course:
  • You will develop the capability to construct, evaluate, and refine business models for new ventures.
  • You will develop the capability to set-up effective and efficient research designs to turn critical assumptions into knowledge.
 
Social-communicative skills: During this course:
  • You will develop the capability to document your business modelling process concisely, with clarity, logical flow, and coherence. 
  • You will develop the capability to discuss and present your new venture creation process in a variety of contexts, i.e. in your multidisciplinary student team, during the plenary workshops, in a feedback session with startup coaches and entrepreneurs, and in front of an expert panel at the final presentation session.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud De Entrepreneurial Challenge is een kort en krachtig vak. In teamverband verken en ervaar je wat het is om een nieuw en ambitieus bedrijf te starten. Je leert dat management niet alleen management nodig is in bestaande bedrijven, maar ook geldt in nieuwe, jonge bedrijven. Veel van de lessen blijken bovendien niet alleen van toepassing op nieuwe bedrijven, maar zijn ook relevant voor het management in volwassen bedrijven en organisaties.
 
In lijn met de missie van RSM – A force for positive change – richt de challenge zich meer in het bijzonder op het het starten van een social business met als doel om impact te maken in lijn met een of meer Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). In het vak worden enkele theoretische concepten en theorieen geïntroduceerd, met als doel om deze toe te passen in de praktijk. Deelnemers gaan in teams zelf ideeën verkennen en business modellen ontwikkelen.
  Leerdoelen Na afloop van het vak:
  • Begrijp je dat het starten van een bedrijf bestaat uit het systematisch ontwikkelen en testen van kritieke veronderstellingen over het business model, en dat dit leerproces doorgaans gepaard gaat met flinke veranderingen in het business model zelf.
  • Begrijp je de complexiteit van het start-up proces. Je bent in staat om de verschillende hoofdstappen, -activiteiten en -uitdagingen uit te leggen en te illustreren.
  • Ben je in staat om business modellen voor startups te ontwikkelen, te evalueren, en aan te passen
  • Ben je in staat om effectief en efficient onderzoeksmethoden te ontwikkelen en toe te passen om startup-ideeën te valideren.
  • Ben je in staat om het startup proces beknopt en helder te documenteren
  • Ben je in staat om het startup proces te presenteren en te bediscussiëren

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Course content, description
The objective of this course is to provide students with a state-of-the-art understanding of the valuation of small and mid-cap public and private firms, and the economics of contracts as it applies to entrepreneurship and new venture finance. Entrepreneurship concerns the undertaking of new business ventures. We will analyse the unique financial issues relating to entrepreneurial firms and to develop a set of skills that has wide applications for such situations. Specific topics will include: start-up ventures; financial management of rapidly growing firms; deal structuring; valuation; initial public offerings; the decision to harvest; and leveraged/ management buyouts. We will discuss the various sources of capital for entrepreneurial firms. These sources include venture capital, commercial banks and crowd funding. The decisions of firms at various phases of their life cycle will be examined and the advantages and disadvantages of various sources of financing will be compared. Analytical tools will be introduced and utilized. Financial analysis, various valuation methods, negotiations, and deal structuring are examined in the context of entrepreneurial firms. This course is aimed at students who plan to start, acquire, finance or work for entrepreneurial, fast-growing businesses. It will also be useful for students who plan to join venture capital/private equity firms and investment banks. The course aims at instructing the student in how “real world” professional investors and corporate managers operate to create wealth from entrepreneurial activity. Leerdoelen Learning objectives
After having followed this course, students are among others able to understand how to value a start-up firm, how contracts used in new venture finance shape incentives, how deals are structured, how to finance young start-up companies, how private equity works in creating value in start-ups, buyouts and growth financing and how to decide when to exit investments. Students are also able to appraise and construct a valuation for a start-up company, compare and select the different sources of financing and connect theory and practice.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Contents, course description

If you want to know more about developing a business model for a startup and/or setting up your own venture, the Entrepreneurial Lab course is for you. Within an intense and hand-on experiential approach, the Entrepreneurial Lab course allows you exploring a business opportunity with your team and testing its potential value. 
​
This course provides advanced master students with a practical, yet rigorous understanding of the role, the analytics, and the process of business planning that leads to the successful creation of new ventures. Above all, students will be responsible to develop their own professional networks. As it’s a hands-on course, you will learn about business modelling, how to refine opportunities, analyse feasibility, financial planning, and organisational implementation. You will write a weekly blog and a business report and pitch your idea to a jury of experts. In previous years our students launched successful new businesses, including Senz Umbrellas, Symbid and Yoursurprise.com.
Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives

After this course, students will:
•    Define and assess the elements of new business models and recognize how these elements interrelate to each other;
•    Identify major assumptions in their start-up’s business model mainly on their value proposition;
•    Translate assumptions in their start-up’s business model in measurable hypotheses, test them, and change the business model accordingly;
•    Communicate and effectively interact with others to discover and develop a viable start-up business model.
•    Reflect critically on the entire process of the project and evaluate peer and own contribution to the project.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['AM de Greef, MSc', 'dr. FPH Jaspers', 'dr. G Criaco', 'dr. I Verheul', 'J Dresia', 'L Fuligni', 'M Bax']
text: Inhoud

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. AM Nadolska-den Ouden', 'PJ de Wilde - Mes']
text:
Inhoud The Entrepreneurship course zooms in on 4 key questions:
 
  1. What is entrepreneurship? (Module 1)
  2. What types of entrepreneurs are there? (Module 2)
  3. What is an "entrepreneurial opportunity"? (Module 3)
  4. What do you need to be successful as an entrepreneur? (Module 4).
Leerdoelen Learning objectives Block 7
After the modules, tutorials and the business case, the student can:
  1. Explain what entrepreneurship is, what the core elements are, and why entrepreneurship is seen as indispensable in our economy and society;
  2. Critically analyze the process underlying the start of a new business;
  3. Participate in an active and semi-professional manner in discussions and apply literature on topics covered in the course during discussions and assignments;
  4. Prepare well-founded and structured writing assignments and develop a business case that meets the guidelines of academic writing set in this course.
Learning objectives Block 8
After the lectures, tutorials and the Entrepreneurship Challenge, the student can:
  1. Develop a proposition and business model based on the Lean Startup method;
  2. Explain how an individual can develop into a (successful) entrepreneur; how to set up a business; and how this company can develop successfully;
  3. Present his or her own business idea by means of a "Pecha Kucha" presentation;
  4. Implement a project in a team with random fellow students.

Inhoud
In this course we will introduce entrepreneurship as an academic discipline and we will discuss some important aspects of starting a new venture. This course contains a concise introduction to the domain of entrepreneurship theory and practice. Entrepreneurship is all about identifying opportunities and pursuing them. Understanding the origins of such opportunities is key for entrepreneurs and existing companies alike in order to develop business models that will effectively create and capture value. In this course students will focus on three views of entrepreneurship theory: entrepreneurship, corporate entrepreneurship and social entrepreneurship. Entrepreneurship is not just a process but also a mind-set; it is behaviour.  Students will also develop that mind-set by exploring the first stages of entrepreneurial process: the identification and evaluation of opportunities and the search for viable business models. This course is a crash course in the (theoretical) foundations of entrepreneurship and a pressure cooker module for developing a business case and presenting it in front of a jury.
Leerdoelen After the course, students are able to:
  • Explain what entrepreneurship is, what its central elements are, and why entrepreneurship is crucial for our economy and society;
  • Explain the difference between entrepreneurship and management in general, and between entrepreneurship, intrapreneurship and social entrepreneurship in particular.
  • Develop a business model by applying the principles of the lean startup method.
  • Explain how new ventures emerge and develop.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud During this course we will address the role of entrepreneurship within media markets. We will look at this issue from two angles: entrepreneurship from the perspective of the challenger start-up   company and entrepreneurship within existing media firms. We will discuss literature on entrepreneurship and business model innovation and apply these insights to media related case studies. Furthermore, we will discuss how entrepreneurial principles are applied to media endeavors with not-for-profit social objectives. We will address questions such as: how to identify new market opportunity or social opportunities,  how to find competitive advantage in a media market, how to move from idea to execution and how to scale up and manage growth.
 
In line with the entrepreneurial focus of this course, students are required to write a business plan
for a media-related startup and develop a new value proposition for an existing company. During this process students will experience the valuable contribution of scientific inquiry and insights for the development of new products and services. Students are also required to pitch their business idea and will receive presentation training during the course.
 
As entrepreneurship is the theme of the course, we will invite several professionals from the media industry to discuss their entrepreneurial endeavors. We will also try to arrange having company visits (the dates for these visits might be at a different time than regular classes). Students are also encouraged to organize this themselves.


  Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding  of:
  • Current theory and research on entrepreneurship and innovation and entrepreneurship in media.
  • Characteristics of media markets.
  • Business  model innovation.
  • Social  entrepreneurship theory
 
Students have developed skills to:
  • Analyze entrepreneurial activity and entrepreneurship both from the perspective of the challenger and the incumbent companies.
  • Apply models such as the business model canvas and strategy tools to the media industry.
  • Develop a business idea for a media-related start-up.
  • Create a business plan and strategy for an entrepreneurial endeavor for an existing media company.
  • Create a business plan and strategy for a social entrepreneurship initiative

Inhoud
  • The skeptical economist (ch 1-2)
  • The economic approach (ch. 3 and 11.1-2)
  • Economics of pollution (ch. 4)
  • Environmental policy (ch. 5 (excl. 5.8, 5.9, 5.13), ch. 6 (excl. 6.5), ch. 7 and ch 13.3 (excl. 13.3.3 and 13.4))
  • Valuation: concepts and measurement (ch. 11.3, 12)
  • Renewable resources (ch. 17)
  • Dutch Environmental Policy (ch. 6, 9)
Leerdoelen
  • To learn the economic approach towards the environment and apply this approach to real world environmental and resource problems (including sustainability, the implications of seeing the environment as a commodity and the role of the government or social norms in preventing environmental damage).
  • To understand the main lines of methods in environmental economics.
  • To understand the role of discounting, how to set environmental goals and how to choose between instruments to reach these goals.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar More interactive using mentimeter due to (partly) digital course. Extra This course builds on micro-economics, which is necessary to understand the course. This means that it is possible that you have do extra work yourself if micro-economic knowledge is not at the right level. Our experience is that students who do not follow the courses nearly always fail for the exam. The courses are also needed to focus on the parts of the book that are essential for the exam as the book is extensive.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)

course_title: Environmental History: Perspectives from Human Rights
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. MF van Dijck', 'MDP Jimenez Galindo, MA']
text:
Inhoud

The lately debate about climate change due to human activities on one side, and the Environmental alarmism on the other side, have lead the discussion about the relationship between humanity and its environment in different fields, especially when it comes to policy making. This discussion locates the nature as the main actor, readdressing efforts to create strategies to undo the already damage in order to procure current and next generations with access to basic resources such clean air and fresh water. The course addresses questions such how to reconcile the protection of the nature while granting humanity the possibility to advance in activities with an economic drive specially those which imply the extraction of natural resources? How to reconcile sustainability and development while the last one encompasses an extractive imperative? What does imply for humanity that the nature is considered a subject of rights?

This course gives a detailed overview to different aspects related to human activities deeply intertwined to the course of nature. The discussion rather than focusing on environmental degradation itself or the role of humanity as an entity; will focus on the distribution and share that different human sectors take from the environmental degradation.

Leerdoelen

In this course students will understand the link between environmental damage and human rights by analysing critical theory from different fields. Students will also approach this relation in the frame of the current efforts to create sustainability, involving principally social and economic activities.

Through a historical approach, students will learn about concepts within the study of environmental issues and how they have evolved in time exacerbating the debate around cultural, economic and social inequality and consequently, also about human rights.  Students will learn different approaches to concepts such Conflict & environmental peace, Environmental vulnerability & risk, Ethnic minorities & vulnerability, Intersectionality and the Resources curse. Students will also analyse non-western ways to relate to the environment such ‘El buen vivir and the Pachamama’.

Students will also learn the main issues in the relation between environment and human rights such Land grabbing, transnational water management related to scarcity or industry use, Traditional property and limited access to natural resources in ethnic protected areas, the extractive imperative, sustainability, and corporate environmental accountability & due diligence.

course_title: Epidemic Disease, Famine and Development in Historical Perspective
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Entering the 21st century, climate change, globalization, inequality, and rural-to-urban migration have created conditions conducive to emerging infectious diseases and food production challenges. Epidemics and famine are yet to be consigned to the past – most noticeably seen in the food price spikes seen in the aftermath of the global financial crisis of 2008-9, and in the challenges of Ebola or COVID-19. However, measuring the causes and consequences of these traumatic events is not straightforward. Can history allow us to view these challenges in a new light by offering a deeper temporal perspective?

By comparing terrible cases such as the Black Death of 1356-43, the ‘Columbian Exchange’ diseases of American colonization, the worldwide influenza pandemic of 1918-20, and the Great Leap Forward Famine in China of 1958-62, can we understand more about diseases today such as Ebola or COVID-19 or famines in East Africa, Syria and Yemen? Although the past may be a ‘foreign country’, we shall see that there are many points of continuity and similarity.

Students will understand more about the causes and characteristics of epidemics and famines, and how they relate to development and welfare, social (dis)order, gender inequalities, public health provision, and their relationship with climate change and conflict. We also consider how epidemics and famines have been represented and remembered by surviving generations, and consider controversies over ‘who is to blame’. At the heart of the course, we show how epidemics and famines can shine new light on ‘social vulnerabilities’ often hidden from view in normal times.
  Leerdoelen
  1. Students can identify the major causes, characteristics and consequences of epidemic diseases and famines throughout history using the extensive secondary literature.
  2. Using the extensive secondary literature, students can explain why outcomes from epidemics and famines could be different across time, region, and outbreak.
  3. Students can apply general theoretical concepts from the course to a specific historical case study of an epidemic or famine, by integrating other secondary and primary source evidence of their own.
  4. By comparing epidemics and famines in the pre-industrial past, modern history, and today using the extensive secondary literature, students can explain the value of a historical approach to epidemics and famines.

lecturers: ['dr. AR Vasques', 'dr. J.A. Haagsma', 'dr. L.E. Coffeng', 'prof. dr. I. Lansdorp - Vogelaar', 'prof. dr. ir. A. Burdorf']
text:
Inhoud This course will teach you the main concepts of Epidemiology and Global Health. Epidemiology is the quantitative study of disease occurrence and distribution in specified populations, the study of consequences of health problems as well as risk and protective factors, and the application of this knowledge to prevent and control health problems. You will learn (i) how to use methodological approaches to measure the incidence and prevalence of diseases in populations, (ii) how to determine causes of diseases, and (iii) how and when interventions may contribute to improvements in population health. Throughout the course you will work on an evidence-based prevention plan for a disease and country of your choice. Leerdoelen After following this course you will be able to:
  • Understand measures of occurrence of disease
  • Understand causes of diseases and relations between exposure and disease
  • Analyse relative importance of causes for the burden of disease
  • Understand the effectiveness of interventions
  • Design effective intervention strategies

college: Institute for Housing and Urban Development Studies (IHS)
lecturers: ['CP Wissink - Nercua', 'dr. PE Rabé', 'F Vanelli', 'OFF Fika']
text:
Inhoud A Focus on Equity
Land governance is about the political economy of land, and equitable land governance focuses on the notion of equity and sustainability and the need for designing land policies, initiatives and instruments that can help to address market failure and protect the environment as well as vulnerable members of society from the impacts of unequitable markets.
 
“An understanding of land issues from a governance and political economy perspective can  be  derived  through  a  three  part  framework  that  (i)  analyzes  the  broad  country  context, the types of tenure that exist, the operation of land markets and the institutions (rules  and  structures)  that  regulate  both  tenure  and  markets;  (ii)  examines how a governance  and  political  economy  perspective  can  be  applied  to  a  specific  land  issue or  reform  context,  with  emphasis  on  clarifying  stakeholders,  interests,  influence,  institutions and relationships; and (iii) explores how to manage a reform process.” Palmer, D., Fricska, S. & Wehrmann, B. 2009
 
In the RW, students will split up into working groups that correspond to the three thematic clusters of the ULG specialization.
 
Students can develop their thesis proposals in accordance to the ULG clusters depicted below:

EULG consist of two research workshops and four colloquia. The colloquia will enable students to obtain feedback on their research from IHS staff and their peers in the UMD program. Each colloquium is connected to chapters of the thesis.
 
EULG Research Workshop 1
The first research workshop will focus on the development of conceptual frameworks based on theoretical discussions on the selected topic of students. Students will be exposed to literature on: land rights and the rule of law; land markets and finance; and land, water and natural resources. The theories reviewed will be the underpinning of their thesis proposals and analysis.
 
Output: At the end of RW 1, students should have completed their theoretical chapters.
 
EULG Research Workshop 2
The second research workshop is aimed at equipping EULG students with the techniques needed to conduct their fieldwork. It supports students in the operationalization of their variables and in collecting the right type of data needed to carry out their analysis.
 
Output: At the end of RW 2, students should have completed their research proposals.
 


 
  Leerdoelen Summary Objective
The research workshop aims to support students in investigating and analysing the ways in which urban land, water and natural resources are governed through research. At the end of the research workshop, students should be able to write their research proposal (introduction, literature review and methodology chapters) on equitable urban land governance, considering in detail the notions of equity and sustainability—and the policy and institutional implications of these approaches.

Inhoud Een essay over een fiscaal actueel thema ontleend aan recente wetswijzigingen, recente rechtspraak of fiscaalmaatschappelijke ontwikkelingen. Leerdoelen
  • Het onderkennen van een fiscaal probleem
  • De werking van verschillende heffingswetten, en de economische en juridische gevolgen van gemaakte keuzes op het terrein van privaat en ondernemingsrecht kennen.
  • Het kunnen beschrijven van een fiscaal probleem en de economische gevolgen vanuit verschillende heffingswetten, rekening houdend met de mogelijkheden van het privaat en ondernemingsrecht.
  • Het formuleren van oplossingen voor de uitgewerkte problematiek.
Extra De Paper hoeft niet in blok 1 geschreven te worden, maar heeft doorgaans een uiterste inleverdatum die in de eerste helft van Januari ligt.

course_title: Essential Contemporary Challenges: Philosophy and Practice
text:
Inhoud

We will discuss four key contemporary examples in practical philosophy of pressing social, political and cultural issues, or ‘challenges’. We will explore their implications on both the individual and on the collective level. The four challenges are: 1) Enlightenment as emancipation: a blessing or a burden? The pressures of modern living. Emancipation frees us from many burdens, but now creates new and unexpected ones. 2) Democracy: do we need more, or less? Government and citizens seem deadlocked in a struggle for more and better democracy. Can democracy deliver on its promises – and can the citizens keep up? 3) Environment: how do we configure individual and collective responsibility to minimize ecological crisis? From an environmental justice perspective, those worst hit by environmental harms are often in the least politically and socially empowered to challenge their generating structures. 4) Public health: What is the proper relationship between looking out for the health of people versus corporate power to profit from harmful products and externalities? With rising medical costs, how to distribute scarce resources? What is the role of prevention?


This course aims to promote reflection on these contemporary issues and their linkages through exploring various philosophical responses and dilemmas.

Leerdoelen

Small scale weekly seminars, 1 x 2 hours (obligatory for full-time philosophy students, optional for double degree students)

Lectures will be recorded.

Ability to assess the practical dimension inherent in philosophical theories on society and culture
Ability to discuss case studies philosophically
Ability to analyse, reflect and take a position on 4 societal issues discussed during the course and identify philosophical arguments and positions with respect to them

Inhoud
