Inhoud  
This upper-division undergraduate course studies fundamental philosophical problems at the intersection of ethics and economics. It provides students with the skills to critically evaluate economic arguments, to connect these arguments with contemporary moral theories, and to apply these theories to pervasive social problems. Leerdoelen By the end of the course, students should be able to:
 
1. define and elaborate on core concepts in economics (hedonic vs. preferentialist utility, Pareto improvements, weak vs. strong sustainability, contested exchange) and ethics (side-constraints, moral incentives, rule vs. act utilitarianism, lax vs. strong difference principle, workplace democracy).
 
2. critically assess economic aspects of property rights, market exchange, gender inequality, and environmental degradation in light of the main moral theories.
 
3. assess these theories themselves, in terms of their coherence, cogency, and relevance.

Inhoud This graduate course offers a profound examination of ethics and economics in theory and practice. Firstly, we will study some key concepts and values in economics. What is a market, and what are the virtues and moral limits of markets? What are property rights, and what is their moral relevance? What are the values usually invoked to defend markets? How are markets taken to promote efficiency, freedom and human well-being respectively? Secondly, we will analyze some substantive normative positions on economic questions, such as those held by right-libertarians, left-libertarians or Marxists. This will also allow us to study different ethical foundations that have been offered for different economic systems, such as varieties of capitalism and socialism. In a third step we explore the moral limits of markets and discuss possibly alternative economic systems. Among others, we discuss some specific policy proposals related to debates about ethical problems of our current economic system, such as basic income as a response to increasing material inequality. Leerdoelen The main objective of this course is twofold. Firstly, students acquire an understanding of the relationship between ethics and economics in terms of its historical development, as well as in terms of its role in the contemporary discipline of economics, as well as the economy. Secondly, students learn to critically assess the positions in the field and further develop their oral and written argumentation skills.
  • By the end of this course you should have a good overview of recent work done in the field of economics ethics. You will have studied work by the main contemporary philosophers as well as the most important discussions and issues in this field.
  • You will be equipped to do research (e.g. for a Master’s dissertation) on questions of economic ethics, both theoretical/conceptual as well as applied questions.
  • This course will help you to improve your knowledge of methods and styles of arguments in analytical moral philosophy (esp. ethics/normative political philosophy) – which can also be useful for other streams within analytical moral philosophy.
  • You will be able to practice, refine and further develop your writing and argumentation skills for analytical practical philosophy. This will be a special focus of this course, since you will receive detailed and extensive individual feedback on your written pieces of work.
  • You will be able to practice, refine and further develop your oral argumentation and presentation skills in moral philosophy, through participating in the class discussions.
  • You will be able to learn/practice/rehearse some basic skills related to literature searching and use of libraries and bibliographical search methods.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['D. de Jongh', 'dr. E.M. Bunnik', 'dr. L.L.E. Bolt', 'dr. S. van de Vathorst', "H. Ismaili M'hamdi", 'I. Tuink - Brinkman', 'I.D. Hartog', 'K. Tromp, MSc', 'M. Smedinga', 'mr. J.G.M. Aartsen', 'prof. dr. M.H.N. Schermer']
['mr. CFE Sullivan', 'mr. HY Wu', 'mr.drs. R Bierenbroodspot', 'O el Manouzi, LLM', 'prof.mr. HM Vletter - van Dort']
text:
Inhoud Ethische dilemma’s doen zich regelmatig voor in de financiële sector. Vooral na de financiële crisis van 2007/08 heeft ethiek in de financiële sector meer aandacht gekregen van wetgevers, toezichthouders en de media. Schandalen zoals Enron, Panama Papers en ING worden vaak besproken in ethische discussies en leiden tot bewustwording in de financiële sector. Toch blijven dergelijke schandalen zich voordoen, wat bijvoorbeeld blijkt uit het recente schandaal rondom betaaldienstverlener Wirecard. Hoe dienen wij deze problematiek te benaderen? Hoe kunnen klassieke ethische theorieën ons hierbij helpen? Op welke wijze geven ontwikkelingen in de financiële sector invulling aan ethische kaders? Hoe verhoudt ethiek zich tot het voldoen aan wettelijke verplichtingen en het handelen naar waarden en normen?

Het vak Ethiek, duurzaamheid en compliance is voornamelijk gericht op vaardighedenonderwijs. U wordt – al dan niet in groepsverband – de vaardigheden bijgebracht om een wetenschappelijke bijdrage te leveren aan ethische discussies die betrekking hebben op de financiële sector. Daarnaast worden enkele hoorcolleges verzorgd waarin diverse actuele onderwerpen worden aangesneden die in ethische perspectief worden geplaatst. Hierbij kan worden gedacht aan de ethische overweging bij corporate governance, waarbij gedrag en cultuur een aanzienlijke rol speelt. Daarnaast wordt aandacht besteed aan de ethische implicaties van technologische ontwikkelingen in de financiële sector. Het onderwerp duurzaamheid wordt ook uitvoerig onder de aandacht gebracht met bijzondere aandacht voor de Sustainable Development Goals (SDG’s) van de Verenigde Naties. Voorts wordt stilgestaan bij de wisselwerking tussen compliance en ethiek.

Tijdens het vak wordt getoetst aan de hand van vaardighedenopdrachten. Deze opdrachten betreffen achtereenvolgens een debat, een vlog en een schriftelijke groepsopdracht. Het vak heeft geen afsluitend schriftelijk tentamen.

  Leerdoelen
  • De student herkent een moreel dilemma en kan hierover een oordeel vormen op basis van de ethische theorieën en presenteert dit in groepsverband.
  • De student kan vanuit het theoretische kader argumenteren en debatteren rondom duurzaamheid en ethiek.
  • De student kan de samenhang tussen ethiek enerzijds en corporate governance, financieel recht en economie anderzijds beoordelen.
  • De student kan zelfstandig een kritische visie geven vanuit een ethisch perspectief over de positie van actoren op de financiële markten in relatie tot maatschappelijke opvattingen en de economie aan de hand van internationale kaders.
  • De student kan de financiële en ethische verantwoording van een financiële onderneming toetsen en daarover adviseren.

Inhoud

Welke rol spelen emoties in de morele oordeelsvorming van mensen? Zijn emoties constitutief voor de morele positie die mensen innemen of zijn het stoorzenders die een redelijke oordeelsvorming in de weg staan? En: wat zijn emoties? Zijn emoties louter gevoelens en is een moreel oordeel daarom altijd de expressie van een bepaald gevoel? Of zijn emoties ook te beschouwen als cognitieve mentale toestanden die ons informatie verschaffen over onszelf en over de wereld om ons heen? Ter beantwoording van deze vragen zullen we in deze cursus niet alleen de meest actuele moraalfilosofische debatten over ethiek, rationaliteit en emoties bespreken, maar ook te rade gaan bij het hedendaagse moraalwetenschappelijke onderzoek naar de oorsprong en aard van emoties en naar de invloed van emoties bij oordeelsvorming (o.m. werk van Frans de Waal, Jonathan Haidt en Antonio Damasio). We zullen nadenken over de lichamelijke basis van gevoelens en emoties en dit verbinden met cognitief psychologisch onderzoek naar de onmisbare (en soms misleidende) rol van emoties in het redeneren en het vormen van een standpunt. Vervolgens zullen we discussiëren over wat dit betekent voor de aard en de betrouwbaarheid van evaluatieve oordelen. Een morele stellingname is meer dan de expressie van een gevoel. Maar in welke zin is het meer en anders?

Voor de voltijdstudenten zijn de hoor/werkcolleges verplicht.

Te laat en zonder overleg met de docent ingeleverde verwerkingsessays worden niet meer nagekeken en becijferd.

Leerdoelen Inzicht verkrijgen in de belangrijkste hedendaagse moraalfilosofische en moraalwetenschappelijke visies en debatten over de aard van emoties en over de rol van emoties en redenen in morele oordeelsvorming; het op basis van dit inzicht ontwikkelen van een eigen standpunt ten aanzien van enkele cruciale kwesties in de morele psychologie en meta-ethiek.

course_title: Ethnographic Research and Reflexivity in Development Contexts

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Central in the course is the discussion of two strands of literature. The first strand will focus on the elements of ethnographic research. We will read and discuss literature on data collection, data analysis, theoretical backgrounds (the interpretive research traditions, practice theory), and specific ethnographic/ethnography-related traditions such as auto-ethnography or grounded theory. This will be combined with the reading of examples of ethnographic research into culture participation. During the course, specific assignments will be given to practice the various elements of ethnographic research. In the meetings, students will be involved in active discussion as well as practical exercises in, e.g., interviewing and the open coding of ethnographic data. Students carry out a small ethnographic research project of their own choice, which is prepared through various assignments and which will be reported upon in the final essay. The course will provide a firm introduction into the topic and a sound basis for those who wish to carry out ethnographic or ethnograpically inspired research in the future.
  Leerdoelen This course will provide students with an introductory but thorough understanding of ethnographic research into culture participation. Students will read and discuss key literature on the theoretical backgrounds and methodological issues of ethnographic research. This will be combined with a discussion of examples of ethnographic research into cultural participation. Students will be asked to carry out and report on individual research activities connected to the three main data sources in ethnography (observation, interview, study of documents/artefacts); this will feed into their final assignment, which will be the production of an essay based on the analysis of own empirical data.

course_title: Etiology of Offender Types and Forensic Neuroscience
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud This course has the aim for students to become familiar with different offender types and differentiating these offender types based on their etiology and risk factors. Questions that will be addressed are: "What risk factors for violence does an offender with a psychopathic personality have?" and "which subtypes of offenders with a psychotic disorder can we distinguish on the basis of their background?" In addition, this course involves using fundamental insights from neuroscience. These insights relate to forensic topics such as the emergence of aggression and antisocial behavior and how different brain networks are associated with psychopathic personality. Questions that will be addressed are: "How do different processes in the brain contribute to the development of aggression?" and "how come that a psychopath feels ‘nothing’?" But also: "How can activity in the brain be measured and used in violence risk assessment and management?"
Attention is also paid to the emerging field of science named 'neurolaw'. In court, there is an increase in the use of neuroscientific evidence, for example by giving a court ordered forensic neuropsychological examination of the suspect of a crime. This is also increasingly being used by the defense to reduce the sentence, or even to plea for insanity. Leerdoelen During this course, the student learns to:
  • Distinguish different types of offenders on the basis of etiology and risk factors
  • Describe functions of different brain structures that play a role in aggressive behavior
  • Explain which neurobiological factors are related to the delinquent behavior of different types of offenders.
  • Explain how different neuropsychological conditions play a role in forensic practice.
  • Distinguish between forensic neuropsychology and forensic neuroscience.
  • Assess the added value of neuroscientific information in assessing the risk of violence (compared to the common risk factors used in the risk assessment of violence) and the subsequent risk management.
  • To substantiate the advantages and disadvantages of the use of neuropsychological and neuroscientific information within the legal system ("Neurolaw").

course_title: Europe in a Globalizing World: Migration, Citizenship and Identity
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. CLA Willemse', 'dr. I Gusc', 'G van Campenhout, MSc', 'prof.dr. G Oonk']
text:
Inhoud
Which passport is the most accepted passport around the world and why is this (un)fair? How many generations does it take for a settler and his family to become 'native'? What is the potential of global citizenship in relation to patriotic realities? These are just some of the pressing questions which are fully explored in this course on Global Migration, Citizenship and Identity. Migration and ethnic minorities have always challenged the ‘nation’ in the Nation State. In this series of lectures we will discuss the development of cosmopolitan citizenship and its discontents. We will take examples from Europe, the US as well South Africa, Japan, Brazil and India. We discuss issues as slavery and citizenship, birth right lottery, paper citizens, multiple passports and loyalties. Global migration has forced us to re-think the construction of the nation state. States increasingly compete with each other for international prestige and economic development. They wish to attract skilled laborers (including sportsmen and women and scientist) and investors or rich consumers. In addition, however, especially western welfare states wish to restrict migration from poor countries to protect the welfare levels of its citizens. Cosmopolitism may be seen as an asset, a challenge and a burden.
Leerdoelen
Students study three different perspectives on migration and citizenship; (1) Egalitarian liberalism, (2) Communitarian and (3) libertarian perspectives. With these three perspectives in mind they learn how to debate national self-determination, migration and multiculturalism and global distributive justice and migration. By the end of the course they are able to write a critical review of an academic monograph on migration, citizenship and identity.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud Europe in the World is a Master course for students in the International Public Management and Policy program. This course aims at developing students’ understanding of the activities of the European Union in the world. By the end of the course, the students will be able to understand and theoretically explain the EU’s external action. They will appreciate the difficulties of EU’s foreign action, and will be able to critically appraise the EU’s foreign policy. Students will have improved soft and transferrable skills.
 
Students in this course will be expected to have covered the basics of international relations theory. This can be done by having passed the course Global Governance in the IMP program, or an alternative program elsewhere (recognized at the discretion of the instructor).
  Leerdoelen By the end of the class, the students will be able to
  • Illustrate and explain areas of EU’s activity in the world
  • Compare different means of EU’s foreign affairs activity
  • Contrast EU’s approaches in different areas of foreign policy
  • Critically evaluate EU’s efficiency in global governance and foreign affairs

lecturers: ['dr. CWA van Wijnbergen', 'dr. T Ertuna Lagrand, LL.M', 'PK Livaha, LLM']
text:
Inhoud The end of WWII engendered the world’s most far-reaching experiment in international cooperation between sovereign nation states.  European countries embarked on a process of integration which has brought them peace, stability and prosperity. Yet, on the European Union’s 60th anniversary, celebrations are noticeably muted with citizens’ support for European integration flagging.  How come?
 
This course explores the historical, political, and economic background to European integration.  It will elucidate the EU’s unique origins, institutions and competences, and debate its place in the world and its relationship to member states.  The course sets out to provide the theoretical foundations to critically discuss questions on EU governance, key policy areas, crises and reforms, and to contemplate the EU’s future. Leerdoelen After completing the course, you should be able to:
  • Understand the origins and evolution of European integration;
  • Assess the political and economic motives of member states to join the European Union;
  • Explain the necessary conditions for the transition from constitutional right to international right, as stated by Immanuel Kant in Toward Perpetual Peace (1795), and use this to evaluate the feasibility of the idea of a politically integrated Europe;
  • Analyze and reproduce the arguments of Hegel against Kant's idea of global/European perpetual peace;
  • Evaluate theories on European integration;
  • Understand the institutional structure and the legal system of the EU, as well as its competences and the limitations thereof;
  • Understand the economics behind monetary integration and assess the recent crisis in the Eurozone and potential solutions;
  • Apply concepts of sovereignty to the EU in keeping with the latter's political form;
  • Examine the European Union’s relations with the outside world;
  • Articulate an informed view about current debates on the EU.

course_title: European Law: Justice and Home Affairs
lecturers: ['dr. F Coman Kund', 'N Pouls, LL.M', 'prof.dr. R Repasi', 'TP Poot, LL.M']
['dr. E Themeli, LL.M', 'dr. EA Ontanu', 'prof.mr.dr. XE Kramer']
text:
Inhoud
The globalisation of trade has led to an increase of transnational relations and situations that can require the application of different sets of rules in a cross-border context. For instance, an English company concludes a sales contract with a French company; an agent settled in the Netherlands represents a United States-based company in several European countries; a German consumer buys goods from a Swiss company over the internet; a semi-finished product manufactured in Spain causes damages in further production chain in Poland.
International legal practice is increasingly confronted with questions of private international (including procedural) law. The substantial diversity of jurisdiction and procedure rules, and the lack of harmonisation may increase legal uncertainty and ineffective adjudication.
This course focuses on the general concepts of private international law and the application of private international law. Particular attention is given to private international law at European Union level and to related international conventions. Where relevant, attention will be paid to comparative aspects, for example common law jurisdiction vs. civil law jurisdiction.
The instruments to be discussed include those dealing with international jurisdiction, recognition and enforcement, evidence, service of documents, harmonised European procedures (i.e. European Order for Payment, European Small Claims, European Account Preservation Order), insolvency, and the applicable law to (commercial) contracts and torts.
Leerdoelen
A student who has successfully completed this course should:
  • identify the sources of private international law;
  • assess the importance and problems of harmonisation of private international law at European level, and to some extent at international level;
  • understand general concepts of international jurisdiction, including lis pendens and forum non conveniens, forum shopping, choice of forum, jurisdiction in personam, and jurisdiction in rem;
  • understand the concepts of recognition and enforcement, including reciprocity, exequatur, free movement of judgments, and grounds of refusal;
  • understand general concepts and principles of conflicts of laws, including party autonomy, connecting factors, public policy, and overriding mandatory rules;
  • compare the process of service of documents under the European Service Regulation and the Hague Service Convention, and apply the European Service Regulation;
  • compare the process of obtaining evidence under the European Evidence Regulation and the Hague Evidence Convention, and apply the European Evidence Regulation;
  • assess the position of weaker parties in European Private International Law;
  • have a basic understanding of the European uniform procedures;
  • apply European jurisdiction rules to concrete civil and commercial matters;
  • determine how a concrete judgment regarding civil and commercial matters given in a Member State can be recognised and enforced in another Member State;
  • determine on the basis of European legislation in a concrete case which law applies to commercial or civil relationship or claim;
  • describe the interplay between the UN Convention of International Sales of Goods and Rome I Regulation;
  • understand the concept of centre of main interest (COMI), determine jurisdiction and the applicable law in insolvency proceedings, the recognition and enforcement of opening of insolvency proceedings;
  • analyse the relationship between European Private International Law and third states.

Inhoud
The course offers and introduction to the European Union Law. It provides insights into: a) the evolution of the European Union and the sources of EU law; b) EU institutions; c) the decision making process of the EU; d) the relationship between EU law and the legal systems of the EU Member States; e) the internal market All subjects within the course are approached from a point of view which enables the students to grasp the evolution of European integration. The course intends to embed law related questions into the wider political, social and economic EU-context, without leaving out the developments and discussions as to the future of the European Union.
 
Leerdoelen
On completion of this course, the student will be able to:
  • Understand the institutional structure and the legal system of the EU, as well as its competences and the limitations thereof,
  • Understand the foundations of EU Single Market Law, EU Competition Law, EU Citizenship, principle of Equal Treatment and Human Rights within the EU, and EU Migration Law,
  • Distinguish the legal issues embedded in news items, literature etc.
  • Point to the legal and institutional ways of solving basic legal problems/cases

lecturers: ['dr. M Glavina', 'I Dervic, LLM', 'mr. MK Shahid', 'mr. R Notenboom', 'mr. RM Klein Entink', 'N Pouls, LL.M', 'prof.dr. R Repasi']
text:
Inhoud In recent decades, there has been a rapidly increasing influence of European Union law on more and more areas of national law. Because of this development, people often speak of the progressive 'Europeanization' of different parts of the national legal systems of the Member States of the EU. Virtually all jurisdictions are affected by EU law, which means that the developments in EU law have a major impact not only on the functioning of the national legal jurisdiction and judicial organization, but also on the daily lives of ordinary citizens.
 
Building on the students’ existing knowledge about the basic principles of EU law and the institutional framework of the EU, the second-year course ‘European Union Law’ goes beyond the basics of the EU’s construct. In particular, the course focuses on the substantive law of the EU. Students will gain an understanding of the internal market and the four fundamental freedoms, the system of legal protection in the EU, EU competition law, as well as Brexit.
 
  Leerdoelen Upon completion of this course, students will not only be able to understand the foundations and background of EU law, but will also be able to find, understand, analyze, interpret, critique, and apply the (primary and secondary) rules on legal protection, the four freedoms of the internal market, and EU competition law in the EU to case studies. In addition, student will also be able to find, analyze and apply the relevant case law of the ECJ to a case study.

lecturers: ['dr. M Glavina', 'I Dervic, LLM', 'mr. MK Shahid', 'mr. R Notenboom', 'mr. RM Klein Entink', 'N Pouls, LL.M', 'prof.dr. R Repasi']

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud This course analyses the European Union as a political system. Rather than just describing the various political actors and formal and informal decision-making procedures, the course aims at a higher level of understanding by applying theories based on institutional rational choice to the various facets of the EU. The basic idea is that political outcomes are the result of actor preferences and institutions (as rules of the game). Equipped with this approach we will analyse among other things, executive politics, legislative politics, judicial politics, interest group politics, and policy making in a variety of areas. Leerdoelen After completion of this course, students are able to:
  • describe the composition, internal structure and formal decision-making role of EU actors such as the European Commission and the European Parliament;
  • describe the main problems and dynamics of EU policy-making concerning regulatory policies, expenditure policies, and interior policies;
  • define central concepts of rational choice-informed political science theories, such as principal agent theories and coalition-formation theory and to describe the assumptions and hypotheses of these theories;
  • apply rational-choice informed political science theories to executive politics, legislative politics, judicial politics, interest groups politics, regulatory policies, expenditure policies and interior policies;
  • synthesize information about changes in the actor's environment, its effects of actor preferences and changing institutions to predict policy change;
  • effectively communicate orally about case study findings.
Belangrijk om te weten This course is part of the selective Master in International Public Management and Public Policy (IMP) and also an elective for students from other Master programmes in Public Administration. Please notice that the eligibility criteria for the IMP programme are higher than for the Dutch Master programmes, both in terms of English proficiency (which is higher than the level achieved in Dutch secondary schools) and in terms of grades obtained in the Bachelor programme. This course is geared towards this higher level. Students from other programmes are strongly recommended to take note of these admission criteria for the IMP Master, see www.imp.eur.nl

lecturers: ['dr. RP van den Dool', 'prof.dr. P Kavelaars']
text:
Inhoud
Een van de redenen voor de Europese toenadering en de totstandkoming van het Verdrag betreffende (de werking van) de Europese Unie is het streven van de lidstaten om te komen tot een interne, markt zonder fiscale belemmeringen, beperkingen of distorsies. Hierdoor moeten onder andere ondernemingen in staat worden gesteld om zich beter aan te passen aan de interne markt, hun productiviteit te vergroten en hun concurrentiepositie op de internationale markt te versterken. Tijdens dit vak wordt geanalyseerd hoe lidstaten deze economische voorspoed kunnen bereiken zonder oneerlijke fiscale concurrentie. Naast de positieve Europese integratie - de regelgeving - wordt ruimschoots aandacht besteed aan de negatieve integratie, de arresten die door het Hof van Justitie worden gewezen.

Het vak bevat o.a. de volgende onderwerpen:
  • Begrippenapparaat + interpretatiemethoden
  • Beginselen van het Europees recht
  • Bespreking van de verkeersvrijheden in het VwEU
  • Staatssteun in het VwEU
  • Formeelrechtelijke aspecten van het EU-recht
  • Fiscale richtlijnen van de EU
  • Wisselwerking tussen EU-recht en nationaal fiscaal recht
     
Leerdoelen
  • Inzicht verwerven in de algemene beginselen van het EU belastingrecht en in het bijzonder het beslisschema van het Hof van Justitie.
  • De vaardigheid ontwikkelen om aan de hand van het EU belastingrecht nationaalrechtelijke belastingregels te toetsen op hun aanvaardbaarheid.
  • Het kritische vermogen ontwikkelen om op zelfstandige wijze naar nationaalrechtelijke belastingregels te kijken.

lecturers: ['EJA Franssen', 'mr. A Zwanenburg', 'mr. RG van Hemert', 'mr.drs. JR Vos', 'N van Toor, LLM', 'prof.mr.dr. JH Even']
text:
Inhoud De doorwerking van het internationale recht op het Nederlandse arbeidsrechtelijke rechtssysteem zal worden besproken. Daarnaast maakt met name het Europees recht het relatief eenvoudig dat een werknemer vanuit Nederland elders in de EU te werk wordt gesteld en vice versa. De regels die hierbij gelden en de problemen die hierdoor kunnen ontstaan worden besproken. Vraagstukken die worden behandeld zijn onder meer: welke fundamentele vrijheden staan de werkgever en de werknemer ter beschikking, hoe verhouden deze vrijheden zich met arbeidsrechtelijke beginselen en rechten, welk recht is van toepassing op de internationale arbeidsovereenkomst en welke rechter is bevoegd bij een geschil. Naast deze meer individuele vraagstukken wordt ook ingegaan op de rol en de rechten van de (Europese) sociale partners binnen de Europese sociale dialoog. Leerdoelen
  1. De student kan de invloed en doorwerking van Europees en internationaal (sociaal verzekerings)recht in het Nederlandse arbeidsrecht toepassen op een concrete casus.
  2. De student kan beoordelen welke rechter in een internationaal arbeidsgeschil bevoegd is en welk recht van toepassing is.
  3. De student kan beoordelen wanneer sprake is van internationale detachering, wat de gevolgen daarvan zijn en welke beperkingen wel en niet kunnen worden opgelegd aan internationale dienstverleners.
  4. De student kan de wijze waarop Europese vrijheden doorwerken in een concrete casus beoordelen en identificeren hoe en waar zich spanningen voordoen tussen deze vrijheden en het (nationale) arbeidsrecht.
  5. De student kan de ontwikkelingen in de Europese en internationale context schetsen en vanuit die context ontwikkelingen beoordelen.
  6. De student kan beoordelen en beargumenteren onder welke voorwaarden een beroep op de Wmo 2015 kan worden gedaan en op welke voorzieningen aanspraak kan worden gemaakt.
  7. De student kan reflecteren op, en een beargumenteerd standpunt innemen ten aanzien van, de voorgeschreven literatuur en ten aanzien van vraagstukken met betrekking tot de voorgeschreven bijzondere arbeidsverhouding(en).

course_title: Evaluation of Development Policy, Programmes and Projects
lecturers: ['dr. BA Demena', 'dr. GM Gomez', 'dr. M Faling', 'dr. S Gyamfi Afrifa']

text:
Inhoud Evolution is such a crucial discipline of modern biology that, in 1973, evolutionary biologist Theodosius Dobzhansky wrote: "nothing in biology makes sense except in the light of evolution". In this course, a comprehensive introduction to the fascination field of evolutionary biology will be presented. Topics that will be covered include: the origin of abiotic and cellular life, the theory of evolution by natural selection (descent with modification), concepts of fitness and adaptation, the genetic and developmental basis of evolutionary change, micro- and macroevolution, speciation and extinction, elementary population genetics, palaeontology, and human evolution.
  Leerdoelen After completing this course, you will have a basic knowledge of:
  • the theory of evolution by natural selection (descent with modification);
  • the concepts of fitness and adaptation;
  • the genetic and developmental basis of evolutionary change;
  • the origin of abiotic and cellular life;
  • micro- and macroevolution;
  • speciation and extinction;
  • population genetics;
  • palaeontology;
  • human evolution.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud As you can see in the overview that would amount to:

1. 15 ECTS minimum should be related to the program History (we also approve courses from programmes like: Political Science, International Relations, Journalism etcetera). 
 2. 15 ECTS maximum non-study related courses. These courses will replace your minor.
You are free to choose your courses, as long as:
- The partner university approves (for some courses you will need prerequisite knowledge and some courses are not open to exchange students)
- The course succeeds the first year of the BA
- The course is not part of the MA or PHD program
- The course is not too practical 
Plus you can do a language course for 6 ECTS maximum.

3. In general, you can only take courses that have been approved by the Examination Board of the ESHCC.



Eligibility
The exchange program is open for bachelor students only. Plus, it is only possible to go abroad during the first semester (term 1 and 2) of the BA-3. 
You will have to meet the following conditions:
1. Average grade of 6.5. We will check the grade point average up to term 1 of BA-2* 
Please note: Some universities outside Europe require an average of 7 for the BA-1 and BA-2. If you don't meet this criteria, they will have the right to deny your application.
More information can be found on the pages of the partner universities.
2. At the time of registration (1 December 2018) students are required to:
a. Have completed all courses of BA-1*
b. Have completed all courses of BA-2, term 1**

*In case you have Personal Circumstances for the courses of BA-1
You are still allowed to register for the exchange program. If you fail to finish BA-1 in the second year, the International Office will have to withdraw your registration for the exchange program.
** In case you have a re-sit exam for a course Term 1 or 2 of the BA-2:
Then you can still register for the exchange program. But it means that other students who meet the criteria, will get priority. Consequently it can happen that you will not be selected for the partner university of your first choice. But we will do our best to select you for your 2nd, 3rd or 4th choice. 
If you fail the re-sit examof a course of term 1 and 2 of BA-2 and you cannot compensate it with another course, you can still go on exchange. However, please keep in mind that you will have to do the courses you have failed all over again in your fourth year.
3. If you choose a partner university that does not offer (a sufficient number of) English taught courses, you are required to submit proof of their proficiency in the language of the foreign exchange institution (at B2 level or higher).
Application
Application is no longer possible for the exchange period of  2018-2019. 
The registration period for 2019-2020 starts from 1 October until 1 December 2018.
See the Canvas page (CC6000) for more information and application form. Leerdoelen The Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication encourages students to go abroad during the first semester (term 1 and 2) of the BA-3.

course_title: Executive Programme Commodity Trade and Supply Networks

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud Digital media have influenced empirical research. Using smart devices and experience sampling techniques we can capture “life as it is lived”.  Instead of taking a photo by a one-time questionnaire, we use repetitive measurements taking within person fluctuations into account. We try to meaningfully interpret the fluctuations over the measurement points (days, moments…). This implies that retrospective bias is reduced, but also that we can answer a different kind of research questions. Leerdoelen At the end of this course, the student…
  1. knows what experience sampling is and can reflect on potential advantages and side backs;
  2. understands what type of research questions can be answered by ESM studies;
  3. is capable to think of possible research questions and research designs in ESM;
  4. is able to analyze the results of an ESM study;
  5. is able to report the results in the format of an extensive abstract or poster presentation.
Belangrijk om te weten Practical meetings are in English

Inhoud Experiments are an increasingly important tool in economics. They are, for instance, used to understand why financial investors spend too little on stocks, why consumers are reluctant to change brands, and in the analysis of labor market decisions. This course deals with the following questions:
  • Why are experiments such a powerful tool to discover the causal effect of a treatment?
  • What exactly are economic experiments?
  • Why should incentives be given in economic experiments work? Do they always work?
  • How can utility be measured with experiments?
  • What kind of statistical analyses are needed for experimental data?
  • What is the optimal sample size to discover the causal effect of interest?
  • Are results found in the laboratory predictive of behavior in the real world?
  • How can we test lab-field generalizability by means of field experiments?
Leerdoelen
  • Understand why randomization is crucial to gather causal inferences of behaviour.
  • Understand why economists use incentives in experiments.
  • Understand why non-parametric tests are needed to analyze data gathered in experiments.
  • Understand why it is sometimes important, and sometimes not important that results from laboratory experiments generalize to other 'real world' settings.
  • Know how many indepedent observations one can get out of an experiment.
  • Apply different non-parametric statistical tests.
  • Be able to apply some power calculations.
  • Be able to come up with an experimental design and derive hypotheses.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar This year, the lectures will be posted online in a video, each Monday at 8.00 hours.
The time slot for the scheduled lectures will be used for an online session. In this session, experimental designs of papers will be discussed in break out rooms.
Students have to work on several questions, that are then discussed by the teacher.

Inhoud
Course description:
Experimental Economics studies economic behavior in a controlled, laboratory or field environment. This course teaches the student how to design an experiment aimed at answering a self-developed research question. In addition, it gives an overview of recent trends in Experimental Economics. The course will focus on a set of recent experimental papers and on experimental designs developed by the students. Each student is expected to actively participate in class by discussing selected papers and to develop and present his or her own experimental design.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud The course is built on three pillars: Testing research ideas with clean and rigorous experimental designs, applying the appropriate statistical techniques necessary to analyse these designs, and properly interpreting the implications of the observed results in light of the study design and research question. Topics include: causal inference, experimental designs (factorial designs, within- vs. between-subject designs, mixed designs), validity of designs (internal, external, criterion-related, and construct validities), experimental caveats (demand characteristics, confounds, experimenter expectancy, checks, measurement order, control variables), applying statistics to experimental designs (e.g., simple effects, simple slopes, contrasts, outliers, statistical power, simple mediation, moderated mediation, mediated moderation), data visualization, and scientific integrity (researcher degrees of freedom, questionable research practices, transparency, p-hacking) 
We will examine these topics from the perspective of an applied behavioural researcher (with examples from fields such as marketing, organizational behaviour, economics, and psychology). Our focus is thus very practical—to help you overcome any issues that might arise in designing and conducting your experiment, analysing your data, writing up your results, and getting your paper published. An intermediate proficiency in a programming language (preferably R) is strongly encouraged for this class.
As in previous years, we may be able to collect data in the Erasmus Behavioural Lab. Leerdoelen The goal of this course is to learn how to design, analyse, and interpret field and laboratory experiments.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Contents, course description
Course content is organized into eight modules covering the following topics:

  • Introduction to Causal Inference—Overview of the course, motivating questions about causes and effects, and the challenges of measuring effects from data
  • Potential Outcomes Model—A framework for measuring causal effects from observational data or experiments that begins with what you want to measure and works backward from that
  • Graphical Models—Another framework for measuring causal effects from observational data or experiments that begins with what you are willing to assume about the world (and what you can measure) and works forward from that
  • Randomized Experiments and Hypothesis Tests—Sampling from a population and random assignment to different treatments are powerful tools for measuring causal effects. Hypothesis tests provide a way to quantify how likely our results are due to these sources of randomness.
  • Confounders—The world is messy. Variables that are correlated with causes and effects can help or hinder our ability to measure causal effects
  • Matching and Regression Estimators—Introduction to typical methods for estimating causal effects
  • Heterogeneity—There is an important difference between an average causal effect across a group of people, and the individual causal effects on any of those people.
  • Challenges to Causal Inference—If we send an email to a customer, they may or may not use that coupon on their next purchase. Here we discuss tools for inference when people don’t do what we expect them to do.

Each module has the following structure:

  • Prior to class, you will read the assigned material.
  • After reading the material, and before class, you will take a quiz (via Canvas) to test your comprehension of the material. You can refer to the reading when you take the quiz.
  • During class, we will review material covered by the assigned reading, focusing on what was less clear to most students. We will work through examples, both as a class and in small groups.
  • After class, your will be able to apply what you’ve learned while completing problem sets during the course, and while working on an integrative assignment due at the end of the course.
     
Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
•    Understand and differentiate between statistical concepts such as correlation, conditional independence, and likelihood; and causal concepts such as randomization, confounding, and exogeneity
•    Express causal relationships among data using Pearl’s graphical framework, and counterfactual quantities of interest using Rubin’s potential outcomes framework
•    Derive conditions under which causal relationships can be estimated from data
•    Design experiments to measure causal effects
•    Simulate outcomes corresponding with an assumed causal model, and use these simulated outcomes to predict the precision of empirical estimates of causal effects
•    Think critically about the ethical consequences of performing randomized experiments, and of making causal claims

text:
Inhoud The FAECTOR Consultancy Project is a 10-week project organised by FAECTOR for econometrics and BSc2 students. The purpose of this project is to give students practical experience and challenge their knowledge and skills. It does so by offering a practical application of their econometric knowledge in the consultancy field. An additional aim of the project is to offer affordable data consultancy to non-profits and (semi-)governmental institutions, who normally cannot afford professional consultancy. This way, the project has an impact on the
real world while still providing valuable education to students. Leerdoelen In this course you gain experience in applying techniques from Econometrics and Operations Research in a consultancy environment.




  Extra The program is extra-curriculair and the students will receive a notification on their diploma and a separate certificate.

Inhoud The FAECTOR Excellence Programme is a programme designed for the highly motivated Econometrie/Econometrics/BSc2 students. The goal of the programme is to give Bachelor students (pre-Master, second year or higher) the opportunity to see different sides of an econometric theme. This programme is organised in cooperation with the Erasmus School of Economics. Last year's theme was Crypto Currencies and Block Chain. This year's theme will be announced in November/December. During this programme you will attend several lectures within this theme. Besides your academic knowledge you get the opportunity to develop your writing skills by writing small papers and soft skills with workshops like a presentation and debating workshop. You will also meet several companies during the programme. Finally, If you finish this programme successfully, you will receive 4 extracurricular ECTS and a certificate signed by the dean of Erasmus School of Economics. The FAECTOR Excellence Programme starts in January and ends in June. There will be a lecture, inhouse day or workshop once every week in block 3, 4 and 5 (excluding week 8 of each block). At the end of the Programme there will be a ceremony where you will present one of your written papers to show your fellow students and your family what you have done during this programme. Here you will also get your certificate. Leerdoelen You obtain insight of the role that econometrics plays in a topical issue from different perspectives.




  Extra The program is extra-curriculair and the students will receive a notification on their diploma and a separate certificate.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['A Jansen', 'dr. SJH Giesbers', 'MH van den Doel']

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
The Netherlands is well known for its expertise in distribution operations. Many American and Asian multinational companies have established their European logistics centre in the Netherlands, and it is the home base of many logistics service providers and operations. The logistics sector has a big impact on the Dutch economy. Warehousing and distribution are core businesses for many large and smaller firms. While most other courses in the SCM master focus primarily on external logistics and strategic issues, this course focuses on intra logistics (or facility logistics): process design and execution; operations, particularly those within facilities. External and intralogistics are strongly related and interdependent. We will address such questions as: what is the impact of a company’s physical distribution structure on the intra logistics system, and vice versa? What storage systems should be used under which circumstances, what handling systems, what is the best layout, which information systems are appropriate, and what is the resulting performance? Besides matters of system choice, operational storage and order picking strategies are also discussed.

During the course, a number of case-based assignments will be carried out. You may have to present your solutions in class.

The course addresses several skills. These include presentations, consultancy (you have to defend solutions to your peers), data-mining with a database tool, design, and analysis of company-internal operations.
  Leerdoelen
Learning objectives
The aim of the course is to:
  • Develop insight and elementary design skills in material handling and facility (particularly warehouse and transhipment) operations management.
  • Develop analytical skills in regards to logistics operations. Tools will be provided to enable you to structure, analyse and master the issues at hand.

Inhoud Het familie(vermogens)recht begeleidt de mens als het ware in juridisch opzicht van de wieg tot het graf (en eigenlijk ook, gelet op art. 1:2 BW, in de periode vóór de geboorte en, gelet op de betekenis van het erfrecht, over het graf heen, dus in de periode na het overlijden). Werkelijk iedereen krijgt gedurende zijn leven met dit zo belangrijke rechtsgebied te maken. Het spreekt iedereen aan. Tot het vakgebied behoren het familierecht in enge zin (personen- en familierecht) en het familievermogensrecht (relatievermogensrecht en erfrecht). Vandaar de overkoepelende naam voor dit vak, waarin de drie deelgebieden tot uitdrukking komen: familie(vermogens)recht.
Het eerste deel van het vak, het familierecht in enge zin of personen- en familierecht, vindt men in Boek 1 van het Burgerlijk Wetboek en in belangrijke verdragen, zoals het EVRM en de daarbij behorende Protocollen (‘family life’/‘vie familiale’), het IVBPR en het IVRK. Het rechtsgebied omvat regelingen met betrekking tot de juridische aspecten van het persoonlijk leven, zoals bloed- en aanverwantschap, naam, woonplaats, burgerlijke stand, huwelijk, geregistreerd partnerschap, (echt)scheiding, afstamming (familierechtelijke betrekking), adoptie, gezag over en omgang met minderjarigen, curatele, meerderjarigenbewind, mentorschap, afwezigheid en vermissing.
Het tweede deel van het vak, het relatievermogensrecht als onderdeel van het familievermogensrecht, is grotendeels in Boek 1 van het Burgerlijk Wetboek opgenomen. Relatievermogensrecht is de overkoepelende term voor huwelijksvermogensrecht, partnerschapsvermogensrecht en samenlevingsvermogensrecht.  Het huwelijksvermogensrecht regelt de vermogensrechtelijke gevolgen van het huwelijk, waaronder begrepen rechten en verplichtingen van echtgenoten, de wettelijke gemeenschap van goederen en huwelijkse voorwaarden. Ook wordt aandacht besteed aan de vermogensrechtelijke gevolgen van de echtscheiding, waaronder begrepen pensioenverevening, alimentatie en de verdeling van de ontbonden huwelijksgemeenschap of de afwikkeling van verrekenbedingen in huwelijkse voorwaarden. Het partnerschapsvermogensrecht regelt de vermogensrechtelijke gevolgen van het geregistreerd partnerschap analoog aan die van het huwelijk. In plaats van ‘echtscheiding’ spreekt men bij het geregistreerd partnerschap over ‘beëindiging met wederzijds goedvinden’ (buiten rechte) of ‘ontbinding’ (in rechte). Bovendien komt de rechtspositie van samenwoners zonder huwelijk of geregistreerd partnerschap (informele relatie) aan de orde, zowel tijdens de periode van samenwoning als na verbreking van de samenleving (feitelijke scheiding). Dit samenlevingsvermogensrecht is gedeeltelijk in Boek 3 van het Burgerlijk Wetboek geregeld, maar alleen voor zover er sprake is van een eenvoudige gemeenschap in de zin van afdeling 3.7.1 BW. 
Het derde deel van het vak ten slotte, het erfrecht als onderdeel van het familievermogensrecht, vindt men in Boek 4 van het Burgerlijk Wetboek. Het erfrecht regelt de vermogensrechtelijke gevolgen van de overgang van het vermogen van de erflater op diens erfgenamen. Centraal staan het versterferfrecht of ab intestaat erfrecht, d.w.z. het erfrecht dat geldt als er geen uiterste wilsbeschikkingen zijn gemaakt, het testamentair erfrecht, in het bijzonder de legitieme portie, de zogenaamde andere wettelijke rechten en de verdeling van de nalatenschap.
Uitgangspunt bij de behandeling van de stof tijdens de hoorcolleges zal zijn dat de kennis, opgedaan in het eerste studiejaar (inleiding privaatrecht) en in het tweede studiejaar (verbintenissenrecht, alsmede goederen- en insolventierecht), dus globaal gezegd: de kennis van het algemene vermogensrecht, nog paraat aanwezig is. Is uw kennis wat weggezakt, fris een en ander dan vóór de aanvang van de hoorcolleges weer even op. Zie ook de hierboven vermelde toelatingseisen. Leerdoelen Met dit vak wordt beoogd de student vertrouwd te maken met het huidige positieve familie(vermogens)recht en de rechtspraktijk in familie(vermogens)rechtelijke zaken, alsmede met de actuele ontwikkelingen op het gebied van wetgeving en rechtspraak. De bedoeling van dit vak is het verschaffen van kennis van en inzicht in het recht met betrekking tot de hieronder onder ‘Inhoud’ genoemde drie deelgebieden en de verschillende onderdelen daarvan. Wie met goed gevolg het vak afsluit, is in staat om casusposities die zijn gerelateerd aan het personen- en familierecht, het relatievermogensrecht en het erfrecht, te analyseren, te interpreteren en op te lossen, waarbij de drie verschillende deelgebieden van het vak geïntegreerd aan de orde komen.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. BE French', 'dr. RM Verweij', 'prof.dr. PA Dykstra']
text:
Inhoud Families are a key link between macro-level processes (political, cultural, and economic shifts) and individual outcomes such as socioeconomic and health status in later life. Many of the decisions that people might perceive as fundamentally personal and individual (the kind of job taken or whether to work at all, whether to become a parent or not, which country to live in) are shaped by the interaction between our families and broader social, cultural, and institutional conditions.

In this course, students will learn about the links between families and social inequalities. We will not only look at social class as dimension of social inequality, but also focus on differences by ethnicity, race, sexuality and gender. Students will gain insights into key theoretical and methodological approaches to the study of families and social inequalities. Attention will be paid to interactions between micro- and macro-levels of analysis; e.g. how markets (e.g. the precariousness of jobs), states (e.g. social policies and national laws) and political, cultural and economic shifts structure family members’ life courses and well-being outcomes, thereby reducing, maintaining or strengthening social inequalities at large.

The course is theory-based and empirical, and thus questions whether claims based on theory are supported by empirical evidence. It also seeks explanations for empirical phenomena. Moreover, tutorials will use empirical evidence in debates. Leerdoelen After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
  1. Understand the key theoretical and methodological approaches to the study of families and social inequalities;
  2. Illustrate how social inequalities arise within and between families;
  3. Indicate how changes at the macro level context (e.g. policies, cultural climate, economic circumstances) influence family relations and in turn social inequalities;
 
After successful completion of this course, students will also have developed the following skills:
  1. Understand and evaluate research and link this to trends and associations observed in data sources;
  2. Build arguments and assess evidence in a clear and effective manner in oral presentations and written text;
  3. Comment in a constructive way on other students’ work.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud This course aims to provide to an in-depth understanding of past and recent developments in the fashion media. Students will explore the shift from printed media to today’s online media platforms and globalized communication networks, as well as changes affecting advertisement and marketing and the use of various fashion communication technologies and outlets. Special attention will be paid to the impact of globalization on the media coverage (formats, content, discourses) given to fashion and the ways in which various media outlets influence processes of reputation building, consecration and valorisation in the fashion world.
  Leerdoelen Define and understand the importance of media in the development of Fashion through the 20th and 21st Centuries. Be able to explain how different media have represented changes in the Fashion market and how the market itself is configured differently in an international, online media environment. Reflect on the contents of fashion media, its influence to the market and makers, and its’ possible futures.

course_title: Feminist Perspectives on Gender and Development
lecturers: ['dr. NYT Shehada', 'dr. S Heumann', 'dr. S Mullassery Sathiamma']

text:
Inhoud
This course introduces students to the field of feminist philosophy through key texts by some of the most prominent figures in the field, such as Simone de Beauvoir, Judith Butler, Audre Lorde, Donna Haraway and Luce Irigaray. Through the analysis of these texts, we will engage with a genealogy of feminist philosophy and explore one of its most contested sites of debate: the body.
 
We will start by critically assessing mainstream canonical philosophy, which has relied on a hierarchically charged binary opposition between mind and body that also correlates with the opposition between masculinity and femininity.  The course will examine how such binary thinking relates to structural (gender) inequalities, and how this has elevated the theorizing of the body in critical feminist thought. By unpacking different feminist positions regarding the themes of embodiment and binaries, students will develop an understanding of key traditions within the field of feminist philosophy, including sexual difference theory, gender performativity, feminist phenomenology and feminist new materialisms.
Leerdoelen
After completing this course, you will
  • Have a basic understanding of key texts within the field of feminist philosophy of the body.
  • Have a basic understanding of key re-conceptualisations of the body within feminist philosophy.
  • Have a basic understanding of key thinkers in feminist philosophy such as Lloyd, de Beauvoir, Irigaray, Haraway, Butler, Young and hooks. 
  • Be able to describe and explain the problematic relation between feminism, philosophy and the body.
  • Be able to describe and explain how the rational subject has typically been constructed against the natural realm and what this entails.
  • Be able to describe and explain what is at stake politically, ethically and epistemologically in rethinking the body in feminist theory.
  • Have a basic understanding of feminist stakes in addressing, and sometimes going beyond, binary thinking.

Inhoud

The last course of the minor will be dedicated to two Welcome Back sessions with all students and internship supervisors, where students will present their work and will reflect on their experiences in the field.


  Leerdoelen

After the course students are able to:

  • Evaluate realistically the potential and limitations of their achievements in the field;

  • Reflect on their own contribution to solving a specific problem of frugal innovation.

Inhoud After this course students are able to:
  • Get a realistic overview of their tasks and assignments during the internship
  • Plan their activities during the internship
  • Reflect on safety and cultural issues in their host country that relate to their internship
Leerdoelen

The bootcamp is a stepping stone towards a more precise description of the field assignment. During the Field Assignment Preparation course you will work further on this description and work toward a final field assignment plan that has been discussed with and has the approval of the field assignment provider(s) and supervisor(s). In addition, students will get further acquainted with the country of destination and the local context, its history and culture, and the hosts that have provided for the field assignment. Also a Safety & Health session and sessions on intercultural communication and inculturation are part of this course. During working groups and individual meetings, students will be guided by their field assignment supervisor(s).

Inhoud Kwesties uit de methodologie van de economie, zoals de vragen hoe onrealistisch economische modellen mogen en moeten zijn en hoe we kunnen beoordelen hoe groot hun verklarende kracht is, en kwesties uit de ethiek van de economie, zoals de vraag naar het doel van economisch beleid, naar ongelijkheid, verdelende rechtvaardigheid en morele grenzen van de markt, worden in de hoorcolleges geïntroduceerd en toegelicht. In vijf werkgroepen worden ethische kwesties in het bedrijfsleven en in de markt besproken en geanalyseerd. Door actief met de materie bezig te zijn ontwikkelen studenten een sterker moreel besef en maken zij zich denkkaders eigen om tot een meer doordachte en evenwichtige eigen oordeelsvorming te komen.

  Leerdoelen Het doel van de cursus is om studenten vertrouwd te maken met elementaire concepten en ideeën uit de filosofie, en meer in het bijzonder uit de filosofie van de economie, die relevant zijn voor economie.



  Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Er zijn nu 5 (verplichte) i.p.v. voorheen 4 (optionele) werkgroepen (tutorials), om studenten beter te kunnen voorbereiden op het schrijven van het essay.
Verder is de inhoud van de hoorcolleges (en dus ook van het tentamen) iets vereenvoudigd, om die beter aan te laten sluiten op de voorkennis van B1 studenten.

Inhoud De colleges worden niet opgenomen.

Hoewel de retorica in sommige tijden een vast onderdeel vormde van het wijsgerig curriculum, bestaat er al sinds Plato ook een spanning tussen retorica en filosofie en is vaak getracht de banden tussen ethos, logos en pathos te verbreken en de retoriek uit de wijsbegeerte te verbannen. In dit practicum zal de theorie en geschiedenis van de retorica worden besproken en worden studenten geoefend in spreek- en discussievaardigheden.
  Leerdoelen Aan het eind van de cursus heeft de student zowel historisch en theoretisch inzicht in de relatie van de retorica tot de filosofie ontwikkeld, als praktische vaardigheid verworven om over wijsgerige onderwerpen in het openbaar te spreken en het eigen standpunt toe te lichten.

Inhoud Kwesties uit de methodologie van de economie, zoals de vragen hoe onrealistisch economische modellen mogen en moeten zijn en hoe we kunnen beoordelen hoe groot hun verklarende kracht is, en kwesties uit de ethiek van de economie, zoals de vraag naar het doel van economisch beleid, van ongelijkheid, verdelende rechtvaardigheid en morele grenzen van de markt, worden in de hoorcolleges geïntroduceerd en toegelicht. In vijf werkgroepen worden ethische kwesties in het bedrijfsleven en in de markt besproken en geanalyseerd. Door actief met de materie bezig te zijn ontwikkelen studenten een sterker moreel besef en maken zij zich denkkaders eigen om tot een meer doordachte en evenwichtige eigen oordeelsvorming te komen. Leerdoelen Het doel van de cursus is om studenten vertrouwd te maken met elementaire concepten en ideeën uit de filosofie die relevant zijn voor economie.
Meer in het bijzonder:
  • Studenten hebben basiskennis van de voornaamste perspectieven, ideeën en argumenteerwijzen in de filosofie van de economie.
  • Studenten hebben basiskennis van de voornaamste perspectieven, ideeën en argumenteerwijzen in de methodologie van de economie.
  • Studenten hebben basiskennis van de voornaamste perspectieven, ideeën en argumenteerwijzen in de vakgebieden waar economie en ethiek elkaar overlappen.
Extra We hebben dit jaar 5 werkgroepsbijeenkomsten (i.p.v. 4 vorig jaar). Hierdoor willen we studenten beter voorbereiden (door het aanleren van de benodigde vaardigheden) op het schrijven van het afsluitende filosofische essay en beogen we ook een betere afstemming te realiseren tussen de stof van de hoorcolleges en de stof van de werkgroepen.

Inhoud In het eerste jaar van de bachelor krijg je een introductie op academisch onderwijs. De focus ligt hier op studievaardigheden. Al tijdens de eerste bijeenkomst zal worden gezocht naar een goede balans tussen jouw verwachtingen en de eisen die de studie stelt. Ook zal aandacht worden besteed aan motivatie, attitude en het structureren van zelfstudie (voorbereiding op colleges en tentamens). Er zijn bijeenkomsten voorzien over ‘de ethiek van het lezen’, waarin verschillende genres teksten worden besproken en de daarbij passende houding van de lezer. Maar er worden ook bijeenkomsten gewijd aan het volgen van hoorcolleges, het gebruik van de UB, citeren, verwijzen en frauderen, en het schrijven van een samenvatting.

Aanvullend hierop wordt als onderdeel van deze introductie één college gegeven met als thema loopbaanoriëntatie. Het doel van dit college is om je kennis te laten maken met de loopbaanperspectieven en om (voor jezelf) expliciet te formuleren wat je uiteindelijk verwacht van de opleiding.

Ook wordt tijdens dit college verteld over de mogelijkheden om jezelf naast de opleiding te ontwikkelen. Hierbij gaat het om informatie over het Honoursprogramma, exchange, medezeggenschap, commissie of bestuur bij ERA en het lopen van stage.

  Leerdoelen Na het volgen van Filosofisch Atelier 1

1. Heb je een duidelijk beeld van wat er van je wordt verwacht tijdens de voltijd bachelor Filosofie als het gaat om de omgangsvormen en het studiereglement.
2. Kan je zelfstandig een filosofische tekst lezen, analyseren en samenvatten.
3. Ken je de regels wat betreft het schrijven van een academisch filosofische tekst.
4. Weet je welke hulpmiddelen en faciliteiten de universiteit biedt ter ondersteuning van je studie.
5. Weet je welke mogelijkheden er zijn om je in en naast je studie persoonlijk te ontwikkelen.
6. Heb je een onderbouwde visie op de loopbaankansen na de studie filosofie.

Inhoud In jaar 2 neem je deel aan vijf Filosofen aan het Werk (FAW) sessies waarin alumni vertellen over hun loopbaan en ervaringen. Daarnaast volg je een training van een loopbaanadviseur waar de focus zal liggen op het vergroten van zelfkennis en het maken van loopbaankeuzes.
Aanvullend maak je verschillende opdrachten. Denk bijvoorbeeld aan het maken van een eerste opzet voor de invulling van de minor/stage- en masterperiode.
  Leerdoelen Na het volgen van Filosofisch Atelier II 

1. Heb je inzicht in je eigen kwaliteiten en persoonlijkheidskenmerken.
2. Geef je jouw verdere studieloopbaan vorm met behulp van het inzicht in je eigen kwaliteiten en persoonlijkheidskenmerken.
3. Heb je inzicht in verschillende loopbaanperspectieven na de studie Filosofie.
4. Heb je een eerste idee over het onderwerp van je thesis.

Inhoud

In jaar 3 ga je verder met het portfolio en voer je een individueel gesprek met de loopbaanadviseur. In dit gesprek wordt er met je gesproken over jouw toekomstplannen. Je schrijft een reflectie op dit gesprek.

Tot slot neem je deel aan de Week van het Werk waarin verschillende workshops worden verzorgd, waaronder trainingen op het gebied van sollicitatievaardigheden.

Leerdoelen

Na het volgen van Filosofisch Atelier III 

1. Weet je hoe je jouw verdere (studie)loopbaan na de bachelor gaat vormgeven met behulp van een gesprek met de loopbaanadviseur.

2. Ken je de belangrijkste onderdelen die betrekking hebben op solliciteren.

3. Weet je of en hoe jij als filosoof zou kunnen en willen bijdragen aan actuele academische of maatschappelijke vraagstukken.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Course content, description
​
FinTech covers technology-enabled business model innovation in the financial services industry. FinTech is rapidly evolving across the globe and represents an existential challenge for major parts of the financial sector. These innovative technologies can disrupt existing industry structures and blur industry boundaries, facilitate disintermediation, radically change how firms create and deliver products and services, generate significant privacy, regulatory and law-enforcement challenges, offer new gateways for entrepreneurship, and create opportunities for inclusive growth.

In this course, we will provide an introductory overview of innovations that are central to FinTech. Specifically, these innovations include cryptocurrencies and blockchains, mobile money, robo-advising, crowdfunding, marketplace lending. We will also explore threats and opportunities that these technologies pose to incumbent firms and discuss the way that FinTech interacts with law enforcement and regulation issues. The approach adopted to address these themes is analytical. Furthermore, the course will feature a number of guest speakers from industry. Leerdoelen Learning Objectives

At the end of this course students will be able to:
»    Describe what FinTech is and why it emerged.
»    Explain both fundamentals and economics of the following FinTech: blockchains, cryptocurrencies, mobile money, robo-advising, crowdfunding, marketplace lending.
»    Analyze the potential and limitations of these FinTech (and their applications). 
»    Assess a FinTech business model.
»    Develop a new venture idea linked to blockchain.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Contents, course description

The financial sector has been increasingly disrupted by the use of technology. Moreover, recent regulations such as the EU PSD2 directive, have created an environment that further facilitates the use of technology, big data, and algorithms in financing applications. One can think about payment systems, Peer to Peer Lending, Crowdfunding, Crypto-currencies, Robo Advising, and High-Frequency Trading.  

The course consists of two parts that run in parallel. In the first part, we discuss the FinTech business models, their value propositions, their impact on traditional players in the financial sector, and their impact on market outcomes. 

In the second part of the course, we apply the knowledge gathered thus far in this course and the core courses by implementing a stylized version of one of these business models under the supervision of an instructor with ample real-life experience of doing so.
 

Leerdoelen Learning objectives

After completing this course, students will:

1.    Understand the potential role of technology in designing financial business models and the value created for various stakeholders
2.    Understand and be able to analyze the impact that new, technologically advanced players have on the incumbent financial sector
3.    Be able to formulate technology, data, and algorithm requirements corresponding to certain functions that financial markets fulfil
4.    Be able to write a business plan for a FinTech business model 
5.    Be able to implement and test a stylized version of a FinTech business model as a team and present the setup and performance in a clear and concise way

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['CP Koning, MSc', 'dr. A Mulder', 'dr. MBJ Schauten', 'dr. S van Kampen']
text:
Inhoud In dit vak staan drie vraagstukken centraal: het investerings-, het prijsvormings- en het beleggings- vraagstuk.

Het investeringsvraagstuk betreft de vraag hoe bedrijven het beste kunnen bepalen in welke projecten zij zouden moeten investeren indien waarde creatie centraal staat. Wij bespreken verschillende inves- teringsselectiemethoden die in de praktijk worden gebruikt waarbij de netto contante waarde methode centraal staat. Deze methode wordt namelijk beschouwd als het meest geschikte investeringsselectie- criterium indien maximalisatie van waarde wordt nagestreefd.

Het prijsvormingsvraagstuk betreft de verklaring van marktprijzen van vermogenstitels zoals aandelen en obligaties. Wij gaan in op de waardebepaling door de vermogensmarkt van aandelen maar ook op die van obligaties uitgegeven door ondernemingen en overheden. Vragen die gesteld worden zijn: Wat is de invloed van de te verwachte dividendbetalingen en het marktrisico op de prijs van het aandeel? Wat is de invloed van de termijnstructuur van de rentevoeten op de prijs van een obligatie? Hoe beïn- vloeden de couponbetalingen de prijs van een obligatie? Is het mogelijk om waarde te creëren door het dividend te verlagen en meer te investeren in groei? Wie heeft er voordeel bij een overname?

Het beleggingsvraagstuk wordt benaderd aan de hand van de portefeuilletheorie van Markowitz. Je maakt tevens kennis met het zogenaamde Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM). In de praktijk wordt het CAPM gebruikt bij het bepalen van disconteringsvoeten die nodig zijn bij toepassing van investe- ringsselectiemethoden.
  Leerdoelen

Leerdoelen

Na het volgen van dit vak is de student in staat tot:
  • Het analyseren en gebruik maken van financiële overzichten in relatie tot waarderingen en investeringsselectiemethoden;
  • Het toepassen en evalueren van verschillende investeringsselectiemethoden;
  • Het bepalen van de waarde van vermogenstitels zoals aandelen en obligaties;
  • Het uitleggen van de portefeuilletheorie en het toepassen van deze theorie ten einde porte- feuilles samen te stellen van vermogenstitels;
  • Het uitleggen van het CAPM en het toepassen van het model ten einde een vermogenskos- tenvoet vast te stellen;
  • Het uitleggen van de Efficiënte Markt Hypothese en het analyseren van de implicaties ervan.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['CP Koning, MSc', 'dr. MBJ Schauten', 'dr. S van Kampen']
text:
Inhoud The performance of a corporation depends on how well managers succeed in creating value. This course will demonstrate how several financial theories can be applied in order to create value. In this course, we discuss three main issues in finance: capital budgeting, asset pricing and financial investments.
 
The capital budgeting decision involves how firms select projects that create value. We emphasize the net present value method, which is considered as the most frequently used optimal decision method. In addition, we also discuss several other selection criteria and explain how these criteria are related to the net present value method.

The asset pricing part concerns the way financial assets are priced by the market. The focus is on the pricing of stocks issued by firms and bonds issued by firms and governments. Questions raised are: What is the influence of the expected stream of dividends and the level of market risk of firm’s projects on the price of stocks? How are the term structure of interest rates and promised coupon payments related to bond prices? Is it possible to create value by lowering the pay-out ratio and investing in growth? Who benefits from the value that is added when a takeover occurs?

The financial investment decision is approached from a portfolio perspective and ends with a discussion of the Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM). In practice, this model is often used to set a discount rate for capital budgeting purposes.
  Leerdoelen Learning goals
After following this course, the student is able to:
  • Analyse and make use of financial statements in relation to valuation and capital budgeting;
  • Apply and evaluate capital budgeting techniques;
  • Determine the value of financial assets such as stocks and bonds;
  • Explain Portfolio Theory and apply this theory to form portfolios of financial assets;
  • Explain the CAPM and apply this model to determine the cost of capital;
  • Explain the Efficient Markets Hypothesis and analyse its implications.
